speaker: Sothis
text: Bandits, they say…

speaker: Sothis
text: Do you recall when we first met? You shall not fall so shamelessly again, correct?

speaker: Sothis
text: Have you no words for me? Do not tell me that you are shocked to hear from me! You ought to know that I am always with you now. To hear my voice should not come as a shock.

speaker: Byleth
text: Right.

speaker: Byleth
text: I don't understand.

speaker: Sothis
text: Whatever shall I do with you? I am alive within the confines of your heart. I am unknown to all but you. But through your eyes and ears, I see and hear. Just listen to your heart, as you are doing now, and we may speak like this. That is all that I know.

speaker: Kostas
text: What is this nonsense?! All I was told was to kill as many noble pipsqueaks as possible! No one said anything about the Knights of damned Seiros being on our trail!

speaker: Flame Emperor
text: You have proven yourself worthless. Distracted by something so trivial. I had hoped you would achieve your goal despite the setback. But now a child of the Knights’ former captain is in play. How interesting.

speaker: Kostas
text: Hey, this isn't what I agreed to!

speaker: Flame Emperor
text: Hiring a mercenary as a professor. What was that woman thinking?

speaker: Kostas
text: Are you listening to me?! How do we finish this?!

speaker: Flame Emperor
text: You die.

speaker: Kostas
text: Wh– What?

speaker: Flame Emperor
text: Underestimating the Knights was an amateur mistake. One you will pay for. The road to eternal torment awaits you all. Now I must locate your replacements...

speaker: Kostas
text: Wait! Get back here! Damn you!

speaker: Rhea
text: We are planning a grand ball for this month. I am sure the students will be most pleased.

speaker: Seteth
text: Yes, certainly. However, we must not devote all of our time to frivolity. We have a new mission for you. We have found evidence of someone sneaking into an unused chapel.

speaker: Byleth
text: A chapel?

speaker: Rhea
text: It is a building that was once a temporary sanctuary at a time when the monastery was under renovation.

speaker: Byleth
text: Was something stolen?

speaker: Rhea
text: No, there is nothing of value in that building. We do not yet know what the intruders' objectives are.

speaker: Seteth
text: This month, your class is tasked with guarding the chapel and investigating these intruders. With the recent state of affairs surrounding the holy church, we cannot afford to overlook any abnormality, no matter how seemingly trivial.

speaker: Rhea
text: I am ordering a seasoned knight to assist you to ensure the safety of the students. In times like these, I am afraid we must always expect the worst.

speaker: Byleth
text: That's reassuring.

speaker: Byleth
text: Which knight?

speaker: Jeralt
text: Reporting for duty, Lady Rhea.

speaker: Rhea
text: I thought you two could use the time to bond. And to speak of important matters...

speaker: Jeralt
text: Appreciate the thought.

speaker: Seteth
text: Bear in mind that Jeralt has a separate mission of his own. He will join you once he has finished it.

speaker: Jeralt
text: It's true. I'll be away from the monastery for a while. But when I return... I'll come and watch you work. I'll be looking forward to it.

speaker: Sothis
text: Tomas... No, Solon, was it not? And the Flame Emperor... It is most clear that something has transpired. And it relates to you somehow. Or is the fault my own, and you're just caught inside the wave... Sothis, the goddess of this world... I bear her name... Hmm... How confusing. I feel as though my head has turned to mush!

speaker: Edelgard
text: Everyone's in such a festive mood. I feel a bit out of my element here. I can't help but worry something might happen while we're all distracted... After all, our enemies are always plotting. Still, this air of levity is much more agreeable than the grim atmosphere of late.

speaker: Dimitri
text: It seems the dastards who set Remire Village aflame have yet to be apprehended. Monsters. Trampling mercilessly over innocent lives. They deserve a gruesome end...

speaker: Claude
text: Someone entered the old chapel... I think the townsfolk used it for feasts and such in the past. With that whole Tomas business, you can't blame the church for being on edge.

speaker: Hubert
text: Another month full of chaos. I've barely had time to catch my breath. What is the objective of Tomas and his ilk? And what makes Flayn so special–does that not bother you?

speaker: Ferdinand
text: Ah, the ball. It reminds me of my first such event, back in the Imperial capital. It was held by my father, the prime minister. I really showed off my dancing skills! Everyone was quite impressed with me.

speaker: Linhardt
text: You know, Professor, I used to think I would be comfortable with all manner of experiments, so long as they provided usable results. But when I heard of Solon's work, well, I realized I'd not consider the moral and philosophical limits of what "all manner of experiments" might mean. Urk... Sorry. I'm not great with blood, even when I'm just thinking about it. I feel a bit ill now.

speaker: Caspar
text: I can't believe this... I'm so angry right now! First it's the Death Knight, and now Tomas, and neither of them are in custody! I can't stand the thought of such evil lurking in the world. We have to do something about this! I have to do something about this!

speaker: Bernadetta
text: The ball. A grim reminder of my sad reality. The other nobles will be fine, I'm sure. They've all been to events like this before. But me? I'm a noble, and I've never even been close to one of these things!

speaker: Dorothea
text: I wonder if Remire Village will ever be the same again. How do you recover from such a terrible event? So many dead, so much destroyed... I can't see how the whole village doesn't just end up abandoned.

speaker: Dorothea
text: Our class was also sent to help put the village in order. But then…

speaker: Petra
text: Dancing of Fódlan is not the same as dancing of Brigid. The reason is maybe that the music has many differences. In Brigid, dancing is different for each person. Our dancing has vigor and ferocity. There is no speech of technique for our dancing.

speaker: Dedue
text: Even though there is to be a ball, we still have a mission. It would be nice if this month passed by in peace.

speaker: Felix
text: Argh... Too much merriment. The librarian betrayed us. The Death Knight is back. Is this the time to be throwing a ball?

speaker: Ashe
text: Last month was– Well, you know even better than I do. I hope this one will be more cheerful. This ball though... I don't know. It's all new to me.

speaker: Sylvain
text: Great work in Remire Village, Professor. Who would have ever guessed it was Tomas? Ah, but no. Now isn't the time to get lost in gloomy thoughts.

speaker: Mercedes
text: Oh, now, where did that Ingrid run off to? The ball is soon and she hadn't even put on any makeup! I was trying to help her out.

speaker: Annette
text: So, Tomas the librarian was a bad guy? But he always seemed so nice! C'mon, self. You're better than this. You promised you'd be on top of things this month.

speaker: Ingrid
text: Mercedes locked me in her room for hours earlier... She was slathering pounds of makeup onto my face. Saying something or other about the ball. It really wore me out...

speaker: Lorenz
text: Ah. The long-awaited ball. Finally, an opportunity to showcase my exquisite skills on the dance floor. These skills were ingrained in me when I was a boy. My hands and feet move on pure instinct.

speaker: Raphael
text: The ball is coming up soon! I am so excited! I can't wait to fill up on food while everyone's dancing. I even heard there'll be some prime cuts of meat!

speaker: Ignatz
text: Some scary things have been happening lately. I hope that this month, of all months, is peaceful. The ball is coming up and everything... Although I'm not much of a dancer actually.

speaker: Lysithea
text: It's true that Tomas was employed here under the recommendation of House Ordelia. But that's all I know of the topic. I'd never even seen him prior to enrolling here. Even when he was supposedly in Ordelia territory, I never once saw him there. I'm still feeling bothered by all of this, but...there's not much else I can say about it right now.

speaker: Marianne
text: A ball? Um, I don't think I'll partake.

speaker: Hilda
text: It's almost time for the ball! Oooh my, am I excited! This being a school, we don't have many chances to get dressy.

speaker: Leonie
text: I'm glad the Remire Village situation got sorted out. But it's not over yet, is it? And I can't believe old Tomas turned out to be an enemy. Who can you trust anymore?

speaker: Rhea
text: Before the ball, it is customary that we host a competition of dance known as the White Heron Cup. The students are quite fond of this tradition. Each house must select representatives to compete. Their dance shall be judged by its beauty, grace, and technique. The student who is deemed the winner will be given the opportunity to train as a dancer, should they so please. It is a very precious thing, the gift of dance. I hope that you and your students will choose to participate.

speaker: Rhea
text: I have been told that your house won the White Heron Cup. This can only be a result of the students' talent and effort, not to mention your steadfast instruction.

speaker: Rhea
text: It would appear your house was defeated in the White Heron Cup. With the White Heron Cup concluded, all that is left is to wait for the ball. I hope you will find it enjoyable.

speaker: Rhea
text: It has come to my attention that you did not participate in the White Heron Cup. Were none of your students skilled in dance? With the White Heron Cup concluded, all that is left is to wait for the ball. I hope you will find it enjoyable.

speaker: Seteth
text: I have looked into Tomas, but I just cannot make sense of this at all. From his behavior up until now, I never would have suspected that a man like him could turn on us. I have also discovered that his appearance has changed... It is almost as if he is not even human! What in the world is going on?

speaker: Flayn
text: Hello Professor! The ball will soon be upon us. Ah, I can feel my heart fluttering already! I... I have never danced in front of people before. Not even once in all my life. I am very much looking forward to it!

speaker: Alois
text: Ah, the ball... It reminds me of how I met my wife. I was at a village's harvest festival. There was a full moon bathing everything in its cool glow. She appeared out of nowhere, dancing gracefully in the moonlight–a lovely fairy!

speaker: Byleth
text: That story sounds fake.

speaker: Alois
text: Hah! The "full moon" was an embellishment, I admit. But you can forgive a man for waxing poetic, can't you? Anyway...

speaker: Byleth
text: That's a wonderful story.

speaker: Alois
text: We soon fell in love and tied the knot. Now we have a daughter, who's as bright and beautiful as a sunny morning. So, whenever I see people dancing, I think of my wife, and my heart does a little waltz.

speaker: Catherine
text: The area with the old chapel was supposed to be off-limits. It was at risk of collapse, so they didn't even post guards. It's not too strange. Does that surprise you? Eh, Garreg Mach has lots of places that are blocked off for one reason or another. That's true of the underground Holy Mausoleum as well as the northern woods. People call it the sealed forest, but as far as I can tell, it's nothing special. Just a forest.

speaker: Shamir
text: What's this about? The ball? Knights don't participate. It's an event for students, but it does pique the interest of some knights in particular.

speaker: Shamir
text: Alois can't dance, but I hear he likes to watch. He volunteered to judge the White Heron Cup. Not that I care.

speaker: Gilbert
text: It cannot be true that our siblings-in-arms could turn against us. However, I will continue investigating members of the church. To think even someone as senior as Tomas would fall under suspicion... I know not how far to take my search.

speaker: Byleth
text: Even the knights...

speaker: Gilbert
text: Unlike the monks, the Knights of Seiros are Lady Rhea's direct subordinates. Some are in quite unique circumstances, but I cannot think any of them would betray us.

speaker: Byleth
text: Even the students...

speaker: Gilbert
text: Yes, a great many strange and terrible things have come to pass this year... I must not dismiss the possibility that someone among the students is behind it all.

speaker: Hanneman
text: Garreg Mach Monastery is said to have been completed during the Ethereal Moon. Why, 995 years ago as a matter of fact. That's rather a long time ago, don't you think? Every year, a ball is held to celebrate the founding. And every one hundred years, a very special celebration takes place. It's a grand festival, involving all of Garreg Mach. It is thrilling to read of past festivals, and I'm rather excited to experience one for myself. Once in a lifetime, eh? The next one, in five years, will make a millennium. Should be quite an event. Do you imagine you'll still be here teaching then?

speaker: Manuela
text: Great. Just...great. It's that time when all the students get all lovey-dovey. You're new, but you know about the ball, yeah? I can't bear it. Young love is wasted on the young. They can't appreciate it to its fullest! Ugh, I wish I could fall in love too...

speaker: Manuela
text: Oh! Speaking of the ball, Professor, have you selected your representative for the dance contest yet? If you don't, the contest will go on without your house. And that would be...embarrassing.

speaker: Cyril
text: Nah, Tomas wouldn't betray the church. I don't believe it. I won't believe it! There's some people in the church who hate people like me who are from Almyra, but Tomas was always real kind. But if he really was Lady Rhea's enemy... Well, I'd defend her against anybody. No matter how kind they'd been in the past.

speaker: Anna
text: Hey, Professor. How's it going? Making lots of coin? I'd love to catch up, but I'm super busy right now. Working. For money. You understand.

speaker: Gatekeeper
text: Greetings, Professor! Nothing to report! Ah, other than the legend of the Goddess Tower, of course. Have you heard the students talking about it? On the last night of the Ethereal Moon, on the same night as the ball... If a man and a woman go to the Goddess Tower and make a wish, it's sure to come true! I have a wish, but I can't find anybody to make it with me...

speaker: Byleth
text: (Is there someone I feel that way about?)

speaker: Rhea
text: The White Heron Cup is a competition of skill and grace in dance. Please encourage your house to participate. That said, if you are serious about winning, be sure to choose your representative carefully.

speaker: Edelgard
text: By the way, have you chosen our house's representative for the White Heron Cup? If nobody else comes to mind, I'm willing to take up the challenge, Professor.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Understood. Just leave this to me and victory is assured.

speaker: Edelgard
text: I see... If you believe there's someone more qualified, I certainly won't object.

speaker: Hubert
text: On a lighter note. I've heard you've yet to choose a class representative for the White Heron Cup. It's not something I'm interested in, but if no one else wants to do it, then I will shoulder the burden.

speaker: Hubert
text: How very whimsical of you. I suppose I'll have to do what I can.

speaker: Hubert
text: Wise. Better to choose someone with more charm.

speaker: Ferdinand
text: Do you see what I am trying to say here? Do not make me beg you... Please, choose me as our representative for the White Heron Cup!

speaker: Ferdinand
text: Wonderful! You will have a chance to see the legendary footwork of House Aegir!

speaker: Ferdinand
text: Hmph. If you really think someone is better suited for it, I will not argue.

speaker: Linhardt
text: Let us change the subject and settle my stomach. I assume you've heard about the dance competition? Have you chosen a representative yet? Or... Oh my. You haven't, have you? Have you come to tell me I'm to be it?

speaker: Linhardt
text: I see... I can dance, in theory, but I dare say in practice things may go very differently.

speaker: Linhardt
text: I think that's wise. I simply can't really be bothe-- What I mean to say is I lack the confidence.

speaker: Caspar
text: Ugh. Sorry about that, Professor. I'm just so frustrated right now. I need something to take my mind off things. That reminds me! If you're looking for a volunteer, I'd be happy to represent our class in the White Heron Cup. I'm an excellent Dancer.

speaker: Caspar
text: Great! We both know I'm our class's best chance at winning this thing.

speaker: Caspar
text: You really think you can find a better dancer than me?

speaker: Bernadetta
text: What is a White Heron Cup, anyway? Wh-what?! A dance competition?! That's terrifying! W-we need a representative for our class?! Please, anyone but Bernie!

speaker: Bernadetta
text: You're just trying to humiliate me, aren't you?

speaker: Bernadetta
text: Oh, what a relief! Thank you so much, Professor!

speaker: Dorothea
text: I'm sorry, Professor. I'm talking about such grim and terrible things when we could be talking about the White Heron Cup. It's a big dance contest between the classes, and I simply adore dancing. I'm quite good at it, since I was a diva in an opera company, you know.

speaker: Dorothea
text: I think my heart just skipped a beat. You want me to represent the class? I'm not sure when I last experienced such flattery, Professor.

speaker: Dorothea
text: What? Why not me? Oh, whatever. So long as you remember to chose someone, hm?

speaker: Petra
text: Are you choosing me to represent at the White Heron Cup? Or are you not?

speaker: Petra
text: I will display all that I have learned. I will grab the victory!

speaker: Petra
text: I have understanding. You believe that I cannot grab the victory, I am guessing?

speaker: Dimitri
text: I... I'm sorry. Please ignore my troubled ramblings. Was something the matter? Something to do with the White Heron Cup? Professor, I beg of you. Please do not chose me as our house representative. I am utterly serious.

speaker: Dimitri
text: What?! Curse you, Professor. I will of course accept, but know that you have damned us all.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Oh, thank the goddess. Please be sure to select someone with the confidence to win for us.

speaker: Dedue
text: Incidentally, I have heard there will be a dance competition prior to the ball. Have you chosen a representative yet?

speaker: Dedue
text: I will take part, if you insist.

speaker: Dedue
text: Someone must want to participate. You would do well to find that person.

speaker: Felix
text: Ah, whatever. You look like you're about to say something. Are you considering me as our representative for the White Heron Cup? Heh.

speaker: Felix
text: I was joking. You really couldn't find anyone else?

speaker: Felix
text: I see. That's a relief.

speaker: Ashe
text: But speaking of the ball, isn't there something happening just before it? The White...Heron...something? It sounds like every class needs a representative. Have you picked ours yet?

speaker: Ashe
text: Are you sure you want m-me to do this? I guess I'll just have to do the best I can, then.

speaker: Ashe
text: You should pick one of the nobles. They all have experience with this sort of thing.

speaker: Sylvain
text: The ball is almost here...and the White Heron Cup dance contest. So, Professor, who will be representing our class?

speaker: Sylvain
text: Me? Uh, sure! Why not? I'll get out there, show off my moves, and drive the ladies wild.

speaker: Sylvain
text: I get it. No worries, really. I'd rather see a beautiful person dancing instead of some goof like me.

speaker: Mercedes
text: While we're on the subject of the ball, what's this I hear about a dance competition? Physical activity isn't my forte, but dancing can be fun! If there's no one else you'd rather select, I'm happy to represent our class.

speaker: Mercedes
text: Thanks for having faith in me, Professor! I'll try my best to win!

speaker: Mercedes
text: Are you sure? Please let me know if you change your mind!

speaker: Annette
text: After all, we have the ball to look forward to, and the White Heron Cup before that! Oh, speaking of have you chosen our house representative yet? If not, I'd like to volunteer!

speaker: Annette
text: Really? That's fantastic! I'll try as hard as anyone's ever tried, you can count on it!

speaker: Annette
text: Aw, that's too bad. But if you reconsider, you know where to find me!

speaker: Ingrid
text: Speaking of, I heard that there's going to be a dance competition. Have you sorted out who will represent our class, Professor? It's not me, is it? Please don't say it's me...

speaker: Ingrid
text: Oh dear... Well, I'll see what I can do, then. On my honor.

speaker: Ingrid
text: Thank goodness. I don't know the first thing about dancing.

speaker: Claude
text: Considering this recent rash of strange incidents, I wonder if having a ball is really the best idea... And then there's the White Heron Cup. Sheesh. What poor sap are you enlisting to represent our house, Teach?

speaker: Claude
text: Claude: Me?! Don't be unreasonable, Teach! Ugh... I mean, if I have to make a miracle happen, I guess I'll figure it out...

speaker: Hilda
text: Oh, but first, the White Heron Cup! Who will appear onstage, I wonder? You're choosing a representative for the dance contest, isn't that right? Choose me! I'm a pro!

speaker: Hilda
text: Great! Now that I'm in the spotlight, I'll do anything to win!

speaker: Hilda
text: Aww, I was really getting excited for it. Let me know if you change your mind, huh?

speaker: Lorenz
text: From what I hear, the White Heron Cup will be held just prior to the ball. Say no more, Professor. I would consider it an honor to represent our class!

speaker: Lorenz
text: You will not regret this choice!

speaker: Lorenz
text: By all means, take your time and think it over. But I do assure you, there is no candidate better suited to the task than yours truly.

speaker: Raphael
text: Apparently there's supposed to be a dance contest too. I think it's called the White Heron Cup. Who's gonna represent our class? I can do it if you haven't picked someone else!

speaker: Raphael
text: You made the right choice, Professor! Everyone's gonna think my moves are hilarious!

speaker: Raphael
text: Aww, really? I may not look it, but I'm actually a pretty good dancer.

speaker: Ignatz
text: Watching other people dance can be fun though. I've heard people talking about the White Heron Cup. Do you know who will be representing us?

speaker: Ignatz
text: Me?! What? No, please! You can't!

speaker: Ignatz
text: I think a noble would make for a better choice. Bound to know their way around a ballroom.

speaker: Lysithea
text: Right... It's the dance this month, isn't it? I can't see how anyone would be much in the mood for dancing, considering... Although I suppose the White Heron Cup does sound pretty fun.

speaker: Lysithea
text: Uh, you want me to be our representative? I've certainly got a few moves...

speaker: Lysithea
text: It would probably be more logical to ask someone who likes dancing in the first place, so I certainly understand.

speaker: Marianne
text: There's a dance contest as well? I see. I'll cheer for our class, of course. So, um... Who will represent our house in the contest?

speaker: Marianne
text: I see, well... Um, I'm sorry. What did you say?

speaker: Marianne
text: I'm sure whoever represents our class will do a fine job. Much better than I could do.

speaker: Leonie
text: The ball? Doesn't matter. I don't dance. I might show up for the food though. Not that it's got anything to do with me, but have you picked someone to represent us for the White Heron Cup yet?

speaker: Leonie
text: What? You're asking a peasant to dance? You've got some pretty weird ideas!

speaker: Leonie
text: Well, someone's bound to want to do it. I'm sure we've got a few people with the talent to win too.

speaker: Flayn
text: Have you heard yet about the White Heron Cup? If you have yet to choose a representative, do you mind terribly if I volunteer?

speaker: Flayn
text: Ah, thank you, Professor! I am overcome with joy! Just you wait until my feet touch the ballroom floor!

speaker: Flayn
text: Understood. Ah, well. Either way, I am still so excited about the ball!

speaker: Edelgard
text: Well, I suppose we should practice, then. Shall we?

speaker: Edelgard
text: How was that? I believe I've improved my technique.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Huh... Well, let's practice whenever you can spare the time. Agreed?

speaker: Hubert
text: To think I'd be rehearsing my dance moves, of all things. Give me some advice, Professor.

speaker: Hubert
text: A little less grotesque now? Maybe.

speaker: Hubert
text: All right. But if we want to avoid a tragic accident during the contest, I will need more practice.

speaker: Ferdinand
text: Professor, uh... Do you know how to dance? I could really use some guidance.

speaker: Ferdinand
text: You really can do everything! I am envious of you, if you will pardon my frankness.

speaker: Ferdinand
text: Fair enough. You do not think I need guidance. You are probably right.

speaker: Linhardt
text: Professor? Are you here to practice with me for the dance contest?

speaker: Linhardt
text: I don't enjoy a bit of this, you know. Entirely too much standing up and moving around for my taste. But if I'm going to do it, I may as well be in it to win.

speaker: Linhardt
text: I see... Well, that's just fine by me. There's a book on fishing that I'd like to finish.

speaker: Caspar
text: Hey, Professor! Did you want to practice dancing with me?

speaker: Caspar
text: What did you think? Pretty perfect, right?

speaker: Caspar
text: You're probably right. I don't need any more practice. I'm a natural!

speaker: Bernadetta
text: Professor! Will you give me some dancing lessons?

speaker: Bernadetta
text: Was that okay? A little reassuring at least? Maybe?

speaker: Bernadetta
text: Is this your idea of an education? Clip my wings and toss me off a cliff?!

speaker: Dorothea
text: Hey, Professor. You're here to help me practice for the dance contest?

speaker: Dorothea
text: How was that? Was my dancing everything you hoped for and more? I certainly enjoyed it. We simply must do it again. Soon.

speaker: Dorothea
text: Well, I am terribly talented, agreed. Still, I think I'll practice on my own if you're too busy.

speaker: Petra
text: I have much to be learned. We will now practice the dancing, OK?

speaker: Petra
text: I have much more knowledge of Fódlan lance. How is my dancing, Professor?

speaker: Petra
text: That is not fortunate. I will have patience.

speaker: Dimitri
text: I am in the thick of battle, so battle I must. Will you help me prepare, Professor?

speaker: Dimitri
text: How...was that? I perhaps did not offend as much as usual, but...I do not like our chances.

speaker: Dimitri
text: I suppose I must practice diligently while I can. On my own. Away from prying eyes.

speaker: Dedue
text: Will you teach me to dance?

speaker: Dedue
text: Was that satisfactory?

speaker: Dedue
text: That makes things difficult.

speaker: Felix
text: Here, help me practice my dancing. You forced me into this, so you're going to help me.

speaker: Felix
text: How did I get roped into this?

speaker: Felix
text: Hmph! You irresponsible fiend.

speaker: Ashe
text: I've been practicing as best as I can, Professor, but do you think you could give me a little help?

speaker: Ashe
text: Was that all right? I'm completely self-taught, so I really have no idea.

speaker: Ashe
text: You really want to leave this all up to me?

speaker: Sylvain
text: Oh, Professor! I'm glad you're here. I need help figuring out this whole...dancing thing. Mind helping me?

speaker: Sylvain
text: One and two and three and four... Got it! I'm pretty good at this.

speaker: Sylvain
text: Aw, don't be like that, Professor. You chose me... You should help me win.

speaker: Mercedes
text: Oh, Professor? Do you mind watching my dance routine? I would appreciate your honest opinion.

speaker: Mercedes
text: How was that? I hope it's good enough to win...

speaker: Mercedes
text: I'm so sorry, I didn't realize you were busy. I didn't mean to distract you.

speaker: Annette
text: Professor! Would you watch me dance really quick? I've been practicing a ton!

speaker: Annette
text: Mwahaha! Well? What do you think? I'd say I'm pretty great. Wouldn't you?

speaker: Annette
text: Oh, do you have really important professor things to do? Well, let me know when you have the time!

speaker: Ingrid
text: Professor, I admit--I have two left feet when it comes to dancing. Do you have time to give me any pointers?

speaker: Ingrid
text: How did I do? Was I awkward? I felt awkward.

speaker: Ingrid
text: Perhaps some other time, then. Since you chose me, I'll need your guidance in all this.

speaker: Claude
text: Teach, this is all your doing. Step up and take responsibility. You've got to help me practice my dance moves.

speaker: Claude
text: My legs aren't as unwieldy as before, I think... If I keep this up, I might do not terribly.

speaker: Claude
text: You're too busy? Too busy to take responsibility for your actions? Wow. Well, you'd better make time for me before it's too late.

speaker: Hilda
text: Hey, Professor! Care to join me for dance practice?

speaker: Hilda
text: Phew! I don't think we can possibly lose. Just you wait and see.

speaker: Hilda
text: What, you've got something better to do than watch me practice?

speaker: Lorenz
text: Rehearsals will not be necessary. But, if you insist, I can give you a small taste of what is to come.

speaker: Lorenz
text: Well, Professor? Are those not the most exquisitely refined moved you have ever witnessed?

speaker: Lorenz
text: I assure you, dancing is fully ingrained in my being. Any further practice would be redundant.

speaker: Raphael
text: Hey, Professor! You want to teach me some winning dance moves?

speaker: Raphael
text: That looked pretty good, right? I think I can win this thing!

speaker: Raphael
text: If you think my moves are good enough, then I don't need dance lessons.

speaker: Ignatz
text: Professor, can you watch me practice?

speaker: Ignatz
text: Is this how you do it? I'm feeling a little unsteady...

speaker: Ignatz
text: Professor, don't abandon me in my time of need! Why'd you pick me in the first place?!

speaker: Lysithea
text: Professor, can you supervise my dance rehearsal? If I'm going to do this, I want to win it.

speaker: Lysithea
text: Well? How was I? I figure if I dance with passion and fervor, I'll appear even more mature.

speaker: Lysithea
text: You've chosen me, but you won't even bother to help me prepare? That's rather rude, Professor!

speaker: Marianne
text: Did you need something, Professor? I suppose I should p-practice, right?

speaker: Marianne
text: No, no. That's no good. I can't seem to get a feel for it...

speaker: Marianne
text: Oh. Very well.

speaker: Leonie
text: Professor! Come join me for dance practice!

speaker: Leonie
text: I'm going to have to do this in front of a crowd? I can feel myself going pale already.

speaker: Leonie
text: Hey, you're the one who put me up to this! The least you can do is give me a hand!

speaker: Flayn
text: Yes? Do you need me for anything, Professor? I would be happy for some dancing guidance, should you have any!

speaker: Flayn
text: Thank you so much. I am eager to improve my dancing.

speaker: Flayn
text: I see. Perhaps soon!

speaker: Alois
text: Ladies and gentlemen! My sincerest apologies for the wait! Thank you for gathering here on the eve of the highly anticipated ball to bear witness to... The academy-wide dance competition! Welcome to the White Heron Cup!

speaker: Alois
text: The competition will be judged by...me! Your humble servant, Alois Rangeld! And also... The acclaimed former songstress of the Mittelfrank Opera Company, Manuela Casagranda!

speaker: Manuela
text: Yes, yes, thank you. Oh, and it should go without saying, but I swear to show no bias to my own house. Got it? Good.

speaker: Alois
text: Last but not least, the glamorous assassin who does all of her dancing in the dead of night...Shamir Nevrand!

speaker: Shamir
text: Hmph.

speaker: Alois
text: The three of us swear on our honor to judge the following proceedings with utmost impartiality and fairness! And with that, will the representatives of each house please make their way to the stage!

speaker: Alois
text: Contestants! Are you ready to dance? And is the band prepared to play? Very well... BEGIN!

speaker: Alois
text: TIME! That's all, folks! Splendid! All three of you were fantastic! Now, let's hear what the judges have to say...

speaker: Manuela
text: Oh my, let's see. I suppose I have no choice but to vote for...

speaker: Manuela
text: Oh my, let's see. I suppose I have no choice but to vote for...

speaker: Alois
text: Great feedback, both of you! Well then, let's see... Factoring my own humble opinion... Yes! We have a winner! And I will announce who it is...right now! Without any delay! The winner of this year's White Heron Cup is...

speaker: Edelgard
text: Well, a victory is a victory.

speaker: Hubert
text: I am not sure the judges are in their right minds...

speaker: Ferdinand
text: Haha! As expected of someone as accomplished as myself.

speaker: Linhardt
text: Oh? Well, just so long as nothing else is expected from me.

speaker: Caspar
text: I won? I won! How did I win?!

speaker: Bernadetta
text: Bernie? Are you sure? Heh...heh...

speaker: Dorothea
text: I wonder if I can use this to bolster my singing career...

speaker: Petra
text: Everywhere, dancing is dancing. This is the proof.

speaker: Dimitri
text: I won? There must be some mistake...

speaker: Dedue
text: Is this a joke?

speaker: Felix
text: Nonsense.

speaker: Ashe
text: Are you sure this is OK?

speaker: Sylvain
text: Heh heh heh! I knew I had it in me!

speaker: Mercedes
text: Oh, really? How lovely!

speaker: Annette
text: I did it! Go me!

speaker: Ingrid
text: Oh. Um. Sorry. I really didn't see this coming.

speaker: Claude
text: Ah, what a burden to be great at everything!

speaker: Hilda
text: Perfect! Where's the prize? There is a prize, right?

speaker: Lorenz
text: Haha! As expected!

speaker: Raphael
text: Me? Uh, really?

speaker: Ignatz
text: Can't say I had much confidence going in, but this is great!

speaker: Lysithea
text: Yes, it was the logical choice. My dancing was superior.

speaker: Marianne
text: Oh dear... This is a bit embarrassing.

speaker: Leonie
text: I can dance? Huh!

speaker: Flayn
text: Have I prevailed? Oh, most glorious! My practice was not in vain!

speaker: Edelgard
text: The ball is tomorrow. I have no worthwhile memories of such events, yet I'm still looking forward to this one.

speaker: Hubert
text: As am I, in the sense that I look forward to destroying all of the unworthy suitors who will inevitably swarm Lady Edelgard.

speaker: Ferdinand
text: I will admit, Edelgard is adorable. However, when it comes to elegance on the dance floor, I am superior!

speaker: Dorothea
text: You're not a bad dancer, Ferdie. But you do have some moves that are...hard to watch.

speaker: Ferdinand
text: You honor me with your kind words! I understand that I am sometimes too dazzling to behold directly.

speaker: Linhardt
text: I'm envious of your positive attitude. I also know how to dance...in theory. Maybe I should participate as well.

speaker: Bernadetta
text: Not me! You wouldn't catch me dancing at a ball any sooner than you'd catch a fish swimming through the sky!

speaker: Caspar
text: You do tend to flop around like a fish on the land, after all.

speaker: Bernadetta
text: Wh-why would you say that?! Now I feel like a fish on a skillet...

speaker: Linhardt
text: On a skillet... Hahaha! Ahem, never mind.

speaker: Caspar
text: Speaking of the ball, do we get to pick who we dance with? I wonder who I should ask...

speaker: Hubert
text: A bold subject change. Should Lady Edelgard wish it, I would be honored to...

speaker: Petra
text: I will fight with all that I have in me!

speaker: Dorothea
text: Fighting? No, that's not really the point...

speaker: Petra
text: I will not be as a fish upon the flame!

speaker: Dorothea
text: Um... OK...

speaker: Edelgard
text: I have a proposition. Let's all agree to meet back at the monastery exactly five years from today.

speaker: Caspar
text: Like a class reunion? That's a great idea!

speaker: Hubert
text: Five years from today will be the millennium festival for Garreg Mach Monastery. I've heard the magnitude of the festivities will exceed all prior years.

speaker: Dorothea
text: Ooh, how exciting! Sounds like a great excuse to come visit our dear professor.

speaker: Petra
text: You will be seeing how much growing I have done. You will be pleased, Professor. This idea is good!

speaker: Edelgard
text: Who knows where each of us will be in five years' time...or who we will become. Still, I have faith that all of us will gather and celebrate our reunion.

speaker: Linhardt
text: That's assuming the professor is still here in five years...and not enjoying a cozy early retirement.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Even if that's the case, you will come, won't you? Whether or not you're still teaching here...

speaker: Byleth
text: Of course.

speaker: Byleth
text: I will try.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Don't forget, my teacher. Even if the millennium festival should be canceled, I promise to return here...

speaker: Dimitri
text: This is the only ball of the year, and I see why. Everyone is absurdly excited...

speaker: Dedue
text: Your Highness, you sound so detached. We are all encouraged to enjoy the ball tomorrow.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Right you are, What a burden...

speaker: Felix
text: Huh. I never thought we'd see eye to eye, but I agree. I'd rather be swinging my blade than wasting my time with some girl at a ball.

speaker: Sylvain
text: Felix! Your Highness! You must be joking, right? This is our chance to dance with all of the ladies of the academy to our heart's content. You wish to throw away the best day of the whole year for sword practice? Insanity, I tell you!

speaker: Ashe
text: I'm pretty excited about the ball, myself. It's not like we get to do things like this very often.

speaker: Sylvain
text: Too true, Ashe. In fact, I'm gonna do you a favor and give you a crash course in chatting up girls. By tomorrow, you'll be an expert!

speaker: Ashe
text: Actually I'd much prefer if someone could just teach us how to dance...

speaker: Annette
text: Don't worry about the dancing part. I can teach you that, easy!

speaker: Mercedes
text: It's time for the ball! That warrants at least a tiny bit of makeup, don't you think, Ingrid? Just a smidge?

speaker: Ingrid
text: I...hmm. Maybe. I'll think about it.

speaker: Annette
text: It's settled! Tomorrow morning we'll meet up in Ingrid's room. Ooh, I can't wait!

speaker: Dimitri
text: Hahaha. You know... There's no telling where life will take us after we leave here. If only we could find a way to come together again, just like this...

speaker: Dedue
text: A fine notion, Your Highness. Perhaps five years from now?

speaker: Dimitri
text: Five years from now? Ah! That's when Garreg Mach Monastery will be holding the millennium festival.

speaker: Ingrid
text: By then we'll be addressing Your Highness as Your Majesty instead!

speaker: Sylvain
text: That's right. I suppose we all know it's coming, but by then you'll be far removed from us.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Come now. You know me better than that. My title may change, but I won't. And it won't just be me, you know. Five years from now, you'll all have your own stuffy positions to contend with. But as I understand it, the festivities at the millennium festival will be of a scale far beyond anything we've yet seen... In other words, the perfect excuse for us all to return here.

speaker: Annette
text: Ooh, a reunion? That sounds fun! I wouldn't miss it for the world!

speaker: Dimitri
text: I'd love for you to be there as well, Professor. After all, you're the heart of the Blue Lion House.

speaker: Byleth
text: I'll be there.

speaker: Byleth
text: I'll try.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Good. Then it's settled. Of course...if something happens and I'm not able to attend, I'm leaving all of the logistics of organizing this reunion to you, Professor.

speaker: Byleth
text: You have to attend.

speaker: Mercedes
text: It's true! I'm sure being a king will keep you busy, but it's a bit early to be backing out of your own plans, don't you think?

speaker: Dimitri
text: Yes... I suppose you're right. I'm sorry. You have my word. I will return as well. Count on it.

speaker: Claude
text: The time has come for the annual ball. But first, an eve of merriment! OK, I'll admit it. The Officers Academy isn't as uptight as I thought.

speaker: Hilda
text: Ooh, I adore such things! Dancing is the only thing I'm really good at anyway.

speaker: Raphael
text: There's a feast tomorrow, isn't there? Isn't there?! Ah, I can't want a moment longer!

speaker: Leonie
text: Dancing, singing... I'm not good at either of those things.

speaker: Hilda
text: So? Dancing is fun! Oh! And remember, you can't dance with the same partner multiple times. It's tradition! That means you have to dance with all of the gentlemen in all of the houses, swapping dance partners as you please...

speaker: Lysithea
text: How scandalous. I, for one, plan to simply behold the pure essence of dance.

speaker: Marianne
text: I'll, um.... watch. From a distance.

speaker: Hilda
text: You can't just watch, Marianne! If a boy asks you to dance, you simply must accept. It's only polite.

speaker: Ignatz
text: You can ask...anyone? To dance? Gah, whatever should I do?

speaker: Lorenz
text: Hahaha! Lucky you, Ignatz! Tomorrow, if only for a day, you may live out your dearest dreams of an exalted existence! As for me, I am surely to be overwhelmed with the propositions of desperate ladies. I will doubtless have little time for partners of my own choosing.

speaker: Leonie
text: Which one of you is dreaming now, Lorenz?

speaker: Claude
text: Everyone! Listen up. To no one's surprise, I have a brilliant idea. Teach, you'll want in on this too.

speaker: Byleth
text: What's your idea?

speaker: Claude
text: This may sound impetuous. Perhaps irresponsible. Almost certainly impossible. But we're gonna do it anyway. In exactly five years' time, let's promise to meet again, right here at the monastery.

speaker: Raphael
text: A reunion? There's usually food at reunions. Count me in, Claude!

speaker: Marianne
text: Five years from now... will be the monastery's millennium festival, celebrating 1,000 years since the founding of Garreg Mach.

speaker: Ignatz
text: I hear the millennium festival will be the largest celebration in the monastery's history.

speaker: Hilda
text: Oh, I get it! It'll be easier for us to all get back here with the millennium festival as an excuse.

speaker: Lorenz
text: How true. As the new leader of the Alliance, I will certainly have the occasion to attend and pay my respects to Lady Rhea.

speaker: Lysithea
text: That almost certainly will not transpire.

speaker: Claude
text: And you, Teach? I guess it's hard to imagine that you'll still be teaching here five years from now... But I'm sure no matter where you end up, you'll come running at the chance to see your adorable little Golden Deer again, right?

speaker: Byleth
text: I don't know.

speaker: Claude
text: Who knew Teach had a heart of ice? Too bad I can see from a mile away that you're joking. How you really feel is written all over your face.

speaker: Byleth
text: Probably so.

speaker: Claude
text: Ahem... That was your cue to promise everyone you'll return. Go on, set a good example, Teach. If you promise, everyone else will, too.

speaker: Lysithea
text: Hahaha! I'm already excited! After five years, we'll all be whoever we're going to become!

speaker: Leonie
text: Please, Professor! Invite Captain Jeralt too! I want to show him how well his apprentice turns out.

speaker: Hilda
text: It's settled, then. What do you say, Claude? Is it official?

speaker: Claude
text: The promise is sealed! That means we're all obligated to keep it. Five years from today, all of us will meet again at the monastery. Don't forget it, Teach. You and I will meet here again...

speaker: Sothis
text: Running away? I understand. You hardly had the time to breathe in there. It must be hard to be the favorite teacher at the ball! Poor, poor Professor!

speaker: Byleth
text: I am not everyone's favorite...

speaker: Sothis
text: Was that a joke? I find it hard to tell with you. Just think of all the students begging you to dance!

speaker: Byleth
text: It is difficult.

speaker: Sothis
text: So you do think you're the favorite! I might have known.

speaker: Sothis
text: But where is there to run? This place is filled with joyful students looking for a dance.

speaker: Sothis
text: Ah... I see. The Goddess Tower waits for you...

speaker: Edelgard
text: Ah, here you are. Are you waiting for someone?

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm not waiting for anyone.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Good. I would not wish to interrupt anything.

speaker: Byleth
text: I was waiting for you.

speaker: Edelgard
text: For me? Well, you should have summoned me earlier. Regardless, here I am.

speaker: Byleth
text: Has something happened?

speaker: Edelgard
text: No, nothing in particular. In fact, that's why I came here. This place, the Goddess Tower... It was special to my parents. My father attended the Officers Academy himself. A few years after graduating, he was crowned emperor. One day, during a visit to the monastery, he snuck into the Goddess Tower on a nostalgic whim. And there she was, my mother. She had just enrolled in the academy that very year. They were instantly drawn to each other. Love at first sight, you could say. It was the first time either had truly been in love... or so the story goes.

speaker: Byleth
text: Their first love?

speaker: Edelgard
text: Yes. Of course, as emperor, my father had already married for political reasons. As the Empire demands many heirs, he also had numerous other lovers. In the end, my mother settled for becoming one of his many consorts. But I choose to believe there was genuine love between them. Heh, I suppose it's a silly story to cling to.

speaker: Byleth
text: It's a lovely story.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Isn't it? It's a shame that the lovely stories ended after I was born. For as long as I can remember, my mother had already been exiled from the capital. It's strange. Something about you makes me reveal all of the things I so carefully keep concealed.

speaker: Byleth
text: Who was your first true love?

speaker: Edelgard
text: Hmmm. For some reason, I feel compelled to tell you all of these things I have kept hidden. I can't say the name, but it was a noble who I met in the Kingdom, a lifetime ago.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Anyway... What about you? It's your turn to reveal some long-held secret! You can share a story about your past...or perhaps tell me about your first love.

speaker: Byleth
text: I have no such stories

speaker: Edelgard
text: You're telling the truth. I can tell. Hm... I wasn't even able to make you blush.

speaker: Byleth
text: Please don't ask that of me.

speaker: Edelgard
text: You realize that just makes me more curious than ever!

speaker: Byleth
text: Sorry...

speaker: Edelgard
text: Heh... No, I'm the one who should apologize. It wasn't my intention to pry. I'm just intrigued by you and your mysterious past. You have supposedly always been a mercenary, but I believe there is more to your story than that... Let's leave it there for today and return to the ball. There must be plenty of students hoping to talk with you...and to dance with you. I would not wish to prevent you from mingling. I cannot keep you all to myself, after all.

speaker: Hubert
text: Here for a tryst, Professor? I won’t interfere. I shall take my leave at once. Farewell.

speaker: Byleth
text: Just a moment.

speaker: Hubert
text: Yes, what is it? I assume you are waiting on someone.

speaker: Byleth
text: What do you mean, a tryst?

speaker: Hubert
text: You have arranged to meet someone here at the Goddess Tower, have you not?

speaker: Byleth
text: No, not at all.

speaker: Hubert
text: I see. Apologies for the misunderstanding. Then I take it you are unfamiliar with the rumors about this place?

speaker: Byleth
text: What rumors?

speaker: Hubert
text: There is an old legend that says promises made between lovers here are sure to be fulfilled. If you believe in that sort of thing. I would have expected you to be familiar with the story already, considering how popular you are. I was certain that someone had asked you here.

speaker: Byleth
text: I am not that popular.

speaker: Hubert
text: On the contrary, I suspect those who wished to ask were simply too daunted to try.

speaker: Byleth
text: That is not the case.

speaker: Hubert
text: No need to sound so dejected. I suspect those who wished to ask were simply too daunted to try.

speaker: Hubert
text: But thanks to their cowardice, I am gifted with this opportunity to speak with you. It’s clear you have never felt at ease around me, as a result of how little trust there is between us. I should get back to the ball, regardless. I imagine there would be quite a scene if you turned out to be lying.

speaker: Byleth
text: You don’t believe me?

speaker: Hubert
text: Trust is not in my nature. Good night.

speaker: Ferdinand
text: Hello, Professor. I just needed a quick break from the festivities. Fancy running into you here.

speaker: Byleth
text: You followed me, didn't you?

speaker: Ferdinand
text: I beg your pardon?! Absolutely not! It is simply a coincidence. The heir to the great house of Aegir, chasing after a woman in the dead of night! The very thought of it!

speaker: Byleth
text: What a nice coincidence.

speaker: Ferdinand
text: Yes, a coincidence...

speaker: Ferdinand
text: Anyway, seeing you here, I cannot help but recall the legend of the Goddess Tower. It is said that when a man and a woman meet here by chance on the night of the ball, their paths become one. The goddess blesses them and ensures a harmonious union.

speaker: Byleth
text: I heard it differently.

speaker: Ferdinand
text: Oh, you heard the legend too? How was it different? That the goddess is sure to grant any promises made here? Ah, perhaps that is how it goes, come to think of it.

speaker: Byleth
text: Are you sure that's the legend?

speaker: Ferdinand
text: Indeed, that is how it goes. Or at least, that is the version I heard.

speaker: Ferdinand
text: How long have we known each other now? About nine months, by my count. The passage of time is swift indeed. Listen. I need to tell you something. After I graduate, I must pass stern judgement on my father. His greed got the better of him. He has strayed far from the righteous path. As the next Duke Aegir, I will succeed him as prime minister, and it will fall to me to hold him accountable. Only then can I justly guide the Empire's subjects and work to create a better world. That is my dream, my will, and my future. I pray that I will have the courage to fulfill my solemn duty and that I will have your support.

speaker: Byleth
text: Of course. I'm with you.

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm always happy to listen.

speaker: Ferdinand
text: Thank you. Knowing that you are on my side, I feel unstoppable. Well, shall we head back? Plenty of people must be wonder where you went. Specifically the legions of men who would like to dance with you! To be honest, I count myself among them.

speaker: Linhardt
text: Professor, you're late.

speaker: Byleth
text: What do you mean?

speaker: Linhardt
text: To tell the truth, it was an act of sheer hope that I might find you here.

speaker: Byleth
text: We didn't have plans to meet.

speaker: Linhardt
text: True, but a young man can hope to accidentally bump into someone.

speaker: Byleth
text: Oh, sorry!

speaker: Linhardt
text: My apologies, Professor. It was a bit of a joke. I’ve been waiting here because I thought you might come by.

speaker: Linhardt
text: I'm glad to find I was right. I hoped to find you so I might ask... Well, I would very much like to research your Crest.

speaker: Byleth
text: Not right now.

speaker: Linhardt
text: Does that mean you might be interested eventually? Let's decide the place and time right now, then. What? Is that not acceptable?

speaker: Byleth
text: Why would I let you do that?

speaker: Linhardt
text: Because it would be terribly interesting?

speaker: Linhardt
text: Anyway... Have you heard the legend of this place, Professor? It's a sentimental one to be sure. The story goes that if two people share a vow at the Goddess Tower, they'll be bound together forever. Hm, or was it that they'll be cursed forever? One or the other for certain. All the same, I think it's a rather lovely legend.

speaker: Byleth
text: It doesn't sound that lovely to me.

speaker: Byleth
text: Tell me more.

speaker: Linhardt
text: Well, I suppose it does depend on your enjoyment of potentially mistranslated myths. Professor, be warned. This may seem forward of me… However, let's vow that one day I will be allowed to research your Crest as much as I please.

speaker: Byleth
text: I think not.

speaker: Byleth
text: Excuse me?

speaker: Linhardt
text: I've overstepped my bounds again, haven't I? It's just that today is such a special day and, well, I suppose I got caught up in all the excitement. How about this instead? Let's agree to meet here again one day, just the two of us.

speaker: Byleth
text: If the opportunity arises.

speaker: Linhardt
text: Such an opportunity won't just arise, we have to make it happen for ourselves. I look forward to that day.

speaker: Byleth
text: I agree.

speaker: Linhardt
text: I look forward to that day. I really do…

speaker: Caspar
text: Hey, Professor! I was looking all over for you. What are you doing up here? I think this place is supposed to be off-limits...

speaker: Byleth
text: I didn't know.

speaker: Caspar
text: Well, that's the official rule. I don't think anyone follows it though.

speaker: Byleth
text: If it's only supposed to be...

speaker: Caspar
text: Heh! Good point. No one follows that rule anyway, and I heard no one from the monastery really cares.

speaker: Byleth
text: Where did you hear that?

speaker: Caspar
text: Huh. I can't remember her name. It was just some girl who started talking to me last night. She was trying to get me to leave the ball tonight and go to the Goddess Tower with her. She wouldn't say what she wanted to do here though. Said it was a secret or something. I told her I'd be too busy dancing and stuffing my face with food, so she left. Don't know why, but she didn't seem too happy about it. I guess I was curious though, so I came to check it out. That's when I saw you walking this way, so I followed you in.

speaker: Byleth
text: That's just awful.

speaker: Caspar
text: Isn't it? She wouldn't explain herself and she got angry!

speaker: Byleth
text: I was referring to you.

speaker: Byleth
text: I can't help but feel sympathetic.

speaker: Caspar
text: I appreciate that, but I'm not really looking for sympathy. I just wish she would've explained herself before getting all angry.

speaker: Byleth
text: My sympathy was not for you.

speaker: Caspar
text: Huh? Why? Well, it's all over now. Can't change what's in the past.

speaker: Byleth
text: I like your positive attitude.

speaker: Caspar
text: Thanks! I had a feeling you'd get it.

speaker: Byleth
text: Maybe you should worry about the past a little.

speaker: Caspar
text: Ugh. Really? I just don't like to dwell... But if you say so, I could keep it in mind.

speaker: Caspar
text: Anyway, I'm going to head back to the ball. You coming? Doesn't look like there's anything too exciting going on here.

speaker: Byleth
text: Let's head back.

speaker: Caspar
text: Maybe coming to the tower wasn't a total waste of time. I got to talk to you at least, right?

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm going to stay.

speaker: Caspar
text: All right. Don't stay too long though. You might catch cold.

speaker: Caspar
text: Welp, I'm starting to get hungry again. Time to fill up on some more food!

speaker: Bernadetta
text: Ah! Wh-what's that?! Ghost?! Is it a ghost?! Don't eat me!

speaker: Byleth
text: Calm down, it's OK.

speaker: Bernadetta
text: It'll eat the skin right off my bones and no one will ever— Huh? Oh, it's you, Professor. What a relief.

speaker: Byleth
text: It's just your professor.

speaker: Bernadetta
text: I knew it! I said, Bernie, this place is haunted, you'll just get eaten by the ghost of some dusty old professor or— Oh. Oh, it's you.

speaker: Byleth
text: You can relax now.

speaker: Bernadetta
text: Right. I'm better now. Thanks. But try not to scare me like that again, please... With the ball happening tonight, I was sure there wouldn't be anyone here. And from far off, you look... Well, you kinda have a spooky silhouette. I guess you haven't heard the legend?

speaker: Byleth
text: Legend?

speaker: Bernadetta
text: Oh, so if a couple swears a vow on the night of the ball, the goddess grants their wish? That's amazing! Is it true? I guess that's the sort of thing you miss when you spend all your time avoiding people. But wouldn't it be nice to spend some time alone with a nice guy in this lonely tower, cut off from all the rest of the world? Anyway… Oh, Professor! Since you're here and all, could I ask you for a favor? As you probably know by now, it's my lifelong dream to live in solitude forever… So could you help me to swear that vow?

speaker: Byleth
text: Nice try.

speaker: Bernadetta
text: Saw right through me, huh?

speaker: Byleth
text: I can't promise that.

speaker: Bernadetta
text: Guess you're right. It probably wouldn't work out so well for me, would it?

speaker: Bernadetta
text: Ah, well. No use complaining. Actually, I'm happy I got to see you here tonight. Even if it was just by coincidence. Would you mind staying a little longer? It's nice and quiet, and the sky's really pretty. I quite like the atmosphere. On a night like this, being out in the open doesn't seem so bad…

speaker: Dorothea
text: Ah, Professor! You showed up!

speaker: Byleth
text: Why are you here?

speaker: Dorothea
text: Um, I'm the one who called you here, remember?

speaker: Byleth
text: Why do you look so happy?

speaker: Dorothea
text: Well, because you're here, of course!

speaker: Dorothea
text: You came here because you read the letter I sent you, right?

speaker: Byleth
text: Not that I recall…

speaker: Byleth
text: What letter?

speaker: Dorothea
text: Are you saying this is...a coincidence? How disappointing to think you didn't come here specifically to see me. Still, if we're meeting by complete chance... that has a certain appeal too. It's as if destiny brought us together! And tonight is the night of the ball... Lucky me.

speaker: Byleth
text: What are you plotting?

speaker: Dorothea
text: Plotting? That's a bit rude, don't you think?

speaker: Byleth
text: I thought you weren't comfortable around me...

speaker: Dorothea
text: Oh, that's just when you're looking through me in front of others. When it's just us...I kind of like it.

speaker: Dorothea
text: Originally, I wanted to see what you'd do when you read my letter. I just wanted to see if you'd come here like I asked. I had a feeling that you would. Though, I suppose you didn't even read the letter to begin with… I should just be thankful I wasn't left here waiting. All alone. Forever. Do you know it's been almost nine whole moons since you arrived at Garreg Mach? You must have found a special someone by now, haven't you, Professor?

speaker: Byleth
text: I have.

speaker: Dorothea
text: Ooh? Who could it be? You've made me so curious. Oh, don't worry. I'm not going to pry if you don't want to share. Your private life is private, after all.

speaker: Byleth
text: I have not.

speaker: Dorothea
text: Uh-huh, right. I bet you're just hiding it. There's someone you're sweet on… Don't you worry, I won't pry if you don't want to share. These things are private, after all.

speaker: Byleth
text: Is that what you wanted to talk about?

speaker: Dorothea
text: Are you changing the subject? Don't do that. Ohh, I bet that means you do have someone, don't you? Don't you worry, I won't pry if you don't want to share. These things are private, after all.

speaker: Dorothea
text: Well, I oughta get going… I wouldn't want to be in the way if your special someone shows up. Either way, I do hope you'll share a dance with me later.

speaker: Petra
text: Professor, what is bringing you here? Is the ball not enjoyable?

speaker: Byleth
text: I had to escape.

speaker: Petra
text: Escape? I thought the ball was for dancing, not fighting... Oh! Escape! Meaning...to leave. I have understanding.

speaker: Byleth
text: I wanted to see you.

speaker: Petra
text: But you are seeing me every day. Why would you be wanting to see me now? Maybe you and I share a reason for being here...

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm lost.

speaker: Petra
text: Lost? But this monastery is where our home is... I am not understanding.

speaker: Petra
text: I have been hearing about a legend. About the Goddess Tower. People have a belief that the goddess watches this place on this night. If you share a promise, the goddess will make that promise become true. That makes men and women who are close come to this place. On this night. I am wanting to see that, and so I came to observe. With secrecy. But no one is here. I have much disappointment.

speaker: Byleth
text: I wanted to see that too.

speaker: Petra
text: Someone might arrive still. We could go find a hiding spot for both of us. We may have to be squished with each other, but I will not be worried if you are not.

speaker: Byleth
text: You shouldn't spy on people.

speaker: Petra
text: Yes, that has truth. I will be thinking about that from now on.

speaker: Petra
text: Oh! I have a realization! If someone sees us here with each other, they will think that we are with each other! That is not accepting...acceptable for people to misunderstand!

speaker: Byleth
text: That could be a problem.

speaker: Petra
text: We should be returning to the ball, separately.

speaker: Byleth
text: I wouldn't mind.

speaker: Petra
text: Is that OK, Professor? I think we are agreeing on that. Maybe we should be returning to the ball... with each other.

speaker: Dimitri
text: It's quiet here, isn't it, Professor? That reminds me. Do you know the legend associated with the Goddess Tower?

speaker: Byleth
text: I've heard it.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Is that right? You don't strike me as the sort to enjoy stories like that.

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm not concerned with such things.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Just as expected.

speaker: Dimitri
text: They say that wishes made in this tower will come true. I wonder who came up with such a silly notion.

speaker: Byleth
text: You don't believe it?

speaker: Dimitri
text: Legends are legends, nothing more. I doubt there are many who really believe that wishes can be granted. The goddess just watches over us from above... That is all. No matter how hard someone begs to be saved, she would never so much as offer her hand. And even if she did, we lack the means to reach out and grasp it. That's how I feel about her. In any case... I suppose there's no harm in passing the time with silly legends. What do you say, Professor? Care to make a wish? We are here on the night of the ball. Why don't you try wishing for something?

speaker: Byleth
text: After you.

speaker: Byleth
text: I can't think of anything, so go ahead.

speaker: Dimitri
text: A wish of my own... I suppose my wish...is for a world in which no one would ever be unjustly taken from us. Or...something along those lines.

speaker: Byleth
text: That's a great wish.

speaker: Byleth
text: I'll wish for the same.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Thank you, Professor. Although, at a time like this... Perhaps it would make more sense for me to wish that we'll be together forever. What do you think?

speaker: Dimitri
text: … Haha! Well now, Professor! You must admit I've improved in the art of joke telling.

speaker: Byleth
text: That's cruel.

speaker: Byleth
text: It didn't sound like a joke.

speaker: Dimitri
text: I'm sorry... I guess that was rather thoughtless of me. … Honestly... I do regret saying such a thing. Please think nothing of it. I've blurted out irresponsible things like that to my classmates. Promises that we'll see each other again and the like. I have no business making such promises for the future. There are certain things that I must accomplish, even if it means risking my life. I may not even have a future to promise to someone.

speaker: Dimitri
text: We should head back soon. It's rude of me to keep you all to myself. Shall we, Professor?

speaker: Dedue
text: What are you doing here?

speaker: Byleth
text: I could ask you the same.

speaker: Byleth
text: I needed some quiet.

speaker: Dedue
text: I felt similarly.

speaker: Dedue
text: Though I elected to attend this ball, I did not know what to do with myself once there. I do not wish to be a nuisance to His Highness or to my classmates. Thus, I have sought solitude. I noticed a number of people looking for you, however. Should you not return to the festivities?

speaker: Byleth
text: I’d like to stay here a bit longer.

speaker: Byleth
text: Not just yet.

speaker: Dedue
text: As you wish.

speaker: Dedue
text: The stars seem brighter here, somehow. I have heard the goddess of Fódlan grants a special blessing at this tower. The blessing ensures that any oath sworn between man and woman here shall be fulfilled. That is what I have heard. We had similar legends in Duscur. Some elements of human culture are universal, I suppose. Is there an oath you would like to swear?

speaker: Byleth
text: Not that I can think of.

speaker: Dedue
text: I understand.

speaker: Byleth
text: I swear to work toward peace for Fódlan.

speaker: Dedue
text: I am not sure that a full and lasting peace is possible.

speaker: Dedue
text: But while I have this opportunity, permit me to swear an oath to you. I swear that we will look upon these same stars again, when His Highness has led us to a more tranquil age.

speaker: Byleth
text: That is a worthy oath.

speaker: Byleth
text: I look forward to it.

speaker: Dedue
text: Good. There is a chill in the air, is there not? I am accustomed to cold weather. But you should go back indoors.

speaker: Byleth
text: Let’s go back together.

speaker: Dedue
text: If you wish. I suppose the damage to your reputation for being seen with me has already been done.

speaker: Byleth
text: Will you share a dance with me?

speaker: Dedue
text: I do not know how to dance. If you wish to teach me, then I will endeavor to learn.

speaker: Dedue
text: Let us return. If the cold is too much, I will lend you my coat.

speaker: Felix
text: Oh, look who it is.

speaker: Byleth
text: What are you doing here?

speaker: Felix
text: I just wanted some quiet. It's so loud, I needed a little respite.

speaker: Byleth
text: Are you waiting for someone?

speaker: Felix
text: No. I just wanted a bit of quiet.

speaker: Felix
text: Besides, what are you doing here?

speaker: Byleth
text: I thought I might find you here.

speaker: Felix
text: Huh? You must be joking.

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm here for the same reason as you.

speaker: Felix
text: Ah. Well, I guess it figures.

speaker: Felix
text: Hm. Have you heard the legend of the Goddess Tower? That if you make a pledge, it will be fulfilled? Childish, I know. But if it were true... Let's make a pledge to the goddess. I pledge that someday, I will surpass you. I'll surpass your technique, your skill with the sword, and your cunning as a warrior. Then I will make you taste defeat!

speaker: Byleth
text: That seems extreme.

speaker: Byleth
text: That's your pledge to the goddess?

speaker: Felix
text: What a disappointment. If you're looking for a passionate affair, you've got the wrong man. Go find someone else. I've spent my life avoiding love and romance. They're distractions. Blades, blood, and battle. That's what I'm made of and nothing else. If someone saw us, however, this may look like an amorous meeting. You'll have to settle for being mistaken as my lover.

speaker: Byleth
text: That's mean.

speaker: Byleth
text: What nonsense.

speaker: Felix
text: It's time I went back to training. I'll always be more comfortable holding a sword than a woman's hand. Try not to catch a cold up here. I'd hate for such a good sparring partner to be out of commission. Good-bye.

speaker: Ashe
text: Professor! Did you come up here for a rest too?

speaker: Byleth
text: That’s right.

speaker: Ashe
text: I guess we think along the same lines. I was feeling kind of worn out.

speaker: Byleth
text: Actually, I was looking for you.

speaker: Ashe
text: For me? Oh! I’m so sorry to put you out of your way! I was just kind of worn out from all of the excitement. I am enjoying the ball, but it’s a bit much, you know?

speaker: Ashe
text: Everyone else seems used to this kind of thing, but I’ve never been to anything like it before. My friends did teach me a bit about proper manners and how to dance, but I still feel out of place. Stepping on girls’ feet, messing up the pretty floral decorations… Haha, I’ve been a bit of a disaster. Sometimes I wonder if it’s even right for someone like me to be in a place like this.

speaker: Byleth
text: I feel that way sometimes too.

speaker: Ashe
text: Really? You do? That’s kind of reassuring!

speaker: Byleth
text: You have every right to be here.

speaker: Ashe
text: You're right, of course. I'm a student at the Officers Academy, just like everyone else. Lonato was kind enough to send me here. I need to live up to his expectations.

speaker: Ashe
text: By the way, have you heard the stories about the Goddess Tower? They say that if a man and a woman make a wish together here, the goddess will make it come true.

speaker: Byleth
text: What would you wish for?

speaker: Ashe
text: Oh, never mind me. I'd like to know what you'd wish for!

speaker: Byleth
text: Let’s make a wish together, then.

speaker: Ashe
text: My thoughts exactly! Do you have anything in particular you’d like to wish for?

speaker: Byleth
text: My wish is…

speaker: Ashe
text: Your wish is?

speaker: Byleth
text: For your wish to come true, Ashe.

speaker: Ashe
text: What? My wish? W-well, um...let me think.

speaker: Byleth
text: I can’t think of anything.

speaker: Ashe
text: Well, if you can't come up with anything, maybe I should think of a wish instead?

speaker: Ashe
text: All right, I’ve got it. I wish for my brother and sister back home to be able to live out their lives in peace.

speaker: Byleth
text: That’s just like you.

speaker: Byleth
text: That’s a lovely wish.

speaker: Ashe
text: This kind of thing is pretty embarrassing, huh? Maybe I should be heading back. I’ll never get better at fancy social events like this if I keep running away from them, right? I guess I should ask another girl to dance. Oh, but I’d better make sure I go over the steps again first.

speaker: Byleth
text: You could dance with me.

speaker: Ashe
text: Really? You’d do that? Wow, that’d be great! Just promise not to laugh if I mess it up, OK? Come on. Let’s head back.

speaker: Sylvain
text: Evening, Professor. Lovely night, isn’t it? Just look at those stars… I heard you were headed over to the Goddess Tower, and I got curious about who you might be meeting. But here you are all by yourself. This isn’t a lover’s tryst at all! Heh heh…

speaker: Byleth
text: Tryst?

speaker: Sylvain
text: Oh, yeah. The Goddess Tower is where lovers meet. Didn’t anybody tell you? They say that if you exchange vows here, they always come true. It’s a sacred place for lovers.

speaker: Byleth
text: Why are you here alone?

speaker: Byleth
text: Where is your lover?

speaker: Sylvain
text: Well, the person I’m interested in...is already here. You’re here alone. I’m here alone. I was thinking maybe…

speaker: Byleth
text: Wait. Me?

speaker: Sylvain
text: Well, of course! We’re the only two people here, aren’t we? I keep thinking about it, and it just makes sense. My Crest and yours…

speaker: Byleth
text: That’s too much, too soon.

speaker: Byleth
text: Marry you? I can’t even trust you.

speaker: Sylvain
text: Heh, OK. True, true. You know, I’ve never regretted any of my past behavior...until you turned me down just now. I can’t be who I’ve been my whole life. I gotta get it together and become a man you can trust. I know that sounds like another one of my games, but it’s true. I’ll prove it to you. Anyway, I’m going to head back to the ball. Since we’re both here, would you accompany me?

speaker: Byleth
text: I’ll go back with you.

speaker: Sylvain
text: Well then, my lady, I do hope you’ll give me the honor of a dance. It will be good practice for our first dance at our wedding reception. Heh heh—I’m kidding!

speaker: Byleth
text: I’m going to stay here for awhile.

speaker: Sylvain
text: It's chilly out tonight, so take care not to catch cold. And if you do get cold, you know where to find me. Sorry. Old habits die hard, I guess... OK. Well, I'm headed inside.

speaker: Sylvain
text: Anyway… Let’s get going before you change your mind.

speaker: Mercedes
text: Why, Professor! I was wondering where you ran off to. I searched the entire floor but couldn't find you anywhere. Tired, are we? I can tell by that look on your face. It must be exhausting being so popular, huh?

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm exhausted...

speaker: Mercedes
text: I can imagine. Shall we take a break here, then? Say, Professor. Have you heard the legend of the Goddess Tower? They say that if two people exchange a vow here, the goddess herself will fulfill it.

speaker: Byleth
text: I've never heard that before.

speaker: Mercedes
text: Well, that simply won't do. You'll fall behind if you can't keep up with your students!

speaker: Byleth
text: I think I recall such a story.

speaker: Mercedes
text: Ah, so even you have heard that one. The stories must travel far.

speaker: Mercedes
text: Many young couples come here in private, all thanks to that legend. They make promises to stay together forever. Things like that. I actually saw a man invite a lady to join him at the tower while on my way here. It's rather romantic, don't you think?

speaker: Byleth
text: I think so.

speaker: Mercedes
text: Indeed.

speaker: Byleth
text: I disagree.

speaker: Mercedes
text: Really? You're a strange one, Professor.

speaker: Mercedes
text: Though, just because two people share a promise, that doesn't guarantee they'll be together forever. You've noticed many nobles at the academy, right? They very rarely have the freedom to choose their own partners. Yet still they wish to stay together. Maybe that's why they pray to the goddess. Are you waiting on anyone, Professor?

speaker: Byleth
text: No, there's no one.

speaker: Mercedes
text: What a relief. I was afraid that I was keeping you.

speaker: Byleth
text: I was waiting for you.

speaker: Mercedes
text: Oh my. Even though we didn't make plans to meet? You're a charmer, aren't you?

speaker: Mercedes
text: Ah! I almost forgot why I came looking for you! I was wondering if you'd like to dance with me. It's just so loud in the reception hall though. I think I'd rather stay here with you... If that's all right with you, Professor. Thank you. I appreciate it.

speaker: Annette
text: Professor! I'm happy to see you here. Everybody's been asking about you. You're really popular with the students.

speaker: Byleth
text: I had to escape.

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm worn out.

speaker: Annette
text: Oh, really? Huh. Uh, actually, I've been trying to find you too. But if you're not interested in dancing, that's OK. We are supposed to be at a ball thought... If you're not going to dance tonight, when and where will you get another chance?

speaker: Byleth
text: Here.

speaker: Byleth
text: Now.

speaker: Annette
text: Wait...really? There isn't any music... But this is too special to pass up! Maybe...I could sing a little something. I may not look like it, but I'm a practiced singer. Though...people do tend to think my lyrics are a little odd. ♪ Fry the food, it tastes so good... It fills up our hungry tummies... ♪

speaker: Byleth
text: Now I'm hungry.

speaker: Byleth
text: What an interesting song.

speaker: Annette
text: It's about this yummy stew one of the monks taught me to make a while back. Oh, I know! I'll make it for you! It really is just about the tastiest thing in the world. Um... If I'm bothering you, please tell me now and I'll leave you alone.

speaker: Annette
text: Say, Professor... Did you know that if you make a wish here at the Goddess Tower, it will for sure come true? That's why people usually meet up with someone they like here. For a rendezvous! And they make a wish that they'll stay together forever. So... Uh, I thought you might be waiting for a girl here. And that I'm messing it up.

speaker: Byleth
text: I've never heard about that tradition.

speaker: Byleth
text: Nothing of the sort.

speaker: Annette
text: Hehe, that's just what I'd expect you to say! But since we're already here, let's go ahead and made a wish together.

speaker: Byleth
text: What kind of wish?

speaker: Byleth
text: Sure.

speaker: Annette
text: I've already decided what it will be. Dearest Goddess... I wish for the professor and I to always be the best of friends! How's that sound? Can we wish for that?

speaker: Byleth
text: I'd be happy to.

speaker: Annette
text: Really? That makes me so happy!

speaker: Byleth
text: It's a little embarrassing...

speaker: Annette
text: Oh no! Actually, when I said it aloud, I could tell it was an embarrassing wish... Oops!

speaker: Annette
text: Well, I'd better be going now, and you should think about returning to the ball too. But make sure you save me a dance!

speaker: Ingrid
text: Whew, I can't manage one more bite. So full... So full!

speaker: Ingrid
text: Oh! Professor! What do you think you're doing here?! I came here to stuff my fa—I mean to have some ME time.

speaker: Byleth
text: I sort of followed you...

speaker: Ingrid
text: You mean you saw that just now? All the food? Everything?! Ugh, so embarrassing... Maybe there's a nearby rock I can crawl under.

speaker: Byleth
text: No reason, really.

speaker: Ingrid
text: Oh, so we're just running into one another by chance, then. Phew. If you had followed me here, I'd be a little...bothered. And probably embarrassed.

speaker: Byleth
text: Were you waiting for someone?

speaker: Ingrid
text: Who, me? No, no, of course not. I was just about to walk off all that food I just ate. Really, I came here to have some privacy. But you're here now, so I suppose that makes it a bit less private.

speaker: Byleth
text: Are you worried people may get the wrong idea?

speaker: Ingrid
text: I suppose there's that possibility, now that you mention it.

speaker: Byleth
text: Just the two of us...

speaker: Ingrid
text: Uh...well, yes. I suppose it's just us here...

speaker: Ingrid
