text: There is no time to waste. Your Majesty, Professor, we must escape while we can.

speaker: Seteth
text: Edelgard and Hubert have disappeared. They will surely return to the Empire. The knights have been dispatched to search and investigate. If there is any movement, we will know. We cannot ignore the possibility that there will soon be open hostilities between us and the Imperial army. When that happens, are you prepared to fight your own? If you wish to return to the Empire, I will not stop you. That is your choice to make.

speaker: Ferdinand
text: If Edelgard is acting afoul, then we have no choice but to strike her down.

speaker: Caspar
text: It's up to us to stop them! We have a war on our hands!

speaker: Linhardt
text: I have no interest in fighting, not even for her. And yet--

speaker: Bernadetta
text: How are we supposed to decide just like that?

speaker: Dorothea
text: Edie, Hubie, I'm sorry about this, but... I'm siding with the professor.

speaker: Petra
text: Her doings are wrong. It is our duty to make everything right.

speaker: Seteth
text: I am sure you all have much on your mind. I encourage you to confer with your professor and make a decision. You have until the fighting commences.  Professor, I am depending on your strength for the safety of Fódlan.

speaker: Edelgard
text: The leaders of the church have misused its creed to fulfill their true desire - to rule the world. They have fooled the people of Fódlan. Long ago, they divided the Empire to create a Kingdom, and then, divided that Kingdom to create an Alliance. They did all of this to make the masses bicker amongst themselves. They caused instability in order to reinforce their own authority. They gathered gold and lived in extravagance. How? By preying on the devotion of those who wished for the goddess's salvation! Those corrupt hypocrites cannot lead Fódlan to true peace! Their foul belief system must be torn asunder so that true wisdom may finally prevail! And so, I have decided-- by order of the Adrestian Emperor, Edelgard von Hresvelg-- the Empire hereby declares war on the Church of Seiros!

speaker: Seteth
text: I cannot believe it... Let us recount the situation as it stands, Professor. After you returned from the Holy Tomb... the Adrestian Empire declared war upon the Church of Seiros, as well as our allies.

speaker: Byleth
text: Declared war?

speaker: Seteth
text: Edelgard demanded her own father relinquish the throne, and then assumed the position of emperor. She has deemed the Church of Seiros to be an evil of this world, and is calling upon the people of Fódlan to help her tear it down. I must discuss our response to this declaration with the archbishop after the knights return from their investigation. Until then, watch over the students. See that they remain calm.

speaker: Felix
text: So... He's finally shown his true face. The same Dimitri I've seen once before–a beast who loves spilling blood.

speaker: Ingrid
text: You're wrong! I'm sure of it. There has to be an explanation...

speaker: Sylvain
text: I knew he'd been carrying the burden of that tragedy. I understand his thirst for revenge. His family and closest friends...all massacred right in front of him. But...it still doesn't add up. There must be more that we don't know.

speaker: Mercedes
text: That's true. Dimitri didn't come unhinged until after the Flame Emperor was unmasked...

speaker: Ashe
text: You don't think...there's some connection between those two...do you?

speaker: Dedue
text: Professor. The Empire has declared war on the Church of Seiros.

speaker: Sylvain
text: We knew this day would come, sooner or later.

speaker: Annette
text: What's going to happen?!

speaker: Byleth
text: Don't worry.

speaker: Byleth
text: We need more information.

speaker: Ingrid
text: We can't afford to be optimistic. It's entirely possible the Kingdom will be invaded.

speaker: Sylvain
text: Settle yourself, Ingrid. We need to carefully consider our options.

speaker: Ashe
text: We can't just act rashly. That will only make things worse.

speaker: Dedue
text: One we've ascertained the situation, we must return to Fhirdiad.  Your Highness...

speaker: Claude
text: I heard what happened, Teach. The princess-- well, the emperor now-- she really did it, didn't she? The lords and dukes of both the Kingdom and the Alliance have been called out, and now have to choose between the Church and the Empire. The seed of conflict was always there, and now we find ourselves in the middle of a war that will tear Fódlan in two.

speaker: Lysithea
text: The Empire is rash, but I never thought it would come to this.

speaker: Leonie
text: How could something like this happen? I hope everyone back home is safe.

speaker: Hilda
text: I'm sure it's mass confusion at home right now. My brother must be worried sick about me.

speaker: Byleth
text: Only time will tell.

speaker: Byleth
text: Let's calm down.

speaker: Claude
text: You're absolutely right, Teach. I'm sure a lot of us are worried about our homes, but... all we can do now is prepare for battle... and tread carefully.

speaker: Shamir
text: That's what we're dealing with. Is there no chance it's an infectious disease?

speaker: Manuela
text: There are no absolutes in medicine, but the chances are extremely slim. Restless movements, fits of violence, becoming bedridden or even impossible to wake... With symptoms that varied, there are only a few possibilities. It's either a mixture of poisons or magic. And dark magic, at that.

speaker: Jeralt
text: You're talking about Remire Village, aren't you, Manuela?

speaker: Manuela
text: Oh my, if it isn't Jeralt. Tell me, what was the first thing you heard?

speaker: Jeralt
text: Everything after you mentioned that it's not likely it's an infectious disease. My child and I owe the people of Remire Village. If something's happening there, we must help them.

speaker: Shamir
text: We scouted the area ourselves. Speak with the knights. Hear what they have to say. I must go. Thank you for your help, Manuela.

speaker: Manuela
text: You know, I'm more than willing to go with you to Remire Village... After all, I owe you my life. If you'd like, I bet we could even manage the mission all by ourselves. Just the two of us...

speaker: Byleth
text: That's nice of you.

speaker: Manuela
text: Professor! A bit of a tease, are we? A girl could get used to this side of you.

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm afraid not.

speaker: Manuela
text: You're saying no? Well, aren't you just a great, big bore.

speaker: Jeralt
text: Nice try, but I'll be going to the village as well. Enough nonsense. It's time to move out.

speaker: Manuela
text: As you like. Good-bye, Jeralt. Good-bye, Professor.

speaker: Jeralt
text: I'll be in my office making preparations. What about you? If you have the time, it would be helpful if you could go ahead and talk to the knights.

speaker: Jeralt
text: Hey! What's wrong?

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm OK.

speaker: Byleth
text: I just got a little dizzy.

speaker: Jeralt
text: If anything feels off, return to the infirmary. No need to just grin and bear it. Got it?

speaker: Sothis
text: Ugh... What could have caused such dizziness? I felt it too. Actually... I've felt that way before...

speaker: Hubert
text: You look unwell. It's because of what happened, isn't it?

speaker: Edelgard
text: Don't speak of it aloud.

speaker: Hubert
text: You can't change the past. For now, all we can do is use it to our advantage.

speaker: Edelgard
text: I know that. I also know that I must steel myself to ascend the Imperial throne.

speaker: Hubert
text: Those preparations are going well. We... Someone is coming.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Professor, I heard about our mission for this month. Something terrible is happening in Remire Village. That's where you were when fate sent you our way. This feels...preordained.

speaker: Hubert
text: Are the knights making progress with their investigation?

speaker: Byleth
text: I don't know.

speaker: Byleth
text: They are.

speaker: Hubert
text: If what is happening there is by design, there must be someone pulling the strings. There is the Death Knight, of course. And the mysterious mages who were implicated with the Western Church. They showed up when Flayn was kidnapped as well. And now there is another strange occurrence near the monastery... It seems an unknown organization hopes to make the monastery its stage for something.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Do you believe that all of these incidents are connected, Professor?

speaker: Byleth
text: I do.

speaker: Edelgard
text: That is the logical conclusion, but I'm not so sure.

speaker: Byleth
text: I do not.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Oh? I'm surprised to hear you say that, but actually, I agree.

speaker: Edelgard
text: It certainly appears that all of the events surrounding the monastery are connected by a single thread. However... I think it's possible that it may just be a result of different motives overlapping. Remember, Professor... If you think of people as simply enemies or allies, it may be impossible to grasp the truth.

speaker: Dimitri
text: I see. So you'll be staying here for some time, then. Honestly, I'm surprised. I've heard it's been a few years since you last donated to the church.

speaker: Lord Arundel
text: That was merely because of the financial situation of my territory. I assure you, it has nothing to do with my dedication to the church. By the way, Dimitri... Isn't Edelgard currently enrolled at the Officers Academy as well?

speaker: Dimitri
text: Yes. She's in the Black Eagle House. I don't believe she has any plans to leave anytime soon. Why not pay her a visit?

speaker: Lord Arundel
text: I may do just that. It's nice to stay in touch with my dear niece every now and then. Of course I'm also delighted that I was able to speak with my nephew, as well. Whether through marriage or otherwise, family is family, after all.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Of course. The feeling is mutual.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Professor... If you were watching, you should have made your presence known.

speaker: Byleth
text: Who was that?

speaker: Dimitri
text: That was Lord Arundel, the Regent for the Empire. He is also Edelgard's uncle.

speaker: Byleth
text: An acquaintance of yours?

speaker: Byleth
text: He called you his nephew...

speaker: Dimitri
text: My stepmother was his younger sister. We are not related by blood, but he is technically my uncle.

speaker: Byleth
text: In other words...

speaker: Byleth
text: So, you and Edelgard...

speaker: Dimitri
text: Yes. My stepmother was Edelgard's birth mother. Edelgard and I are siblings by marriage. We can delve into that topic another time. For now, let's make preparations to investigate what's happening in that village.

speaker: Sothis
text: Oh dear. The princess of the Empire and the Kingdom's prince are kin! How very odd.

speaker: Byleth
text: So that's why he was worried about her...

speaker: Sothis
text: All beings are attached somehow to those who are their family. Yes...even I. I must have had a family too... I wish I could remember them. My family... I wonder who and where they are, and what they're doing now.

speaker: Byleth
text: I find it odd as well...

speaker: Sothis
text: They likely harbor knowledge they do not wish to share. Oh yes, I'm sure of it. But I suppose we must wait until the time of truth arrives...

speaker: Sothis
text: In any case... About this Arundel. You've heard that name before, correct?

speaker: Byleth
text: In the library.

speaker: Sothis
text: Quite true! We came across that name within the library, right where the prince had been.

speaker: Byleth
text: In the office.

speaker: Sothis
text: Your memory is worse than mine! The library! We came across that name within the library, right where the prince had been. Don't you recall?

speaker: Sothis
text: I thought that Arundel had died... And yet, not so. He seems alive and well. I wonder what the prince had hoped to learn from reading of his uncle's charity... So many things the prince has yet to tell... How bothersome...

speaker: Claude
text: Tomas doesn't seem to be here... Oh well, that's fine. I've been researching the Heroes' Relics a lot since we last spoke to him. I found out something interesting.

speaker: Byleth
text: Why have you been researching them?

speaker: Claude
text: Why? Do you have to ask? Trust me, what really matters is what I found out.

speaker: Byleth
text: Something interesting?

speaker: Claude
text: It's about the connection between Crests and the Heroes' Relics. The Crest Stone of each Relic is carved with a specific Crest-the one that has the ability to wield it properly. The Crests are the keys. You need the right one to safely use a Hero's Relic. The only thing I can't figure out is...why doesn't the Sword of the Creator have a Crest Stone bearing a Crest?

speaker: Byleth
text: It's by the whim of the goddess.

speaker: Claude
text: Hey, now! No need to write off my findings by saying it's a mere whim of the goddess.

speaker: Byleth
text: It had one in the past.

speaker: Claude
text: Precisely. At least, that's my current guess.

speaker: Claude
text: There's more. I believe the Crest Stones might be the source of the Relics' inhuman power. When Miklan transformed into a Black Beast, he was taken over by something that originated from the Crest Stone. And the Crest Stone was on his body. It all seems to add up. Now, look at this picture I found in the library.

speaker: Claude
text: That creature is called the Immaculate One, who was supposedly sent by the goddess to save the followers of Seiros. See the pattern on its brow, and the faint circular boundary? Isn't it possible that's a Crest Stone? If all this is true, then Crest Stones are what power the ability to assume massive forms like that of the Immaculate One. And maybe the Heroes' Relics can harness that transformative power...

speaker: Seteth
text: Oh. It is you. Have you seen Tomas recently?

speaker: Claude
text: No such luck. I was hoping to speak with him myself, but he seems to be out on the town.

speaker: Seteth
text: I see. Well... Hm?! Where did you find that picture?

speaker: Claude
text: It was in the library. Why do you ask? Is it something my youthful eyes shouldn't be seeing?

speaker: Seteth
text: No, of course not. However, that is not part of this library's collection. It must belong to Tomas. It would be problematic if it got mixed in with the other books. I will take possession of it for now.

speaker: Claude
text: Take it away where no one can see it, you mean...

speaker: Seteth
text: What was that?

speaker: Claude
text: That's what Tomas said. He said records that the monastery doesn't approve of tend to disappear.

speaker: Seteth
text: Tomas said that? Preposterous. I have far too much to accomplish to waste time with this foolishness.

speaker: Claude
text: He was certainly in a hurry. I wonder if he's off to confront Tomas. Well, he took the picture, so I guess that's that for now. I'll see you later, Teach.

speaker: Claude
text: So, the church is hiding something after all. Some massive secret about Relics and Crests. A secret that must have something to do with the professor's true identity...

speaker: Sothis
text: I do not know why it is so, but being here makes me feel quite...unwell. I am so sleepy...and a bit... It is a struggle merely to stay conscious... Are you feeling the same?

speaker: Byleth
text: I am.

speaker: Sothis
text: And yet, it feels familiar... As though pulled from a corner of my memory, from a time long ago... I simply cannot fathom it.

speaker: Byleth
text: I am not.

speaker: Sothis
text: Why must you be so difficult! I know the entire contents of your heart and soul, so you should know there is no fooling me!

speaker: Edelgard
text: They say that things rarely if ever go according to plan. Still, plan we must. After all, if we don't effectively force things to go our way, nothing will be achieved. How about you, Professor? Are you leading the life you envisioned for yourself?

speaker: Byleth
text: I am.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Your character must be stronger than most.

speaker: Byleth
text: I am not.

speaker: Edelgard
text: That's surprising... but I suppose it's possible you're telling the truth.

speaker: Edelgard
text: They say that things rarely if ever go according to plan. Still, plan we must. After all, if we don't effectively force things to go our way, nothing will be achieved. How about you, Professor? Are you leading the life you envisioned for yourself?

speaker: Dimitri
text: I'm sorry to ask this of you...but I would deeply appreciate it if you would promise to keep my association with Edelgard to yourself. It is a...complicated history, what she and I share.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Professor, you seem unwell. How are you faring? If you're not feeling well, I'd strongly recommend some rest.

speaker: Claude
text: Even if I spend all my time rummaging through this library, there's a limit to the knowledge that can be gained. Apparently, it only contains books whose contents have been deemed appropriate by the church. If only Tomas were around. I bet he has some interesting stories he could regale us with…

speaker: Claude
text: What in the world is happening in Remire Village? I hear even the knights have been dispatched. I hope it's nothing too serious… After all, that's where we first met. I have valued memories of that place.

speaker: Hubert
text: Need something, Professor? I was just asking Monica here to be less demanding of Lady Edelgard's time.

speaker: Monica
text: Hey, it's not like I'm bothering her! Sorry for the ruckus, Professor. Please don't worry about it too much. Nooothing to worry about here!

speaker: Hubert
text: Ugh. I wish you would worry about it a little more.

speaker: Ferdinand
text: Remire Village... Is that not where you met Edelgard? If you had not been there, something terrible could have happened. Did one of the house leaders know that mercenaries were staying in Remire Village? I wonder... It will remain a mystery for now. All we can do at this point is speculate.

speaker: Linhardt
text: I fear I may become a social recluse soon... My life consists of wearing a groove in the floor between the library and the dining hall. Although, I guess a real recluse wouldn't leave their room, eh? That would be me if you weren't my teacher, locked away in my room, reading napping, never to be seen. You know I never see Bernadetta outside of class. I wonder what it is that she does in her room all day.

speaker: Linhardt
text: I fear I may become a social recluse soon... My life consists of wearing a groove in the floor between the library and the dining hall. Although, I guess a real recluse wouldn't leave their room, eh?

speaker: Caspar
text: Hey, Professor. Did you see that my father came by during the Battle of the Eagle and Lion? He left soon after, but I saw him talking to Edelgard first. I wonder what they could have to talk about.

speaker: Byleth
text: Your father?

speaker: Caspar
text: Yeah, he's pretty important in the Empire. I thought I mentioned it to you before? He's the Minister of Military Affairs.

speaker: Byleth
text: Empire business, perhaps?

speaker: Caspar
text: I guess that would make sense. He is the Minister of Military Affairs, after all.

speaker: Caspar
text: Still though... I could've sworn those two didn't get along.

speaker: Bernadetta
text: What is it? Sorry, I've, um... I've got a cold.

speaker: Byleth
text: Get well soon.

speaker: Bernadetta
text: Um. Thanks.

speaker: Byleth
text: No, you don't.

speaker: Bernadetta
text: How did you know? My act was perfect. Alas, 'tis no mere illness of the body, but a malign affliction of mine soul! So, um, back to bed.

speaker: Dorothea
text: Congratulations on winning the Battle of the Eagle and Lion. Did you get a special reward? I certainly feel like I earned a special reward. Don't you, Professor?

speaker: Byleth
text: No. Winning is its own reward.

speaker: Dorothea
text: I was afraid you might say that. I do wish you'd dote on me just a bit more...

speaker: Dorothea
text: Aww... Disappointing.

speaker: Petra
text: This is a place of mysteriousness. I have awareness of how much difference every part of the world is. In a place alike to this place, you can imagine the goddess of Fódlan truly existing. At times, I miss those places in Brigid. At times... I am missing those places so painfully.

speaker: Dedue
text: All this month, His Highness has been going out late into the night. He will not speak of it to me. Professor, do you happen to know anything?

speaker: Byleth
text: As I recall...

speaker: Dedue
text: Lord Arundel is here? That may well explain it.

speaker: Byleth
text: I don't know.

speaker: Dedue
text: I see. I am sorry to trouble you with questions.

speaker: Dedue
text: His Highness's headaches have been growing steadily worse. I would prefer that he retire to bed early.

speaker: Dedue
text: Investigating Remire village? Be on your guard.

speaker: Ingrid
text: You know, Professor–the tournament fish, and the meal we indulged in after the Battle of the Eagle and Lion... Why, all of the food I've eaten in this monastery has been absolutely delectable. Every last bite of it.

speaker: Felix
text: Food really is the only thing you think about, huh?

speaker: Ingrid
text: Hardly! I think about all sorts of things.

speaker: Felix
text: Oh! Like tomorrow's menu, for instance?

speaker: Ashe
text: I'm worried about Remire. That affliction is a little too mysterious for my liking. I'm pretty sure it's not normal.

speaker: Byleth
text: I've heard it's not an ordinary disease.

speaker: Ashe
text: Then what could it be?

speaker: Byleth
text: I've heard it's the work of a cursed specter.

speaker: Ashe
text: Wh-what?! Ah! Come on, don't tease me. But what if it really was something like that? How could we hope to stop it?

speaker: Sylvain
text: I wonder how Remire Village is faring. Hopefully we're not dealing with some new epidemic. It wouldn't be unheard of. Almost 20 years ago, a terrible plague blazed through Faerghus. It even hit the capital city, taking the queen consort's life...or so I heard. The whole Kingdom was in an uproar over that loss. The person who saved the Kingdom wasn't a doctor but a holy woman–the fair Lady Cornelia. After that, she was awarded the honor of being a mage in the service of the royal family. She sounds like an amazing woman, but... She must be pretty old by now. But hey, maybe she's aged like a fine wine.

speaker: Mercedes
text: Oh, goodness. Is something the matter, Professor? You look a little pale... Please be careful. It's so easy to catch a cold this time of year.

speaker: Annette
text: Hmm... The librarian is always out and about these days. And just when I had some questions about a book I'd borrowed... Ugh, now I'm so curious about where he's gone off to! He'd better come back soon...

speaker: Lorenz
text: How are you feeling, Professor? You look rather ill, if you don't mind my saying so. Are you sick? If so, I would urge you not to push yourself too hard. Take some rest.

speaker: Byleth
text: Nothing gets by you.

speaker: Lorenz
text: Just my natural talent. Nothing out of the ordinary. Enough wit, now. You should lie down.

speaker: Byleth
text: What an unexpected kindness.

speaker: Lorenz
text: What is that supposed to mean? Never mind. If you're not feeling well, you should stop trying to walk it off and simply lie down.

speaker: Raphael
text: Hey, Professor. Can I get your advice on something? I just don't know what to do anymore. I used to think they were the best, but now I can't even stand looking at them!

speaker: Byleth
text: It's OK to be worried.

speaker: Raphael
text: But worrying about it won't solve my problems! What if I can never eat fish again?

speaker: Byleth
text: Time heals all wounds.

speaker: Raphael
text: Good point, Professor. I think I need to see other meats right now. Then I can come back to fish when I'm good and ready!

speaker: Ignatz
text: Ah, Professor! The Battle of the Eagle and Lion was such good fun, don't you think?

speaker: Hilda
text: Ignatz, how long are you going to keep harping on about the Battle of the Eagle and Lion?

speaker: Ignatz
text: Aw, come on, let me gush! Did you see how the house leaders came together after the battle? What an incredible thing to witness! Harmony, even after something so hard-fought.

speaker: Hilda
text: True. If they can keep playing nice, perhaps there will be peace in Fódlan after all.

speaker: Lysithea
text: I heard about Remire Village from some of the knights. It's certainly troubling. If it's a contagion, we at Garreg Mach should be on the lookout as well.

speaker: Byleth
text: I don't believe it is.

speaker: Lysithea
text: Oh? Well, that's better, but I wonder what the real cause could be... Your words are oddly persuasive, Professor. Even if they're not exactly based on anything.

speaker: Byleth
text: I'll handle it.

speaker: Lysithea
text: Your words are oddly persuasive, Professor. Even if they're not exactly based on anything.

speaker: Marianne
text: Good day, Professor. Well then, I should go.

speaker: Leonie
text: Professor! Captain Jeralt just told me. Remire Village is in a bad way, right?

speaker: Jeralt
text: The situation there is worrying, yes... But tell me, how is your vertigo?

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm all right now.

speaker: Leonie
text: Were you not feeling OK? You seem fine to me.

speaker: Jeralt
text: I hope you're not just saying that. We can't have you putting on a brave face only to fall in battle.

speaker: Byleth
text: Still a little unsteady.

speaker: Leonie
text: Are you not feeling OK? You should get some rest!

speaker: Jeralt
text: Hm. If you must go to the village, make sure you're in good health before we depart.

speaker: Rhea
text: Professor... Do you ever wish you could return to your life as a mercenary?

speaker: Byleth
text: I do.

speaker: Rhea
text: I thought you might. Traveling the world, just you and Jeralt... How lovely it must have been.

speaker: Byleth
text: I do not.

speaker: Rhea
text: Is that so? I suppose you have become accustomed to your new line of work. This month's assignment will again take you outside of Garreg Mach...to Remire Village.

speaker: Rhea
text: It was in Remire that you first met Alois and the rest of his order, was it not? Half a year has come and gone since then. How quickly time passes...

speaker: Seteth
text: What is it? I am in the middle of my daily duties. I assume you know by now that the Four Saints are all important figures in the teachings of Seiros... Still, I have a particular fondness for Saint Cethleann.

speaker: Flayn
text: I am so happy to be part of your class, Professor. I honestly cannot recall the last time I interacted with others on a daily basis like this... It reminds me of when I was a child. Ha, that was so very long ago now...

speaker: Byleth
text: How long ago?

speaker: Flayn
text: Oh, I mean, very. Very, very, very long ago.

speaker: Byleth
text: You're still a child.

speaker: Flayn
text: Despite how young I may appear to you, I'm quite mature. You may be surprised, you know.

speaker: Alois
text: I'm going to catch me some mighty fish, just you wait and see! I didn't catch a single fish last month. But this month! This month!

speaker: Byleth
text: Time to give up.

speaker: Alois
text: That's exactly what Captain Jeralt said!

speaker: Byleth
text: Maybe you're doing something wrong?

speaker: Alois
text: I'm casting my line just as the captain taught me all those years ago...

speaker: Alois
text: You're going with the captain to investigate Remire Village, aren't you? It feels like so long ago that you two came here...

speaker: Catherine
text: Of the four or five years since I started here, this is certainly the busiest.

speaker: Shamir
text: It was four. I've been here five.

speaker: Catherine
text: Oh, what's a year here or there? Don' t be petty now, Shamir.

speaker: Shamir
text: You count your enemies the same way.

speaker: Catherine
text: If I take care of them quickly, what does it matter how many there are? Oh, sorry! We didn't mean to ignore you, Professor.

speaker: Shamir
text: As you were saying, it's been a busy year. There never seem to be enough hands for the work.

speaker: Catherine
text: That reminds me, do you have that thing? If you do, we want it.

speaker: Shamir
text: Want? No. We need it. Give it to me, not her.

speaker: Catherine
text: Hey now, I'm the one who brought it up. We may be friends, but that's just rude.

speaker: Gilbert
text: Professor? Tell me, is this about Remire? There are more villagers acting strangely today than yesterday. Knights have been dispatched, yet... The underlying cause is as yet unclear, and the most anyone can do is stand back and watch. It is most distressing. Professor, what do you think about all this?

speaker: Byleth
text: Some kind of illness.

speaker: Gilbert
text: If it were indeed a disease, why would it only affect the villagers, and not infect the knights stationed there?

speaker: Byleth
text: Some kind of conspiracy.

speaker: Gilbert
text: In that case, we should strengthen the guards. If you visit the village, Professor, please...take care.

speaker: Byleth
text: Punishment from the goddess.

speaker: Gilbert
text: The goddess?! You have spoken near blasphemy, and I would suggest a hasty apology!

speaker: Hanneman
text: I thought we might make it through last month in peace, but no. Another incident just had to arise, didn't it? If only this debacle had to do with Crests. Why, I'd have gone and dealt with it in an instant.

speaker: Manuela
text: I know you figure medicine and magical healing are two ways to do the same thing, but it's way deeper than that. Medicine is all about preventing infection and suppressing symptoms with, well, medicine... That's probably obvious. But magical healing is focused on closing up wounds faster, raising a body's vital energy, stuff like that.

speaker: Cyril
text: The knights go out from Garreg Mach to take on all kinds of other duties. I'd sure like a job like that one day. Then again, I don't know... Serving Lady Rhea here is pretty good.

speaker: Gatekeeper
text: Greetings, Professor! Nothing to report! Oh, except that Tomas departed the monastery and is yet to return. Consider that reported. He's been gone for periods of time before and has always returned, so I'm not too worried. Still... I wonder what in the world he's doing out there!

speaker: Jeralt
text: We've got to go. Now.

speaker: Byleth
text: What's going on?

speaker: Byleth
text: OK.

speaker: Jeralt
text: The situation in Remire Village has changed drastically. We don't know much more than that. We're hearing reports that the villagers are killing each other. Some say houses are burning. Regardless, we need to move.

speaker: Rampaging Villager
text: Kill! Kill! Ahhhh!

speaker: Rampaging Villager
text: Haha... Hahaha... Hrngyarhh!

speaker: Village Child
text: Help! Somebody, please help!

speaker: Jeralt
text: What's going on here...

speaker: Edelgard
text: This is horrific. It's even more revolting...more terrible than I expected.

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm revolted too.

speaker: Byleth
text: It really is horrifying.

speaker: Hubert
text: True, but if we are not careful how we proceed, we will only increase the death toll.

speaker: Caspar
text: The villagers are all attacking each other! Let's knock them all out, one by one!

speaker: Linhardt
text: Always so reckless. You do know that if we mess up, we will either kill or be killed, right?

speaker: Ferdinand
text: Still, we cannot just stand here twiddling our thumbs and doing nothing!

speaker: Bernadetta
text: I'd r-really like to go home now...but there's no time for thoughts like that.

speaker: Dorothea
text: We have to help them!

speaker: Petra
text: I am waiting for your orders with full readiness.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Wait. Those people over there... They seem to be observing the chaos. They must be behind this. Eliminate them and rescue all of the unafflicted villagers.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Ungh...

speaker: Byleth
text: What's wrong with you?

speaker: Byleth
text: Are you OK?

speaker: Dimitri
text: I... Don't worry about me. I'm fine.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Don't waste your time on me. Saving the village is far more important. We haven't a moment to lose!

speaker: Dedue
text: What can we do amidst such confusion?

speaker: Felix
text: We'll have to take up arms against the villagers who are rampaging. If we strike carefully, it should be possible to spare their lives.

speaker: Mercedes
text: Oh dear... Isn't there a more peaceful way to deal with this?

speaker: Ingrid
text: No matter how long it takes, we'll need to check and rescue them all, one at a time.

speaker: Ashe
text: Those who have gone made may be victims themselves. Is it possible to save them?

speaker: Annette
text: Well, saving the poor people who aren't crazy is definitely our top priority! Let's get on with it!

speaker: Sylvain
text: Slow down, Annette. It won't do anyone any good if we panic and get injured ourselves.

speaker: Dedue
text: Isn't that... Your Highness. Suspicious figures spotted in the village. They seem to be...watching the chaos.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Are they the ones responsible for this madness? If so...it's clear what must be done. Kill them all. Don't let a single one of them escape. Sever their limbs and crush their wicked skulls!

speaker: Claude
text: This is unbelievable... There's no way to tell who's lost their mind from who's mad with fear...

speaker: Hilda
text: If we don't act quickly, things are just going to keep getting worse!

speaker: Byleth
text: It's horrifying.

speaker: Hilda
text: I really don't want to get involved here...but we can't leave these people on their own, right?

speaker: Byleth
text: What can we do?

speaker: Raphael
text: How about we hit them hard enough to knock them out, but not hard enough to kill them?

speaker: Ignatz
text: That's too reckless! But... I'll admit, I can't think of a better option.

speaker: Marianne
text: If some must die, just know it was by the will of the goddess...

speaker: Leonie
text: Stop that, Marianne! We have to save all of them. There's no way this madness is by the will of the goddess!

speaker: Lorenz
text: Nobles are responsible for the safety of commoners. By the honor of House Gloucester, I swear that I will save them all.

speaker: Lysithea
text: Claude. There are some strange-looking people here.

speaker: Claude
text: So you noticed too. Look. There's a suspicious group hiding amongst the villagers. Could they be the culprits? If so...

speaker: Byleth
text: They will not be forgiven.

speaker: Byleth
text: I won't let them escape.

speaker: Claude
text: There you have it. Our objective is clear. Take down that suspicious group and rescue the villagers.

speaker: Jeralt
text: There are some suspicious looking ruffians out there, but our top priority is to rescue the villagers! Got it? I'll rein in the villagers who've turned violent. You focus on rescuing the others.

speaker: Edelgard
text: The one giving commands in the back... I'm certain that's Tomas, the librarian.

speaker: Dimitri
text: The one giving orders to the others...isn't that Tomas, the librarian?

speaker: Claude
text: It can't be… The one giving orders to the weird ruffians… Isn't that Tomas?

speaker: Edelgard
text: Tomas, what are you doing here? Dare I even ask?

speaker: Dimitri
text: Tomas. What are you doing here?

speaker: Claude
text: Tomas! What in the world are you doing here?

speaker: Tomas
text: I'm not Tomas. My name is Solon, the savior of all!

speaker: Solon
text: What's the matter? So shocked you can't even speak? You were so easily fooled by my disguise… I was hiding away in Garreg Mach to get the blood of that little girl called Flayn. With her blood, we'll be one step closer to realizing our goal.

speaker: Death Knight
text: I'll have a bit of fun here too…

speaker: Jeralt
text: That's the Death Knight! He must be an ally of Tomas...or Solon, or whoever he is.

speaker: Solon
text: They charge in without any plan whatsoever. Beasts, all of them... The experiment is over. Kill them!

speaker: Edelgard
text: Solon, what have you done?! You will not escape punishment!

speaker: Dimitri
text: ... I will cut you to shreds!

speaker: Claude
text: You monster! We could have saved them!

speaker: Rampaging Villager
text: Kill! Kill!

speaker: Villager
text: Th-thank you!

speaker: Jeralt
text: We've rescued as many as we can. Now it's time to capture Solon.

speaker: Solon
text: Ah, the cursed Fell Star... This will be a fine opportunity to measure your power.

speaker: Solon
text: You are but a savage, insignificant beast... Yet you think you can kill me?

speaker: Edelgard
text: Tomas! No... Solon, I will stop you.

speaker: Solon
text: What?! If you insist on turning your blade against me, then expect no mercy.

speaker: Death Knight
text: My pleasure... Do your best to kill me with that blade...

speaker: Death Knight
text: You are not the one I crave...

speaker: Death Knight
text: My blade craves their flesh... The weak will eventually die...

speaker: Death Knight
text: What are you trying to do here?

speaker: Edelgard
text: You're the one who should be answering that question. Stay out of my way!

speaker: Edelgard
text: The Death Knight was just a distraction. Let's concentrate on killing Solon.

speaker: Dimitri
text: We let him get away... That doesn't matter now. Our top priority is to kill Solon!

speaker: Claude
text: What does he want, anyway? In any case, we need to take care of Solon!

speaker: Jeralt
text: Why have you gone after this village? What are you planning?

speaker: Solon
text: Heh, I could have conducted this experiment on any test subjects. Now that I have what I came for, I must bid you farewell.

speaker: Jeralt
text: Wait! Damn it, he's gone...

speaker: Edelgard
text: We let him get away... I'll survey the village. There may still be enemies in hiding.

speaker: Dimitri
text: I...will survey the village. There may still be some survivors.

speaker: Claude
text: It's over… All we can do now is focus on our next move. I'll have a look around the village. There may still be people who need our help.

speaker: Jeralt
text: It looks like we somehow managed to sort things out. And casualties were...kept to a minimum. They said they weren't picky about who they used as their "test subjects." Because of them, the people of Remire Village...

speaker: Flame Emperor
text: There you are.

speaker: Jeralt
text: That armor. So, you're the Flame Emperor.

speaker: Flame Emperor
text: Yes. I believe you have met my subordinate, the Death Knight.

speaker: Jeralt
text: Oh, we've met him all right. But back to you. You're the one responsible for the destruction of this village.

speaker: Flame Emperor
text: Do not get the wrong idea.

speaker: Jeralt
text: What in blazes does that mean?

speaker: Flame Emperor
text: It is true that I am working with Solon. But that does not mean our objectives are the same. Had I known they planned to do this, I would have stopped it. You have my word.

speaker: Jeralt
text: Your words are meaningless. Now, I'll have to insist you accompany us back to the monastery.

speaker: Flame Emperor
text: I cannot abide that. However, if you wish to join forces, I will hear your plea.

speaker: Jeralt
text: What?!

speaker: Flame Emperor
text: If left to their own devices, they will commit countless more violent acts like this one. Do you not wish to prevent that? With the Sword of the Creator on our side, Solon would not be a threat...

speaker: Byleth
text: I will join your cause.

speaker: Flame Emperor
text: You are lying. I can see that you cannot contain your fury toward me. Pity.

speaker: Byleth
text: I must refuse.

speaker: Flame Emperor
text: Pity. Though not unexpected.

speaker: Flame Emperor
text: Pray that you do not live to regret your choice.

speaker: Hubert
text: Jeralt, Professor! Have you seen Lady Edelgard?!

speaker: Dedue
text: Jeralt. Professor. Have you seen His Highness?

speaker: Hilda
text: Jeralt! Professor! Have you seen Claude?

speaker: Jeralt
text: What's wrong, kid? Huh? Damn it! He's gone...

speaker: Jeralt
text: Hey. I've been meaning to talk to you. Since coming to the monastery...you've changed.

speaker: Byleth
text: Changed?

speaker: Byleth
text: How so?

speaker: Jeralt
text: You've been angry since we first arrived in Remire Village. And you look so happy when you're instructing the brats. Before the monastery, I'd never seen you bear your emotions like that. Not once.

speaker: Byleth
text: You might be right.

speaker: Byleth
text: It's thanks to the students.

speaker: Jeralt
text: Then perhaps it's a good thing we came to the monastery, if only so I could see your face lit up like that. Or maybe there was never any reason for us to leave the monastery in the first place...

speaker: Byleth
text: A reason to leave?

speaker: Byleth
text: Wasn't I born after you left the monastery?

speaker: Jeralt
text: Ah... I've put my foot in my mouth, haven't I? Though I suppose it may be nearly that time... Come to my office when you next have a moment to spare. There's something I need to tell you.

speaker: Sothis
text: Just what was that about? I can't recall a time of old when you were at the monastery... I wonder what is hiding in the mist that is your past...

speaker: Edelgard
text: Professor, I don't know if this is appropriate to say, but...admirable work out there. I really believe we did all that we could.

speaker: Byleth
text: I wish that were true.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Jeralt said the same thing. We must try to stay positive, even through the horror.

speaker: Byleth
text: I wasn't strong enough.

speaker: Edelgard
text: No mortal is all powerful. We must try to stay positive, even through the horror.

speaker: Edelgard
text: I hear the so-called "Flame Emperor" appeared in Remire Village as well. Hubert told me that you spoke with him.

speaker: Byleth
text: He said he wasn't involved in this incident.

speaker: Edelgard
text: And do you believe him, Professor?

speaker: Byleth
text: I believe him.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Oh? But how can you trust someone without even knowing who they are?

speaker: Byleth
text: I don't believe him.

speaker: Edelgard
text: That makes sense. It's hard to trust someone without knowing who they are or how they're connected to all this.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Even if his words are true, his objectives are still unclear. But if the Flame Emperor should someday reveal his true intentions... Maybe then he will appear before you without his mask, and you can look in his eyes and decide what you believe.

speaker: Byleth
text: He asked me to join forces with him.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Really? Is that what you want, Professor?

speaker: Byleth
text: I do.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Oh? But how can you trust someone without even knowing who they are?

speaker: Byleth
text: I do not.

speaker: Edelgard
text: That makes sense. It's hard to trust someone without knowing who they are or how they're connected to all this.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Even if he wants you as an ally, his objectives are still unclear. If the Flame Emperor truly wishes to make use of your power... Perhaps someday he will appear before you without his mask, and you can look in his eyes and decide what you believe.

speaker: Monica
text: Edel! I need to ask you something! Oh, I'm so sorry. Did I interrupt?

speaker: Edelgard
text: No, not at all. If you'll excuse me, Professor.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Professor... I...I'm sorry you saw that side of me in the village. It must have been quite a shock to you and the others. I'm mortified by my behavior. When I saw the chaos and violence there...my mind just went completely dark.

speaker: Byleth
text: I felt the same.

speaker: Dimitri
text: I see... So that happens to you as well, then.

speaker: Byleth
text: You weren't yourself.

speaker: Dimitri
text: I see why you would say that. I always strive to keep my emotions at bay, but... Sometimes the darkness takes hold and...it's impossible to suppress. It just shows you how lacking I am... I have much to learn.

speaker: Dimitri
text: I've told you before...that some day we may find ourselves facing something we simply cannot accept. That's what the chaos in Remire Village was to me. Solon and the Flame Emperor are both beasts who must be eliminated. Demons who kill the innocent. They aren't even human at this point.

speaker: Byleth
text: The Flame Emperor said he wasn't involved.

speaker: Dimitri
text: And you believed him?! He doesn't deserve our forgiveness. He became an accomplice when he refused to turn himself in and return with us to the monastery.

speaker: Byleth
text: Where is this anger coming from?

speaker: Dimitri
text: It must be hard to fathom. It's true that I don't have any strong connection to those villagers. And yet...

speaker: Dimitri
text: You see, Professor... I saw the same flames of torment just four years ago...in Duscur.

speaker: Kingdom General
text: Please! Have mercy!

speaker: Kingdom Soldier
text: Gah, the pain! Make the burning stop! Help me... Somebody...

speaker: Lambert
text: Avenge us! Those who killed us... Tear them apart! Destroy them all!

speaker: Dimitri
text: Ugh... Gah... My father...my stepmother... Four years ago, they lost their lives to those flames. I'll never forget... I still remember their faces. Their screams. The tortured last moments of every person who died that day... But right now...all that matters is that we do whatever we can to help the surviving villagers get back to their normal lives.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Thank you. For everything.  There's a reason that I came to the Officers Academy. Just one reason. I came here for revenge. And one day, I will have it.

speaker: Claude
text: Hey, Teach. That assignment wasn't my favorite, I've got to admit. I suppose pretending to be unaffected doesn't do anyone any good. That was terrible to behold. It's always hard to see innocents die.

speaker: Byleth
text: It is.

speaker: Byleth
text: I wasn't strong enough.

speaker: Claude
text: Hey, all you can do is keep smiling. Keep marching. That's part of a leader's job. You can't give in to despair. Not just for me or for you, but for all of us in the Golden Deer House. We have to keep smiling so the others can move forward too. As long as we don't show that we're disheartened, they'll know they can make it too. That's what matters.

speaker: Claude
text: Sorry for getting ahead of myself, Teach. That's how I feel, but how you handle it is really up to you. By the way... I hear that guy who calls himself the Flame Emperor showed up in Remire Village. I couldn't believe it when Hilda told me the news. What could he be after?

speaker: Byleth
text: The Heroes' Relics.

speaker: Claude
text: Maybe. After all, he was after the Sword of the Creator in the Holy Mausoleum... But then they kidnapped Flayn and used her blood for their recent attack. Based on that, we should probably assume that their true objective is something other than the Relics. Don't you think?

speaker: Byleth
text: You have a point.

speaker: Byleth
text: What do they want with Flayn's blood?

speaker: Claude
text: They called this incident "an experiment." And they said they got what they came for. That means they might take this success and attempt something even bigger next time. Sadly, that's all we can assume. There are far too many things we still don't know.

speaker: Byleth
text: World domination.

speaker: Claude
text: Ha! I know I just laughed, but that really isn't funny, Teach. World domination... Hm. OK, actually... I wonder. They called this incident "an experiment." And they said they got what they came for. That means they might take this success and attempt something even bigger next time. I hate to even consider it, but if they can replicate the incident at Remire Village on an even larger scale... If we're not careful, we'll have a full-scale war on our hands. Then world domination wouldn't be a joke anymore.

speaker: Byleth
text: I don't know.

speaker: Claude
text: I was afraid you'd say that. Frankly, there's way too much that we still don't know. They called this incident "an experiment." And they said they got what they came for. That means they might take this success and attempt something even bigger next time. Sadly, that's all we can assume.

speaker: Claude
text: Flayn! Your timing is impeccable. Would you care to join us for a while, fair lady?

speaker: Flayn
text: Wha--? Why?! Oh my!

speaker: Claude
text: Damn. She gave us the slip. In any case, I doubt she knows the full story. It seems more like she has something on her mind that she can't divulge.

speaker: Byleth
text: You're pushing too hard.

speaker: Byleth
text: We can't go easy on her.

speaker: Claude
text: Whoa, there. Settle yourself, Teach.

speaker: Claude
text: Seems like it would be better to push Seteth for an explanation. Or, best of all, to go above his head and ask Rhea... Now that we know Tomas was an enemy, we can't be sure that exposing the church's secrets would be to our benefit. Where are the answers I seek? Where are they...

speaker: Rhea
text: You did well handling that awful business in Remire Village. I am certain the goddess shares in our grief at the senselessness of that calamity. More importantly, I was shocked to hear that our own Tomas was actually a dark mage. I must reflect on our blindness.

speaker: Sothis
text: You surely must! You failed to notice that a rat was hiding in your home. Pathetic! Who are these wicked foes? How did Tomas escape your gaze?

speaker: Byleth
text: Who are these villains?

speaker: Byleth
text: Why did Tomas come to the monastery?

speaker: Seteth
text: Tomas came to the monastery 40 years ago, by recommendation of House Ordelia of the Alliance. Around eight years ago he went back to House Ordelia before returning to the monastery once again just last year. After having worked at Garreg Mach for decades, why would he betray us now? Just what did he hope to accomplish? Jeritza became a professor at the Officers Academy because of a recommendation from the Imperial nobility. Supposing that he is the Death Knight, that means that our enemy is an organization that has taken root in at least two territories.

speaker: Rhea
text: In the long history of the Church of Seiros... No, long before even that... There have been an endless number of threats to the peace of Fódlan. Yet, those who oppose us still operate in the shadows, their identities a mystery. I believe that Solon and the Death Knight are merely one part of a much larger whole.

speaker: Sothis
text: A threat to Fódlan's peace? That means we have no choice. We have to stop them all!

speaker: Byleth
text: What now?

speaker: Seteth
text: Without knowing what their objective is, we cannot afford to act recklessly. The knights will investigate. For now, you and your class should focus on your training.

speaker: Byleth
text: They must be stopped.

speaker: Rhea
text: I have truly come to rely on you. I believe that the monastery will remain safe so long as we have you. We do not yet know the enemy's objective or whereabouts. For now, please devote yourself to preparing for whatever comes next.

speaker: Seteth
text: That is all for today.

speaker: Rhea
text: Professor. Please wait. I know there is much that you still do not understand. However, one thing is clear. You possess great power. I believe that you are destined to be a source of great hope for all. In any case, I expect great things from you. Walk this world proudly, dear Professor. May the goddess Sothis protect you.

speaker: Sothis
text: The goddess Sothis?! Is that what she just said?

speaker: Rhea
text: Is something the matter?

speaker: Byleth
text: It's nothing.

speaker: Rhea
text: I see. In that case, farewell.

speaker: Byleth
text: I had never heard the name of the goddess.

speaker: Rhea
text: I see. Sothis is the goddess's true name. Please do not use it carelessly. Farewell.

speaker: Sothis
text: Do not say something that we may regret! She... I... What exactly am I? For now, let's leave this place. Please... Go!

speaker: Edelgard
text: Professor, you already know about the Battle of the Eagle and Lion, correct?

speaker: Byleth
text: Only the name.

speaker: Byleth
text: I can't recall.

speaker: Edelgard
text: I see. In that case, allow me to fill you in. It's a large-scale mock battle between the rival houses that takes place every year.

speaker: Hubert
text: Its scale is incomparable to the mock battle we fought during the Great Tree Moon. It will take place in the vast Gronder Field. That is in Empire territory to the southeast of Garreg Mach.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Whichever house defeats the most opponents wins. Of course, the professors also fight alongside their respective houses.

speaker: Hubert
text: Well, usually. Professor Manuela is being prudent. She will not be participating this year. Since his long-time rival will be absent, Professor Hanneman has also declined.

speaker: Byleth
text: In that case, I must sit out too.

speaker: Byleth
text: What should I do?

speaker: Manuela
text: Oh, don't worry about us. You know you wanna see the kids in action.

speaker: Hubert
text: Are you feeling any better, Professor Manuela?

speaker: Manuela
text: Thanks to all of you. But I'd only be a burden out there. My students don't need to see me collapsed. Well, not on the battlefield, anyway.

speaker: Hanneman
text: Correct, we will not be participating. Regardless, do not expect victory to come easily. Or at all.

speaker: Manuela
text: Well put. We've spent the past few months pushing our students to their limits. You can see me in the infirmary after they destroy you.

speaker: Byleth
text: If I'm the only professor present...

speaker: Byleth
text: This doesn't seem fair...

speaker: Manuela
text: Oh my, look at you. If you're as confident as all that, my students will walk all over you.

speaker: Hanneman
text: We have taught our students well. There is no need to hold back. Challenge them with everything you have!

speaker: Dimitri
text: The Battle of the Eagle and Lion is finally upon us! This is our chance to show off the results of your expert training, Professor.

speaker: Byleth
text: Battle of the Eagle and Lion?

speaker: Dimitri
text: Have Lady Rhea and Seteth really not filled you in? Well, if that's the case, I'm happy to explain.

speaker: Byleth
text: It slipped my mind.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Haha, I highly doubt that. If you don't mind, I'd be happy to explain.

speaker: Dimitri
text: The Battle of the Eagle and Lion takes place every year during the Wyvern Moon. It can best be described as a mock battle between the three houses.

speaker: Dedue
text: Much like the one we had during the Great Tree Moon. Do you remember, Professor?

speaker: Byleth
text: Yes, I remember.

speaker: Byleth
text: I remember our celebration most of all.

speaker: Dimitri
text: It was certainly an unforgettable time. I've never seen anyone put away as much victory food as you did that night, Professor!

speaker: Dimitri
text: This battle will take place in Empire territory, at Gronder Field. In other words, far removed from the monastery. It's a mock battle between the three houses. The house that defeats the most opponents wins.

speaker: Dedue
text: Your Highness, if the rumors are true, I believe Professor Manuela and Professor Hanneman will not be joining us.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Ah, yes, right you are. Given recent events, Professor Manuela has opted to sit this one out. Since she won't be present, Professor Hanneman has decided to skip this year as well.

speaker: Byleth
text: In that case, I must sit out too.

speaker: Byleth
text: What should I do?

speaker: Manuela
text: Oh, don't worry about us. You know you wanna see the kids in action.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Professor Manuela! Are you feeling better already?

speaker: Manuela
text: Thanks to all of you. But I'd only be a burden out there. My students don't need to see me collapsed. Well, not on the battlefield, anyway.

speaker: Dedue
text: In that case, perhaps it is best that you sit this one out.

speaker: Hanneman
text: Correct, we will not be participating. Regardless, do not expect victory to come easily. Or at all.

speaker: Manuela
text: Well put. We've spent the past few months pushing our students to their limits. You can see me in the infirmary after they destroy you.

speaker: Byleth
text: If I'm the only professor present...

speaker: Byleth
text: This doesn't seem fair...

speaker: Manuela
text: Oh my, look at you. If you're as confident as all that, my students will walk all over you.

speaker: Hanneman
text: We have taught our students well. There is no need to hold back. Challenge them with everything you have!

speaker: Claude
text: It's finally time! The Battle of the Eagle and Lion at Gronder Field is this month. Don't tell me you forgot, Teach?

speaker: Byleth
text: It slipped my mind.

speaker: Claude
text: You're kidding! Come on, Teach, I need you to keep it together for me. Don't lose focus when it counts.

speaker: Byleth
text: I know little about it.

speaker: Claude
text: You're kidding! Didn't Rhea or Seteth fill you in? Guess I have to do everything myself around here.

speaker: Claude
text: The Battle of the Eagle and Lion is one of the academy's annual traditions. It's a huge mock battle between the three rival houses.

speaker: Hilda
text: But you know all about rivalry battles, Professor. There was one right after you got here, remember? I hear the Battle of the Eagle and Lion will be held in Gronder Field, far away from Garreg Mach.

speaker: Claude
text: The house that defeats most opponents wins. It's a three-way battle that relies heavily on strategy. Sounds exciting, doesn't it?

speaker: Hilda
text: Hey Claude, what about Professor Manuela? Do you think she'll be able to join us despite her injuries?

speaker: Claude
text: I'm afraid she's sitting this one out, as is Professor Hanneman.  "As my persistent rival will not be present, it only goes to follow that I must also sit out this year's battle. Now leave me be, Claude!"

speaker: Byleth
text: In that case, I must sit out too.

speaker: Byleth
text: What should I do?

speaker: Manuela
text: Oh, don't worry about us. You know you wanna see the kids in action.

speaker: Claude
text: If it isn't our own Professor Manuela! All things considered, you're looking well.

speaker: Manuela
text: Thanks to all of you. But I'd only be a burden out there. My students don't need to see me collapsed. Well, not on the battlefield, anyway.

speaker: Hilda
text: Does that mean you really won't be joining us for the battle?

speaker: Hanneman
text: Correct, we will not be participating. Regardless, do not expect victory to come easily. Or at all.

speaker: Manuela
text: Well put. We've spent the past few months pushing our students to their limits. You can see me in the infirmary after they destroy you.

speaker: Byleth
text: If I'm the only professor present...

speaker: Byleth
text: This doesn't seem fair...

speaker: Manuela
text: Oh my, look at you. If you're as confident as all that, my students will walk all over you.

speaker: Hanneman
text: We have taught our students well. There is no need to hold back. Challenge them with everything you have!

speaker: Sothis
text: Hmph. This monastery is more dangerous than I expected. It's likely that our foes have infiltrated the ranks of the teachers... And there may be others of questionable character about as well! If you ask me, there is something amiss about that old man...Tomas.

speaker: Monica
text: What do you say, Edel? Shall we meet up in the library later to... Oh! Hello, Professor!

speaker: Edelgard
text: Do you need something? I'm a little busy at the moment.

speaker: Monica
text: Sorry, Professor! I've got a lot of questions to ask Edel here. Since I couldn't graduate last year, I really want to make sure I can do so this year. Don't worry. I won't participate in any assignments so as not to take any attention away from the younger students. I look forward to learning from you, Professor!

speaker: Monica
text: What do you say, Edel? Shall we meet up in the library later to... Oh! Hello, Professor!

speaker: Edelgard
text: Do you need something? I'm a little busy at the moment.

speaker: Monica
text: Sorry, Professor! I've got a lot of questions to ask Edel here. Since I couldn't graduate last year, I really want to make sure I can do so this year.

speaker: Dimitri
text: The Battle of the Eagle and Lion... Its name comes from the war in which the Kingdom won its independence from the Empire. It's imperative that we fight our best. We must live up to the legacy of the King of Lions.

speaker: Dimitri
text: To hold a fishing tournament at a time like this... Participate if you must, but I urge you not to lose sight of our goal. As for me, I won't be joining in. I'm so focused on the battle ahead, I fear I would snap my poor rod right in half.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Flayn and...Monica, was it? I'm glad they were returned safe and sound.

speaker: Claude
text: Going all the way to the Empire for a mock battle? This is serious business. And there's a reward to be had as well. I'd really like to win this thing. Everyone else seems to be raring to go too. We're all looking to you to guide us, Teach.

speaker: Claude
text: Going all the way to the Empire for a mock battle? This is serious business. And there's a reward to be had as well. I'd really like to win this thing.

speaker: Claude
text: Seteth, that stubborn goat. Holding a fishing tournament now? Just last month he looked like death warmed over.

speaker: Hubert
text: The Battle of the Eagle and Lion is a free-for-all contest among the three classes. If you are victorious, the archbishop will no doubt present you with a reward.

speaker: Byleth
text: Consider me motivated.

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm not interest in rewards.

speaker: Hubert
text: Just what I thought you'd say.

speaker: Ferdinand
text: You know, the Empire used to control all of Fódlan. But after the civil war, the northern region split off and became the Kingdom. Later, the eastern part of the Kingdom seceded to become the Alliance. There are three powers today, but a thousand years ago, we were all united as one. Even now, among the nobles of the Empire, there are some who dream of reunifying Fódlan...

speaker: Linhardt
text: I'm just absolutely exhausted. I swear to you, Professor, every month we're worked harder than the month before. I had imagined the academy as a chance to possibly relax before our lives began in earnest.

speaker: Byleth
text: You came to the academy to relax?

speaker: Linhardt
text: After graduating, we'll enter into noble society, which mean contending with all the intrigues and dramas that entails. I want to just...postpone life for a bit. Fish... Nap under a tree... Skip out on lectures and– Well, not on your lectures of course, Professor.

speaker: Byleth
text: It is what it is.

speaker: Linhardt
text: Agreed. That's the Church of Seiros for you. What is it they say? "Those with power are obliged to use it."

speaker: Caspar
text: Are you gonna participate in the fishing tournament, Professor?

speaker: Bernadetta
text: Hi, Professor. Want to know something? Gronder is in the territory of House Bergliez, in the Empire. That's right next to my home, the region of House Varley! Oh. Oh no. What if– What if my parents come to watch?! Aaah!

speaker: Byleth
text: Calm down.

speaker: Bernadetta
text: I'm calm! Of course I'm calm! Why wouldn't I be calm? Ugggh!

speaker: Byleth
text: I don't think nobles are allowed to watch.

speaker: Bernadetta
text: Really? Are you sure?! You wouldn't say that if you weren't completely sure, right?!

speaker: Dorothea
text: Fishing? No thanks. I tried it once, and...ugh. Gross. I don't even really like to eat fish, let alone catch and gut them. Besides, who can think about fishing right now? The Battle of the Eagle and Lion is coming up soon. Feeling confident?

speaker: Byleth
text: Very.

speaker: Dorothea
text: That's the spirit!

speaker: Byleth
text: Not really.

speaker: Dorothea
text: Oh, have a little faith in yourself, Professor. You'll do fine, I'm sure of it.

speaker: Petra
text: I fished with frequency back in Brigid. I will not have losing. Will you be trying to fish too?

speaker: Dedue
text: The Battle of the Eagle and Lion draws near. His Highness insists upon training well into the night. He has said it is nothing to worry about. But how could I not be concerned?

speaker: Dedue
text: Did you want something?

speaker: Dedue
text: Ever since the tournament, the kitchen is completely overtaken with fish. The cooks cannot keep up.

speaker: Felix
text: I'm not interested in glory or prizes. All I want is a formidable enemy to sink my teeth into. As far as I can see, there are only a couple of opponents worth my time.

speaker: Felix
text: Since we were little, Ingrid's always gotten this odd look in her eye when someone brings up food.

speaker: Ashe
text: You know, I'm pretty good at fishing. My older brother used to take me out. Why don't you give it a try too? They say we can eat whatever we catch!

speaker: Sylvain
text: A fishing tournament, huh? Sounds fun, but not as fun as reeling in the ladies. Heh! Just kidding, of course. The most important thing right now is preparing for the Battle of the Eagle and Lion. After all, the ladies love nothing more than a winner. And around here, there's no bigger game.

speaker: Byleth
text: That's the wrong reason to compete.

speaker: Sylvain
text: Everyone has their own reasons to fight. At least I'm honest about mine.

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm sure they do.

speaker: Sylvain
text: I knew you'd understand, Professor.

speaker: Mercedes
text: Hmm... Ah! I'm so sorry! I was lost in thought.

speaker: Byleth
text: You seem a bit down.

speaker: Mercedes
text: It's very kind of you to be concerned, but I promise that I'm fine. I was just thinking... The Death Knight's true identity. Could it actually be Professor Jeritza?

speaker: Byleth
text: What were you thinking about?

speaker: Mercedes
text: The Death Knight's true identity. Could it actually be Professor Jeritza?

speaker: Annette
text: Gronder Field is in the Empire, right? I wonder how we'll get there. I thought I heard that there's no path that goes straight from the monastery to the Empire... Oh! Perhaps we'll travel through Alliance territory. Yes, I see, from the east, we would go...hm, there! Ah, yes, that must be it!

speaker: Ingrid
text: Holding such a frivolous and downright ridiculous event so close to the Battle of the Eagle and Lion... It's absolutely absurd. Although...they did say we could eat whatever we catch. I'm a sucker for a good meal...I just couldn't resist.

speaker: Lorenz
text: I received a rare letter from my father recently. He said that he is praying for the Golden Deer House to emerge victorious. Insistently praying. My father attended the Officers Academy, and won a glorious victory in the Battle of the Eagle and Lion. I think he is quite proud of that, even to this day. I suppose that shows how great an honor it truly is.

speaker: Raphael
text: Hey, Professor! Did you hear about the fishing tournament? You get to fish in the pond as much as you want. The more you catch, the more you get to eat!

speaker: Ignatz
text: Sometimes it's nice to dangle a fishing line and let your mind wander. I'd love to spend some time lounging around by a scenic river or lake.

speaker: Lysithea
text: Why would we go all the way to Gronder Field? It's idiocy to travel that far. It may be a tradition, but it takes forever to get there and is exhausting. So pointless. I guess there's nothing to be done about it. Even by you, Professor.

speaker: Marianne
text: Excuse me, Professor. Um, do you think it would reflect poorly on me if I chose not to take part in the Battle of the Eagle and Lion?

speaker: Byleth
text: Yes, it would.

speaker: Marianne
text: Oh, I see...

speaker: Byleth
text: Don't you want to participate?

speaker: Marianne
text: Well, I don't really want to leave the monastery...

speaker: Marianne
text: I'm not very confident, but I'll try my best.

speaker: Hilda
text: Professor, do you have a second? It's about Monica. Does she seem...off to you? She was imprisoned for a long time, but she seems to have recovered almost instantly, and she's been bizarrely cheerful.

speaker: Byleth
text: Now that you mention it...

speaker: Hilda
text: You see what I mean? I wonder if she's straining to seem happy, just to make people comfortable.

speaker: Byleth
text: She's moving on. Isn't that a good thing?

speaker: Hilda
text: I guess you're right. It just seems fast, doesn't it?

speaker: Hilda
text: Hmm... And why is she so close to Edelgard anyway?

speaker: Leonie
text: Why are they having a fishing tournament now? Are they just giving up on the battle of the Eagle and Lion?! You're not condoning this, right? Are you?!

speaker: Byleth
text: Yes, I'm taking part.

speaker: Leonie
text: What?! If you've got all this free time, shouldn't you be spending it on your students?

speaker: Byleth
text: No, I'm not taking part.

speaker: Leonie
text: Good. I'm looking forward to seeing you in action. I hope Captain Jeralt will be watching.

speaker: Rhea
text: The situation last month was dire indeed. The students endured great hardship. I hope you are able to put all of that behind you so that you may focus on this month's assignment.

speaker: Byleth
text: Of course.

speaker: Rhea
text: A most reassuring response. I trust that your class is in good hands.

speaker: Byleth
text: It will be difficult.

speaker: Rhea
text: That is to be expected. I, too, cannot quite shake that feeling of unease. Even so, we must both strive to put that nasty business behind us.

speaker: Rhea
text: I look forward to seeing your skills on display at the Battle of the Eagle and Lion.

speaker: Seteth
text: I have something to ask of you.

speaker: Byleth
text: What is it?

speaker: Byleth
text: Leave it to me.

speaker: Seteth
text: I have not even told you what my request is yet! Well, fine.

speaker: Seteth
text: Flayn has been through an awful lot this past month. To make up for that, I have decided to give her whatever she wants. I asked her what she would like, and she expressed a desire for a feast of fish. Since I'm sure the students would be interested, I have decided to hold a fishing tournament here at the monastery. I have left all of the specifics to Shamir. Please, enter and put in your best effort.

speaker: Seteth
text: I hear that you participated in the fishing tournament. I appreciate you taking the time.

speaker: Flayn
text: I told my brother I had a craving for some tasty fish. I did not realize when I did that it would turn into...well, this. My apologies.

speaker: Alois
text: I'm going to catch me some mighty fish, just you wait and see! Er, but they haven't been biting...

speaker: Byleth
text: Your shouting is scaring the fish.

speaker: Alois
text: What shouting? Everyone told me I was too loud, so I've been using my quiet voice.

speaker: Byleth
text: Maybe the fish are frightened by you.

speaker: Alois
text: I didn't think of that. Ah, the truth is right in front of me...  Just kidding. As though a fish is smart enough to be afraid of me.

speaker: Catherine
text: Can you believe what Seteth said? "Catch some tasty fish for Flayn." I'm her bodyguard!

speaker: Shamir
text: Welcome to the monastery fishing tournament. You look confused. Didn't Seteth tell you about it? Just catch whatever fish Flayn requests. Show any fish you catch to Flayn.

speaker: Shamir
text: The fishing tournament is over. I heard you did some fishing, and that Flayn is happy.

speaker: Gilbert
text: Professor, has Seteth told you? We're to have a fishing tournament. Given the events of the last month, I believe this is just the sort of distraction we need, staff and student alike.

speaker: Byleth
text: Will you take part?

speaker: Gilbert
text: I'm afraid I am not one for festivities. I do enjoy a spot of fishing, though.

speaker: Byleth
text: Are you good at fishing?

speaker: Gilbert
text: I do enjoy the sport, yet I wouldn't say I'm particularly good at it.

speaker: Gilbert
text: I believe it best that I stick to quietly fishing by myself.

speaker: Jeralt
text: The recent happenings at the monastery... There is something going on behind the scenes here. I've been commissioned to investigate as well. As I've already mentioned, this month I'm off to the Kingdom. You be on your guard, OK?

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm not worried.

speaker: Jeralt
text: Well, I hope you're right.

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm more worried about you than myself.

speaker: Jeralt
text: Perhaps I've gotten into your head too much! I won't go dying on you. I've stayed alive this long, after all.

speaker: Jeralt
text: How are preparations for the Battle of the Eagle and Lion going? Hm? Fishing? Taking it easy, are you?

speaker: Hanneman
text: I don' t know if you've heard, but Flayn is very special. Her blood carries a rare Crest... Oh, the lengths to which she could advance my research, if only I was allowed to study her! If only it weren't for Seteth's strict orders! He protects his sister with unusual zeal.

speaker: Byleth
text: You should give up.

speaker: Hanneman
text: I dislike it, but I agree. The time I would spend begging him and accomplishing nothing would be better spent on other research.

speaker: Byleth
text: Maybe you can convince him.

speaker: Hanneman
text: Have you ever tried convincing Seteth of anything? I'm not sure I could convince the man the sky is blue if he hadn't already looked up for himself.

speaker: Manuela
text: I always thought I was pretty good, you know? Then I go and get stabbed. Ugh... But my opponent was the Death Knight, so I figure I did pretty well to only get stabbed. I wonder if it's true that he is actually Jeritza... Whoever he is...I'm going to make him pay. It turns out that when I get stabbed, I get really mad!

speaker: Byleth
text: He hurt you this time. Next time he may kill you.

speaker: Byleth
text: I'll help you get revenge.

speaker: Manuela
text: I'm not going to let him get the better of me again!

speaker: Tomas
text: When you feel that first refreshing breeze upon your face, you know it is almost time for the Battle of the Eagle and Lion. Gronder Field is within the Empire, but the path there from the monastery necessitates passing through Alliance territory. Fódlan's biggest river, the Airmid River, flows along the border between the Empire and the Alliance. You will have to cross one of the largest bridges upon that river, the Great Bridge of Myrddin.

speaker: Cyril
text: Fódlan is big. It's not as big as Almyra is, but it's still pretty big.

speaker: Byleth
text: Do you want to travel around Fódlan someday?

speaker: Cyril
text: Travel? I don't know... Never thought about it, I guess.

speaker: Byleth
text: Do you want to go home to Almyra?

speaker: Cyril
text: Why do you think I would want to do that?

speaker: Gatekeeper
text: Greetings, Professor! Nothing to report! Young Monica disappeared last year. I thought she had simply run along home. But it turns out she was kidnapped! I can't believe it. How awful it must have been for the poor thing. They say her personality is completely changed, but at least she seems more cheerful than before. Grateful to be alive, perhaps?

speaker: Monk
text: Ah, I see. So you are Jeralt's child. You so resemble your mother.

speaker: Byleth
text: Did you know my mother?

speaker: Monk
text: I did indeed. I was acquainted with your parents. I've been wanting to speak with you for a while now.

speaker: Byleth
text: Who might you be?

speaker: Monk
text: I am nothing more than a common monk. I knew your parents...once upon a time.

speaker: Monk
text: I've been gone from the monastery for some time now because... Well, it matters not. Might I...ask a favor? Do you mind terribly picking up some fresh flowers to place upon your mother's grave? I am certain she'd be deeply moved to receive a gift from you.

speaker: Caspar
text: Gronder Field is in the Empire. It's actually part of my family's territory - House Bergliez. It is the largest field in all of Fódlan. The grain it produces sustains the whole Empire. Wait... I sure hope we don't destroy all that grain.

speaker: Hubert
text: It is considered the most suitable place for a large-scale battle.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Professor, if it were up to you, how would you approach this battle?

speaker: Byleth
text: I would fight them head-on.

speaker: Byleth
text: I would surprise them with clever schemes.

speaker: Edelgard
text: That sounds like a certain someone we both know. But as you wish. We'll use whatever strategy you think is best. If the Black Eagle House bands together, we won't lose.

speaker: Hubert
text: Our strength is superior. So if we do lose, it would be on your shoulders, Professor.

speaker: Ferdinand
text: If you're not confident you can do this, just sit back and leave it to me.

speaker: Hubert
text: The most you will do is make things worse. You'll just get in Lady Edelgard's way.

speaker: Caspar
text: Are you two about to fight? Haha! Count me in! Wait, no. I think we all need to calm down.

speaker: Petra
text: We have no lack of opponents. I am ready to go hunting for our enemies!

speaker: Dorothea
text: Hunting isn't exactly... Well, I guess they're pretty similar, actually.

speaker: Bernadetta
text: I'm just gonna hide in the fort and cheer everyone on. There, um, is a fort, right?

speaker: Linhardt
text: Sure, but it's deep in enemy territory. How kind of you to offer to cut through for us.

speaker: Bernadetta
text: What?! No! That's not what I meant! Ugh, good work Bernie...

speaker: Linhardt
text: This will be your first battle, won't it, Flayn? You don't seem nervous at all.

speaker: Flayn
text: Haha, I shall give it my all!

speaker: Edelgard
text: Our battle will begin shortly. The flag of the Black Eagles will soon grace Gronder Field!

speaker: Dimitri
text: So, this is to be our battlefield...Gronder Field. Are you feeling confident, Professor?

speaker: Byleth
text: Very.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Excellent. That's most reassuring.

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm not so sure.

speaker: Dimitri
text: We've seen your power firsthand, so we know better than anyone what you're capable of. Beyond that, we believe in you. If it's not too big a burden, I ask that you believe in us as well.

speaker: Dimitri
text: We can win. I'm sure of it. After all, it's not as though we've spent the last half-year sitting idle. And I'm feeling stronger this moon. As though I could conquer a thousand opponents all on my own.

speaker: Byleth
text: That's reassuring.

speaker: Dimitri
text: You can depend on me. I hope you know that.

speaker: Byleth
text: Don't get carried away...

speaker: Dimitri
text: I'm only joking, of course... But perhaps it isn't a laughing matter. I beg your forgiveness. I must practice levity so that I can provide a more enjoyable joke when the opportunity next presents itself. After all, I hear that telling jokes is a good way to calm the nerves before heading into battle. Still...I find it quite difficult.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Well, it's about time for the battle to begin. Everyone, brace yourselves.

speaker: Felix
