text: Hmph. All I'm worried about is finding someone worthy to cross swords with.

speaker: Mercedes
text: We've prepared and trained a great deal. We should be fine, right?

speaker: Annette
text: You're always so carefree, Mercie! Don't forget we need to try our hardest out there so we can win!

speaker: Ashe
text: This is our chance to show how hard we've been working! Let's do our best.

speaker: Sylvain
text: If I emerge victorious in the lauded Battle of the Eagle and Lion, the ladies are sure to take notice. I'll have to go into hiding.

speaker: Ingrid
text: Ugh, is that all you think about? Actually, as long as you try your hardest, frame it however you like.

speaker: Flayn
text: Haha, I shall give it my all!

speaker: Dedue
text: No matter the battle, I will never falter.

speaker: Dimitri
text: We're counting on your guidance, Professor. Let's show the world what the Blue Lions are made of!

speaker: Claude
text: So this is Gronder Field... Hey, Teach. Not a bad place to wage war, is it?

speaker: Byleth
text: How so?

speaker: Byleth
text: Absolutely.

speaker: Claude
text: I knew you'd understand.

speaker: Claude
text: Plenty of places to hide, and our pick of paths to advance through. It's the perfect battlefield for our tactics. I have my eye on that low hill over there. See it? It's the ideal spot to lure our enemies to, and then surround them with fire.

speaker: Byleth
text: It's risky.

speaker: Byleth
text: Fire is unacceptable.

speaker: Claude
text: Gotcha, Teach! I know, I know. We want all students to make it back to the monastery. With you in command, we can't lose. The Imperial princess and the crown prince don't stand a chance.

speaker: Hilda
text: Professor! Claude! What are you two talking about?

speaker: Lorenz
text: What do you expect? It's Claude. I expect he was foisting more of his ill-advised schemes on our poor professor.

speaker: Claude
text: Oh, you have me all figured out, Lorenz. You know me better than I know myself.

speaker: Ignatz
text: Win or lose, it's an honor just to participate in the legendary Battle of the Eagle and Lion!

speaker: Leonie
text: We've got to win so we can show Captain Jeralt what we're made of!

speaker: Raphael
text: Yes! I'm ready! Let's go!

speaker: Flayn
text: Haha, I shall give it my all!

speaker: Marianne
text: I'll just...stay quiet and follow along so I don't get in anyone's way.

speaker: Lysithea
text: That will not be acceptable, Marianne. The whole point of this exercise is for each house to act as one.

speaker: Hilda
text: Do your best! I can't wait to see how well everyone does.

speaker: Claude
text: All right, sounds like Hilda will be taking control of a central hill and watching the battle from there.

speaker: Claude
text: It's almost time. Come on, Teach! The battle starts now!

speaker: Dimitri
text: You all should know... I am not about to go easy on you today.

speaker: Claude
text: As long as we can pull off the win, it doesn't matter how.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Our victory must be absolute...no matter what it may take.

speaker: Seteth
text: It is time.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Forward! now!

speaker: Dimitri
text: For honor!

speaker: Dimitri
text: The Battle of the Eagle and Lion is set to begin at long last. Everyone, show off the results of your dedicated training!

speaker: Claude
text: Remember, we're not just fighting for honor. There's a prize at stake!

speaker: Edelgard
text: It's almost time to begin. Steel yourselves, everyone.

speaker: Claude
text: The Black Eagles and Blue Lions are fighting... Maybe we can sneak right past them.

speaker: Lorenz
text: A stronghold for me to seize? Splendid!

speaker: Claude
text: There goes Lorenz, acting on his own... Guess we've got no choice but to capture the central hill and cover him!

speaker: Dimitri
text: This could be our chance! Dedue, cut through the Golden Deer!

speaker: Dimitri
text: Ingrid, make use of your mobility—circle back behind the Black Eagles!

speaker: Dimitri
text: Mobile force, you move up as well! Circle around to the rear of the Black Eagles!

speaker: Edelgard
text: If you intend to act, do it now. Hubert! Head toward the Golden Deer!

speaker: Edelgard
text: Ferdinand, circle around to the back of the Blue Lions.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Mobile force, you move up as well. Circle around behind the Blue Lions.

speaker: Dimitri
text: The Black Eagles and the Golden Deer are already in battle? We should take this chance to break through the Black Eagle's flank.

speaker: Dedue
text: I will draw the Black Eagles out, Your Highness.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Yes, and while you are doing so, we will take control of the central hill.

speaker: Edelgard
text: If you stand in my way, I will cut you down until you have no blood left to bleed.

speaker: Edelgard
text: What? I was just trying to rally your spirits. Now, to victory!

speaker: Claude
text: Hey Princess! Heads up! There's a rat right by your Imperial feet...

speaker: Edelgard
text: BAH! I—Huh. How dare you make a fool of me. You will not rile me with such childish tactics.

speaker: Claude
text: Ah, so the sheer terror in your eyes was... something else entirely. My mistake. Anyway, it was only a joke.

speaker: Edelgard
text: You really hope to unsettle me with childish jokes? It won't work. You must stand and fight!

speaker: Dimitri
text: So, it is time to cross blades... I never imagined such a day would come to pass.

speaker: Edelgard
text: If the Empire and the Kingdom go to war, we'll be able to fight as much as we please.

speaker: Dimitri
text: I am sorry, but that is not something to joke about. The thought of fighting you is troubling at best.

speaker: Edelgard
text: In that case, I wonder when you'll be able to stomach facing me in battle... Do you need a few moments?

speaker: Claude
text: This is a great chance for me to find out if the Sword of the Creator really is all it's cracked up to be. On that note, you'd better not surrender too quickly!

speaker: Claude
text: Hey, Your Royalness! If you promise to let me have the prize, I'll let you take the honor of victory. Do we have a deal?

speaker: Dimitri
text: Enough of your foolishness! I– Wait a moment. You are trying to anger me, is that it?

speaker: Claude
text: Saw right through me, did you? Well, if there's no deal, I'll just have to win this thing fair and square!

speaker: Dimitri
text: I will happily face you, here and now. Do not hold back, Claude!

speaker: Dimitri
text: How far can I push myself with you as my foe... This will be a great chance to test our mettle. Do not underestimate me, Professor, or you will fail!

speaker: Edelgard
text: I'm sorry, but I must retreat... You should have no trouble winning. Don't give up!

speaker: Edelgard
text: I hate to admit it...but it seems this is as far as the Black Eagle House goes.

speaker: Claude
text: Sorry, but it's about time I make my exit… The rest of you...please, finish the job!

speaker: Claude
text: I hate to say it, but it seems we're at a stalemate. Looks like the Golden Deer won't be winning this round…

speaker: Dimitri
text: I fear I cannot fight any longer. I'm sorry, everyone… Please continue onward to victory!

speaker: Dimitri
text: I suppose my training wasn't enough… The Blue Lions have no choice but to retreat.

speaker: Seteth
text: That is the end of this year's Battle of the Eagle and Lion! And the winners are... The Black Eagles!

speaker: Edelgard
text: Thank you for your hard work, everyone! I daresay that prize is as good as ours.

speaker: Seteth
text: That is the end of this year's Battle of the Eagle and Lion! And the winners are… The Golden Deer!

speaker: Claude
text: A victory worthy of a feast! We did so well, there's no way we didn't secure that prize.

speaker: Seteth
text: That is the end of this year's Battle of the Eagle and Lion! And the winners are... The Blue Lions!

speaker: Dimitri
text: We won! And judging by our performance, I'm certain we have earned the prize as well.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Edelgard. Professor. That was a spectacular battle. You both fought exceptionally well.

speaker: Claude
text: Complete and utter defeat... I would hate to make an enemy of you two.

speaker: Edelgard
text: No need to get carried away with praise. I know you both feel we won by a paper-thin margin. And I won't deny it. If we were to fight again, there's no telling who would prevail. What do you think, Professor?

speaker: Byleth
text: The Blue Lion House was very strong.

speaker: Dimitri
text: I am honored to hear you say that. Still, I must continue to train rigorously.

speaker: Byleth
text: The Golden Deer House was very strong.

speaker: Claude
text: I'm honored! And I'll level with you - I think that margin is at least as wide as two sheets of paper. I mean that.

speaker: Byleth
text: They were nothing.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Professor?! Well, I suppose it's OK to let victory go to your head just this once.

speaker: Claude
text: In any case, I hope the day never comes when we have to put this experience to use.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Agreed. I would hate to know a future in which I'm forced to cross swords with you.

speaker: Edelgard
text: True. Although the Battle of the Eagle and Lion was originally named after a war between the Empire and the Kingdom. But that's all in the past. I'm sure even the name will one day fade from the pages of history.

speaker: Byleth
text: I hope so.

speaker: Byleth
text: Let's do our best to get along.

speaker: Claude
text: How admirable, Teach! On that note, I have a proposition. When we get back to Garreg Mach, let's have a grand feast to bring down the walls between our respective houses. And by a "grand" feast, I mean a fairly regular feast in the dining hall.

speaker: Dimitri
text: It would be a fine opportunity to know each other better. Count me in.

speaker: Edelgard
text: So be it. Let's plan to meet up on the night we return. Is that OK with you, Professor?

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm looking forward to it.

speaker: Byleth
text: We'll celebrate our victory.

speaker: Edelgard
text: What's gotten into you today? I'm not used to seeing you this excited.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Seeing such a big smile on your face is a rare gift... It makes me feel like I can maybe relax a little too.

speaker: Claude
text: Well done, Your Princeliness. I'm certainly not in any hurry to get on your bad side.

speaker: Edelgard
text: I assumed you would attack us head-on. I clearly need to rethink my opinion of you. Well done, Dimitri.

speaker: Dimitri
text: You both deserve equal praise for a battle well fought. All three houses did extremely well. Don't you agree, Professor?

speaker: Byleth
text: The Black Eagle House was very strong.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Not strong enough, clearly. If there's ever a next time, know that I plan to wipe that smile from your face.

speaker: Byleth
text: The Golden Deer House was very strong.

speaker: Claude
text: It's an honor to hear that from a fighter such as yourself! But there's no getting around it. The Blue Lions were better prepared.

speaker: Byleth
text: They were nothing.

speaker: Dimitri
text: It only seemed that way because of the caliber of your command. Even now, we must not allow ourselves to become complacent.

speaker: Claude
text: In any case, I hope the day never comes when we have to put this experience to use.

speaker: Edelgard
text: I wouldn't mind. I'll accept a challenge from either of you at any time. Heh, I'm kidding, of course!

speaker: Dimitri
text: That is nothing to joke about. The true Battle of the Eagle and Lion is best left in the past. In fact, I wouldn't be surprised if they eventually change the name of this mock battle.

speaker: Byleth
text: I hope so.

speaker: Byleth
text: Let's do our best to get along.

speaker: Claude
text: How admirable, Teach! On that note, I have a proposition. When we get back to Garreg Mach, let's have a grand feast to bring down the walls between our respective houses. And by a "grand" feast, I mean a fairly regular feast in the dining hall.

speaker: Edelgard
text: You really value that kind of thing, don't you? Well, I suppose no harm can come from it. Count me in.

speaker: Dimitri
text: I have no objections either. And you, Professor?

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm looking forward to it.

speaker: Byleth
text: We'll celebrate our victory.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Oh! Well, I'm not sure that's the point... Uh, Professor? Was that...a joke?

speaker: Dimitri
text: You look so...happy. I love seeing you like this. I suppose that look on your face is just another boon from this glorious day. Perhaps the best one of all.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Well done, Claude. I see your schemes are not to be underestimated.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Yes, I must wholeheartedly agree. As ever, I have proven to be no match for you.

speaker: Claude
text: It is the utmost honor to receive praise from your royal–  I'm kidding, of course. Really, though, I was lucky to have Teach on my side. In all honesty, you two made me work for it. If I had to face you again, there's no telling which way it would go. What do you think, Teach? How did the other houses fare?

speaker: Byleth
text: The Blue Lion House was very strong.

speaker: Dimitri
text: I appreciate that. Still, it is clear that I must continue to be rigorous in my training.

speaker: Byleth
text: The Black Eagle House was very strong.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Not strong enough, clearly. If there's ever a next time, know that I plan to wipe that smile from your face.

speaker: Byleth
text: They were nothing.

speaker: Claude
text: Too true, Teach! That just about sums it up. Oh, I'm sorry. That's probably too hard for the losers to hear, isn't it?

speaker: Claude
text: In any case, I hope the day never comes when we have to put this experience to use.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Agreed. I would hate to know a future in which I'm forced to cross swords with you.

speaker: Edelgard
text: I wouldn't mind. I'll accept a challenge from either of you at any time. Heh, I'm kidding, of course!

speaker: Claude
text: Well, now that the three-way battle has ended in an Alliance victory, I daresay it's time for some post-battle reconciliation. The victor has but one request. Hear me out... When we get back to Garreg Mach, let's have a grand feast to bring down the walls between our respective houses. And by a "grand" feast, I mean a fairly regular feast in the dining hall.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Hmph. I accept your proposition. Please notify me once your preparations are complete.

speaker: Edelgard
text: It seems I have no choice but to drown my sorrow at losing in overindulgence. I'll help you with the preparations.

speaker: Claude
text: It's not a feast if you don't eat too much! Leave it to the Imperial princess to say such wonderful things.

speaker: Edelgard
text: That's not exactly what I said, but... Ugh, forget it. Laugh all you want.

speaker: Claude
text: Oh, if you insist! Hahahaha! Hey, Teach. Looks like you're having a good time too. Seeing you smile like that means we've got no choice but to have a great time tonight. Let's get going!

speaker: Bernadetta
text: It's finally over... There were way too many strangers at that feast.

speaker: Petra
text: Put your chin high, Bernie. It was a chance for you to have growth.

speaker: Bernadetta
text: But... but everyone was acting so friendly! It was overwhelming...

speaker: Caspar
text: Linhardt, I wasn't done talking to you! If those Alliance guys came at it from here and those Kingdom guys came from there-

speaker: Linhardt
text: I know, I know. We'd have been able to take them all out at once. I heard you. I'm going to bed now.

speaker: Dorothea
text: Did anyone get the feeling that there were already couples forming? That's not really fair, is it? I wanted to sneak off with someone too...

speaker: Ferdinand
text: I was hoping for some tea after our meal anyway. Would you care to join me?

speaker: Dorothea
text: I suppose I can settle for you just this once, Ferdie.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Until today, I thought it would fall to me to command and guide our ranks all by myself. But with you leading us, I've gotten to experience what it's like to fight alongside everyone... And I've realized... how happy it makes me, fighting under your command. The emperor doesn't take orders from anyone. It's their duty to stand alone and lead the entire Empire. But maybe it's better to have someone to rely on... so that you can support and guide each other through the darkness.

speaker: Byleth
text: Am I that someone?

speaker: Byleth
text: I am unfit to guide an emperor.

speaker: Edelgard
text: I may be heir to the Imperial throne, but first and foremost, I'm your grateful student. That will never change, even when I fulfill my destiny and become the emperor. I told you long ago that I wished to enlist you in the service of the Empire. Well, I take it back. Now I wish only for your continued guidance during my eventual reign.

speaker: Linhardt
text: Don't just hide away in the corner, Professor. You're the reason we're celebrating.

speaker: Bernadetta
text: It's because of you that I've had the courage to leave my room for a bit each day.  I'm...I'm so grateful, Professor!

speaker: Ferdinand
text: We were all just discussing how well you led us. Remarkable!

speaker: Petra
text: Your guidance is without parallel, Professor.  I have had practicing of that phrase.

speaker: Caspar
text: Your training's been top notch. Really!

speaker: Dorothea
text: Whatever would we do without you?

speaker: Flayn
text: I have had the opportunity to experience much. Please allow me to offer you my gratitude once more, Professor.

speaker: Edelgard
text: I feel the same... You are something special, my teacher.

speaker: Dimitri
text: I had a wonderful time today, Professor. As usual, I was astonished by how much you ate in the name of celebration! Really, though, I must thank you again. Our victory in the Battle of the Eagle and Lion was thanks, in no small part, to you.

speaker: Byleth
text: We all did our part.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Yes, that is true, but it was your instruction that allowed us to reach our full potential.

speaker: Byleth
text: I agree.

speaker: Dimitri
text: That's the spirit! There's nothing wrong with acknowledging your own strengths every now and then.

speaker: Dimitri
text: I feel silly admitting this now, but when you first came to lead our class...you unnerved me. You never smiled, and you never showed anger either. And yet, you didn't appear to be suppressing your emotions. They just...weren't there. At first I thought perhaps you just didn't care for us, but I soon concluded that wasn't the case at all. For the longest time I just couldn't tell what you were thinking. It was as though you had no humanity whatsoever...

speaker: Byleth
text: That stings.

speaker: Byleth
text: And now?

speaker: Dimitri
text: You're different now. In the half-year we've spent together, I've seen the glow of humanity in your eyes and in your actions countless times. I am truly grateful to have had the chance to spend this time with you, Professor.

speaker: Sylvain
text: What are you two talking about? How dare you get chummy without us!

speaker: Sylvain
text: Getting cozy, are we? Mind if I cut in?

speaker: Dedue
text: That's enough, Sylvain.

speaker: Mercedes
text: Oh please, I would love to join you as well! I have so many things I wish to talk to you about, Professor.

speaker: Annette
text: Oh, me too! I have so much to tell you! And I want to thank you too.

speaker: Ashe
text: Honestly Professor? I was only able to achieve so much because you were with us.

speaker: Ingrid
text: Ashe is right. You're irreplaceable to us, Professor.

speaker: Annette
text: Yes, that! Without you, the Blue Lions... Well, we wouldn't even be the Blue Lions at all! Except for the blue part. Because we'd be sad.

speaker: Felix
text: I suppose...there are worse things than fighting at your side.

speaker: Flayn
text: I have had the opportunity to experience much. Please allow me to offer you my gratitude once more, Professor.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Haha, as you can see, you have our trust, as well as our admiration. I look forward to spending the rest of the year with you.

speaker: Byleth
text: As do I.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Good. Then let's give it our all this year! Anyhow... It's getting late. We had better return to our quarters and get some rest.

speaker: Hilda
text: Ugh, I can't believe our house leader ate so much he passed out. I guess he should just...sleep it off? Oh, Professor! Great work today!

speaker: Ignatz
text: As long as we have you and Claude, the Golden Deer House is unstoppable!

speaker: Lorenz
text: I am sure we did not require Claude for our victory, but it certainly would not have been possible without our professor.

speaker: Lysithea
text: Haha! I'm so please to be in your class, Professor. You truly bring out the best in us.

speaker: Raphael
text: Let's keep fighting! And winning!

speaker: Leonie
text: I knew the tactics you learned from the captain would be something else. I better work harder to catch up!

speaker: Flayn
text: I have had the opportunity to experience much. Please allow me to offer you my gratitude once more, Professor.

speaker: Marianne
text: Because of you, I managed to get through the fight without feeling like a burden. Thank you, Professor.

speaker: Hilda
text: I hear Lady Rhea and Seteth are singing your praises too!

speaker: Byleth
text: You all worked hard.

speaker: Hilda
text: You're always so modest!

speaker: Byleth
text: Our opponents were strong too.

speaker: Hilda
text: Well, I certainly can't deny that.

speaker: Byleth
text: Just wait until you see my true power.

speaker: Hilda
text: Oh, wow! I don't doubt it.

speaker: Claude
text: You really showed them, Teach! I would really hate to be on your bad side.

speaker: Hilda
text: Oh, look. Claude has been revived.

speaker: Claude
text: Your tactics were ingenious, and you've somehow mastered the power of the King of Liberation's Relic. You really are incredible. Though you can be a bit absentminded at times. Your mind is like a giant bowl with a tiny crack in it...

speaker: Hilda
text: Claude, saying that only makes your own mind bowl seem tiny.

speaker: Claude
text: How dare you! My bowl is much bigger than Teach's! Unfortunately, it doesn't just have a crack. The whole bottom of my bowl is missing.

speaker: Lysithea
text: In other words, you are the absentminded one, not our professor.

speaker: Ignatz
text: That's true. He just admitted it.

speaker: Marianne
text: Hehe!

speaker: Leonie
text: It's unusual to hear you laughing, Marianne. Your smile is really cute.

speaker: Lorenz
text: I agree. You really don't know how beauti-- Eh... Never mind.

speaker: Hilda
text: It feels so great to laugh and joke around like this, doesn't it?  Hm? Well, look at that. Someone's having a secret rendezvous in the courtyard...

speaker: Claude
text: All joking aside, I'm having trouble sizing you up, Teach. The honest truth is that I'd hate to have you as an enemy. If possible, I wish for you to fight by my side. If I could use the Sword of the Creator, we wouldn't even be having this conversation. I bet if I could use it, you would trust me to... Right? That selflessness may be what I like best about you.

speaker: Rhea
text: You fought bravely during the Battle of the Eagle and Lion.

speaker: Seteth
text: Comparing against their performance in the mock battle of the Great Tree Moon, the students have grown significantly. I suppose I should praise your efforts.

speaker: Rhea
text: I can only call your deeds during the Battle of the Eagle and Lion...quite versatile.

speaker: Seteth
text: Comparing against their performance in the mock battle of the Great Tree Moon, the students have grown significantly. It is clear that this is a result of your guidance.

speaker: Rhea
text: In appreciation of your efforts, and to show our high hopes for the future of your students, I award you with this.

speaker: Rhea
text: Please continue to instruct your students as a model teacher.

speaker: Sothis
text: So! You've made good use of all my power after all. I would have been upset if you had failed at such an easy task!

speaker: Seteth
text: It pains me to assign such a disturbing mission to you during such a blessed moment in time... However, next month your assignment will be to journey to Remire Village to investigate an abnormal occurrence there.

speaker: Sothis
text: Remire Village... If I recall, you've been there with your father many times.

speaker: Byleth
text: An abnormal occurrence?

speaker: Seteth
text: I have yet to ascertain the details, but it would seem the villages have been acting strangely. I have already dispatched the knights to verify the authenticity of this information. They should be back shortly. I suggest you begin by finding out what they have discovered.

speaker: Rhea
text: I pray this is not a bad omen... May the goddess protect you all.

speaker: Rhea
text: Professor, I have a new mission for your students.

speaker: Seteth
text: We have received reports that Lord Lonato has rallied troops against the Holy Church of Seiros.

speaker: Byleth
text: Who is Lord Lonato?

speaker: Byleth
text: Why would he do that?

speaker: Rhea
text: Lord Lonato is a minor lord of the Kingdom. He has been showing hostility towards the church for some time now.

speaker: Seteth
text: A vanguard unit from the Knights of Seiros is already on its way to his stronghold, Castle Gaspard. Lord Lonato's army is nothing compared to the knights. It's quite possible the rebellion has already been suppressed.

speaker: Rhea
text: Even so, I would like for your class to travel with the knights' rear guard to deal with the aftermath.

speaker: Seteth
text: War zones are unpredictable. We do not expect you will have cause to battle, but be prepared for the worst.

speaker: Catherine
text: Excuse me. You sent for me, Lady Rhea?

speaker: Rhea
text: This is Catherine. She will be leading the knights whom you will be accompanying.

speaker: Catherine
text: Nice to meet you. We've heard a lot about you. If you need anything, just ask.

speaker: Rhea
text: She is one of our bravest knights, and that is no small feat. Only an exceptional few have what it takes to join the Knights of Seiros. This mission should prove useful in demonstrating to the students how foolish it would be to ever turn their blades on the Church...

speaker: Sothis
text: You have spent quite some time in here, engaging in such idle chatter. Do you not know that we do not have a moment left to waste?

speaker: Byleth
text: I had forgotten.

speaker: Sothis
text: Forgotten? I don't believe that is the truth. No, it is more likely you were dreaming the whole day away. You must try harder from now on.

speaker: Byleth
text: I should have listened more intently.

speaker: Sothis
text: You must try harder from now on.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Even within the Knights of Seiros, Catherine is the strongest. By a large margin from what I've gathered. Why not seek her out as a sparring partner, professor?

speaker: Edelgard
text: Lord Lonato must know that his efforts are futile...yet he can't help but fight. If I were in that situation, I would do whatever it took to ensure victory. You can count on that.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Doubtless, there are times when one must take up their blade, even if there's no chance of winning. But this... It's downright senseless. Lord Lonato knows better. If he had enough allies to back his rebellion, it would be a different matter...

speaker: Byleth
text: Allies?

speaker: Byleth
text: How so?

speaker: Dimitri
text: Ah, my apologies. I was just thinking aloud. This whole situation is a bit too strange for my liking. Even with the necessary preparations in place, there is always a chance that something unexpected will occur. Please be ready for anything, Professor.

speaker: Dimitri
text: After Faerghus lost its king, there were many rebellions. It is likely Lord Lonato's provocations are related. How frustrating that I am too young to take the throne. Rendered powerless by age... If the throne is vacant much longer, the Kingdom will fall to ruin!

speaker: Claude
text: First that bandit business, and now a noble rebellion? Are we ever gonna do anything but find and subdue people? Well, if we're just going to tie up loose ends, at least it'll be pretty safe. I don't mind stretching my legs for this one. And if Catherine's going, too, there's a good chance we'll get a look at her Relic in action.

speaker: Claude
text: Hey, Teach. There's some minor noble rebelling in Faerghus, right? He has no chance of winning. I wonder what he hopes to achieve... Huh? Are you going along to help? Sounds like an easy victory, but good luck out there.

speaker: Hubert
text: Something about this situation doesn't feel right. Why would a minor lord raise an army against a foe he cannot possibly hope to defeat?

speaker: Ferdinand
text: My central duty as a noble is to protect the commonfolk. I abhor those like Lord Lonato, who deliberately shatter the peace. Utterly disgraceful.

speaker: Byleth
text: He must have his reasons.

speaker: Byleth
text: I hope no one is hurt.

speaker: Ferdinand
text: You have a kind soul, Professor. Now I feel a little sheepish for showing anger and not empathy. I apologize for my impetuousness.

speaker: Ferdinand
text: I heard about your class's assignment, by the way. Good luck subduing those treasonous nobles!

speaker: Linhardt
text: Professor, I feel I must speak to you about Caspar's eating habits. I've never seen the likes of it. He inhales entire plates of food in mere seconds.

speaker: Byleth
text: Sounds unhealthy.

speaker: Linhardt
text: Hence my mentioning it to you. Good luck with him.

speaker: Byleth
text: He must have a healthy appetite.

speaker: Linhardt
text: If that is a polite way of calling him a goat, I'm inclined to agree.

speaker: Caspar
text: Today's meal was delicious! Linhardt keeps bothering me about eating too fast. Says I'm gonna choke or something.

speaker: Byleth
text: It's not safe to each so quickly.

speaker: Caspar
text: You're really gonna agree with that guy? Why is no one here on my side?

speaker: Byleth
text: When you're busy there's no alternative.

speaker: Caspar
text: Absolutely! I knew you'd see things my way.

speaker: Bernadetta
text: ♪Hm hm-hm hm-hm... ♪ H-huh?! Um, is someone there? What do you want?

speaker: Dorothea
text: Professor, about this month's assignment... Raising an army against the church? Really? Though it looks like we won't be fighting, it's still quite unsettling. My understanding is that it will all be subdued rather quickly.

speaker: Dorothea
text: Are you going to fight alongside the Knights of Seiros? Hmm... Let me know if you meet anyone I might be interested in, OK?

speaker: Petra
text: The plants of Fódlan are different ones than in Brigid. And people here are unknowing of the spirits who watch over the earth and bless it. Only the goddess is known. Is that factual?

speaker: Petra
text: This flower is one that is eating insects. Is that factual too? I am wondering who watches over the plants in Fódlan...

speaker: Dedue
text: His Highness is strong. But on the front lines, anything can happen. Losing him would be devastating for Faerghus. I hope the church understands that.

speaker: Dedue
text: Best be on your guard.

speaker: Felix
text: Catherine, hm? Her skill is impressive, I'll admit. So is her sword. But I think she's hiding something. Nobody knows anything about her past. You should spar with her. She's strong. Stronger than you are, I'd bet.

speaker: Ashe
text: Ngh... Please, Professor, there must be some mistake. Lonato would never raise arms against the church. At least, he never said anything to me about it.

speaker: Ashe
text: What's going to happen to Lonato? If he's killed, I... I don't know how I'll live with that.

speaker: Sylvain
text: Professor, have you seen Felix around? I swear, as soon as you take your eyes off him–poof–he's gone.

speaker: Byleth
text: I saw him at the training ground.

speaker: Sylvain
text: Ah, of course he's there. Sorry for bothering you, Professor. Thanks!

speaker: Byleth
text: I saw him at the dining hall.

speaker: Sylvain
text: Ah, right, it is meal time. Sorry for bothering you, Professor. Thanks!

speaker: Sylvain
text: Don't you love looking after horses? I do. They repay your absolute love and trust with the same. I wish girls were so easy to deal with...

speaker: Mercedes
text: I've heard whispers about Lord Lonato. They say he is a very kind and gentle lord. Why would such a kind man suddenly raise an army? Oh, Professor. You were working late last night, weren't you? You shouldn't overdo it. A ghost might rise up from the well to get you if you stay you too late! Or so I'm told.

speaker: Annette
text: We're going on a mission with the knights, right? I wonder if... Oh... Sorry! It's nothing. I was just wondering if someone I've been searching for might be among them.

speaker: Byleth
text: You're looking for a knight?

speaker: Annette
text: Yes. Well...maybe? If he's here, he's probably a knight. Though it's also possible he became a monk...

speaker: Byleth
text: I hope you find whomever you're looking for.

speaker: Annette
text: Thank you. I'm definitely going to find him one of these days!

speaker: Annette
text: To be honest, I've felt a bit lost here at the monastery. At a loss for what to do. Thankfully, a sweet young girl reached out and offered help. I believe she's Seteth's little sister.

speaker: Ingrid
text: Why does His Highness take the side of the people of Duscur? I just don't understand it. Only four years ago, they murdered our king and slaughtered the soldiers and knights who were with him, all of whom were innocent. Even if he can forgive them, I can't–not ever. What they've done is against all codes of honor and ethics.

speaker: Ingrid
text: We are truly blessed with how fertile the monastery grounds are. Every day, there's something new to harvest!

speaker: Lorenz
text: It's a noble's duty to protect the commonfolk, not to endanger them by rallying armies in such a feckless and improper manner. Abuse of that kind is no better than slavery. A proper noble must guard the people from such a fate, wouldn't you say?

speaker: Byleth
text: I agree.

speaker: Lorenz
text: Precisely why true nobility is well respected.

speaker: Byleth
text: We don't know all the details yet.

speaker: Lorenz
text: There can be no legitimate cause for a noble to abandon that basic obligation. Let us put an end to this quickly.

speaker: Raphael
text: Hey, Professor! Do you happen to have any food on you? I'm starving! No matter how much I eat before I train, I'm always so hungry after. My muscles must be going through a growth spurt!

speaker: Ignatz
text: This place has so many breathtaking works of art. I feel like I'm living in a museum. Each piece can teach us about styles and techniques from a thousand years ago!

speaker: Byleth
text: Do you know a lot about art?

speaker: Ignatz
text: I'm from a family of merchants, so I've been able to see a lot of art, but I won't pretend to be an expert.

speaker: Byleth
text: Do you like art?

speaker: Ignatz
text: Oh yes, very much. I'm from a family of merchants, so I've been able to see a lot of art.

speaker: Lysithea
text: Ah, Professor. It would seem that a minor lord in Faerghus is raising an army… This poses a threat, obviously. But not one for the Kingdom—for the church. I mean, Faerghus doesn’t even have a king at present. There’s something…unsettling about this army. You had better ensure we’re fully prepared.

speaker: Lysithea
text: The monastery grounds are far too spread out. Feels like it takes hours to get from one area to another. And, no, that's not because I'm getting lost. I'm a fully capable, mature person! Who never gets lost.

speaker: Marianne
text: Oh. Hello, Professor... Um. Was there something you needed?

speaker: Byleth
text: I came to see the horses.

speaker: Marianne
text: Oh! You like horses? I like them too. They're such kind creatures.

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm just looking around.

speaker: Marianne
text: I see. I won't bother you, then...

speaker: Hilda
text: Professor, your clothes are a bit dirty. If you don't pay attention to your hygiene, the girls won't like you! I hate when my clothes get dirty. That's one of the many reasons I find it best to train as little as possible.

speaker: Hilda
text: Professor, your clothes are a bit dirty. I'd have expected you to be more careful, seeing as how you're a professor and all. I hate when my clothes get dirty. That's one of the many reasons I find it best to train as little as possible.

speaker: Leonie
text: I'm studying here so I can be the best there is, just like Captain Jeralt. Do you think I've got it in me to be a top tier mercenary, Professor?

speaker: Byleth
text: That depends on how hard you work.

speaker: Leonie
text: I'm going to work a lot harder than all the fancy nobles around here, I can tell you that.

speaker: Byleth
text: You really want to bring the money in, huh?

speaker: Leonie
text: I do! Though, it's about so much more than being rich. It's about honor.

speaker: Rhea
text: Pointing a sword at the Holy Church of Seiros is akin to pointing a sword at the goddess herself. Meting out appropriate punishments to the sinful... It is a sacred duty with which we have been entrusted. As a member of the church yourself, I hope that you will take that to heart.

speaker: Seteth
text: If you have a moment, I would like to have a word. It has been brought to my attention that certain individuals have been making advances towards Flayn. You wouldn't happen to know anything about that, would you?

speaker: Byleth
text: Not at all.

speaker: Byleth
text: Actually...

speaker: Seteth
text: If you do see anyone getting too close with Flayn, please, inform me of it at once.

speaker: Flayn
text: If the flowers within the greenhouse are removed, they will soon wilt and whither... Is that not so, Professor? I feel I can empathize with them... The flowers. Flowers that thrive–despite their environment–are truly inspiring, are they not?

speaker: Alois
text: Past here is the Holy Mausoleum, where the saints of the Church of Seiros slumber. Sorry, but only a select few members of the church are allowed entry. It's open to the public on only one day of the year, for the Goddess's Rite of Rebirth.

speaker: Catherine
text: Here to train? You really are as hardworking as they say.

speaker: Byleth
text: That's an overstatement. I'm just me.

speaker: Catherine
text: Spoken like a true hard worker.

speaker: Byleth
text: That's right. I'm a force of nature.

speaker: Catherine
text: Huh. Maybe the gossip's wrong. Hardworking people usually don't like to make a big fuss about it.

speaker: Jeritza
text: What? I desired fresh air.

speaker: Byleth
text: That's not like you.

speaker: Jeritza
text: True...

speaker: Byleth
text: The wind feels nice.

speaker: Jeritza
text: Hmph.

speaker: Jeralt
text: Castle Gaspard, eh? I've been there once before. Many years ago... It was by request of the son of that family... Christophe, I think it was.

speaker: Hanneman
text: I'm sorry, but I must vent to someone, Professor. You're familiar with Manuela's slovenly behavior, yes? That woman! She borrowed a book last week and returned it with stains of unknown origin on the cover, and several pages either folded or torn. Just now, she dropped a sandwich on the floor, picked it up and kept eating. When she saw my shock, she said simply, "Three second rule." Ugh!

speaker: Manuela
text: Did you hear? There's news of someone in the Kingdom raising an army. The Kingdom, the Empire, the Alliance... They do love a good war, don't they? Spilling the blood of young men and women...and for what? Just to enjoy the horror of it?

speaker: Tomas
text: Professor, I heard that you may battle alongside Catherine. Even among the knights, she is something special⁠—a holy knight who is able to wield a Hero's Relic. Still...she can be a mite difficult.

speaker: Anna
text: Hey, Professor. How's it going? Making lots of coin? I'd love to catch up, but I'm super busy right now. Working. For money. You understand.

speaker: Gatekeeper
text: Greetings, Professor! Nothing to report! Have you talked with Catherine yet? If the knights are the cream of the crop, she's the cream of the cream. Oh, and that Relic of hers! I hear it's nothing short of amazing.

speaker: Knight Of Seiros
text: Since we're heading to Castle Gaspard, that means we'll be passing through Magdred Way. The road is well known for its beautiful surroundings. Depending on the time of year, it can be incredibly foggy, though. When it's like that you can't enjoy the lovely scenery... Lucky for us, it shouldn't be too foggy while we're there. Not that we'll have time for sightseeing anyway.

speaker: Knight Of Seiros
text: I hear that Lord Lonato served the king of Faerghus's older brother when he was younger. Or something like that. He already had status and prestige, so why raise a rebellion? Eh, I guess it's none of my business.

speaker: Knight Of Seiros
text: Catherine has invited me to train with her. How much do you think I should train before I'm ready to train with someone that strong?

speaker: Monk
text: Lord Lonato... He used to stay at the monastery rather frequently. He was such as pious man. A true believer... Such a terrible shame. I wonder what changed him...

speaker: Monk
text: Next month is when a very important ceremony will be taking place at the monastery. Pilgrims from all corners of Fódlan have already started to gather in anticipation. I pray that you are able to nip this trouble in the bud as soon as possible.

speaker: Shifty Merchant
text: Things we can't obtain here are likely obtainable by way of the underground. Are you unfamiliar with Garreg Mach's underground? The place is an absolute paradise for those who can't stay above ground.

speaker: Monk
text: Those Abyssian idiots. All they ever do is cause trouble. We'd best purge the entire underbelly of Garreg Mach.

speaker: Hubert
text: No matter how powerful our enemies may be, there is no need to worry so long as we're with Catherine, the mighty wielder of Thunderbrand.

speaker: Byleth
text: Thunderbrand?

speaker: Byleth
text: What are you talking about?

speaker: Catherine
text: You mean you don't know? My weapon is called Thunderbrand. It's one of the Hero's Relics. A long, long time ago, the goddess bestowed divine weapons upon 10 heroes, which were passed down to their descendants. It's an honor to wield, but I'm afraid there won't be any chance for that today. Our mission is to help clean up the aftermath, not to fight.

speaker: Hubert
text: One must wonder why Lord Lonato would incite such a reckless rebellion.

speaker: Catherine
text: It all goes back to the Tragedy of Duscur...

speaker: Byleth
text: I've heard of it.

speaker: Edelgard
text: I remember that day well. No one saw it coming.

speaker: Byleth
text: I don't know much about it.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Roughly four years ago, the king of Faerghus was murdered by the people of Duscur. I believe that about sums it up, correct?

speaker: Catherine
text: To put it simply, yes. But there's more to that story. They had accomplices within the Kingdom as well. Lord Lonato's son, Christophe, was one of them, and so he was handed over to the church for execution.

speaker: Byleth
text: The church executes criminals?

speaker: Catherine
text: Speaking from the church's perspective, we simply passed judgement according to our doctrine in place of the Kingdom, which was in complete chaos.

speaker: Byleth
text: Why was the king targeted?

speaker: Catherine
text: King Lambert was attempting a major political reform. Needless to say, he had many enemies.

speaker: Dimitri
text: I have to say... It's a real honor to accompany such a brave and distinguished knight. None other than Catherine, wielder of Thunderbrand!

speaker: Byleth
text: Thunderbrand?

speaker: Catherine
text: You mean you don't know? My weapon is called Thunderbrand. It's one of the Hero's Relics. A long, long time ago, the goddess bestowed divine weapons upon 10 heroes, which were passed down to their descendants. It's an honor to wield, but I'm afraid there won't be any chance for that today. Our mission is to help clean up the aftermath, not to fight.

speaker: Ashe
text: Why would Lonato incite such a reckless rebellion?

speaker: Catherine
text: You should know more about that than any of us, Ashe.

speaker: Ashe
text: Well, I don't. Lonato never mentioned anything of the like to me.

speaker: Dimitri
text: He probably didn't want you getting caught up in his own personal vendetta.

speaker: Byleth
text: Is Ashe related to Lord Lonato?

speaker: Ashe
text: I'm Lonato's adopted son. He raised me as though I were his own blood. He was always so kind. I don't understand... I guess it has to do with Christophe.

speaker: Byleth
text: What vendetta?

speaker: Catherine
text: How much do you know about the Tragedy of Duscur, Professor?

speaker: Byleth
text: I've heard of it.

speaker: Byleth
text: I don't know much about it.

speaker: Catherine
text: It's when the king of the Holy Kingdom of Faerghus was...was murdered by the people of Duscur. It happened about four years ago...

speaker: Dimitri
text: It's OK, Catherine. Please, go on.

speaker: Catherine
text: Right. Well, Lord Lonato's son, Christophe, was accused of being involved in that whole awful affair. He was executed by the church.

speaker: Byleth
text: The church executes prisoners?

speaker: Catherine
text: Speaking from the church's perspective, we simply passed judgement according to our doctrine in place of the Kingdom, which was in complete chaos.

speaker: Byleth
text: Why was the king targeted?

speaker: Catherine
text: King Lambert was attempting a major political reform. Needless to say, he had many enemies.

speaker: Claude
text: It really is an honor to accompany Catherine, wielder of Thunderbrand. I hear you're intimidating enough to silence the howling winds!

speaker: Byleth
text: Thunderbrand?

speaker: Catherine
text: You mean you don't know? My weapon is called Thunderbrand. It's one of the Hero's Relics. A long, long time ago, the goddess bestowed divine weapons upon 10 heroes, which were passed down to their descendants. It's an honor to wield, but I'm afraid there won't be any chance for that today. Our mission is to help clean up the aftermath, not to fight.

speaker: Claude
text: Why would Lonato incite such a reckless rebellion? He had to have known he had no chance of winning.

speaker: Catherine
text: It all goes back to the Tragedy of Duscur...

speaker: Byleth
text: I've heard of it.

speaker: Byleth
text: I don't know much about it.

speaker: Claude
text: You must be joking. Where have you been traveling that news of it didn't reach you?

speaker: Claude
text: It happened about four years ago. The king of the Holy Kingdom of Faerghus was murdered by the people of Duscur. That about covers it, right?

speaker: Catherine
text: To put it simply, yes. But there's more to that story. They had accomplices within the Kingdom as well. Lord Lonato's son, Christophe, was one of them, and so he was handed over to the church for execution.

speaker: Byleth
text: The church executes criminals?

speaker: Catherine
text: Speaking from the church's perspective, we simply passed judgement according to our doctrine in place of the Kingdom, which was in complete chaos.

speaker: Byleth
text: Why was the king targeted?

speaker: Catherine
text: King Lambert was attempting a major political reform. Needless to say, he had many enemies.

speaker: Catherine
text: Whatever the truth behind that incident may be, Lord Lonato has harbored resentment to the church ever since. Well... To be more specific, his grudge isn't only against the church. It's also against the one who turned Christophe over to them...

speaker: Church Soldier
text: Report! The enemy is approaching! They can't be avoided. Their numbers are far greatly than we predicted. They used the fog to slip past the knights' perimeter!

speaker: Catherine
text: It looks like our mission just changed, Professor. Everyone, prepare for battle!

speaker: Catherine
text: With this fog, it's impossible to tell where the enemy might be...or how many of them there are. The enemy could be trying to surround us, but they shouldn't have enough soldiers to form a tight circle. Take down anyone who breaks through the fog, and let's push through!

speaker: Edelgard
text: That smell... It's fresh blood. It seems the battle has already started within the fog.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Shouting from within the fog... It seems the knights are already battling.

speaker: Claude
text: The conditions are the same for both sides... But we're at a disadvantage for not knowing the terrain.

speaker: Catherine
text: Proceed with caution! Wait for them to enter your field of view.

speaker: Narration
text: You can earn a reward if your allies do not suffer heavy losses. Be careful not to let your allies flee!

speaker: Militia
text: Lord Lonato doesn't deserve such sadness and anger... Now it's your turn to suffer!

speaker: Ashe
text: Why, Lonato? Why did you drag so many others into this?

speaker: Militia
text: You would think we're just gonna do nothing while you try to kill our lord?!

speaker: Narration
text: The fog is lifting as a result of the Dark Mage being defeated! It seems the fog was being caused by magic.

speaker: Gaspard Commander
text: I won't let you anywhere near Lord Lonato!

speaker: Lonato
text: It's you. Thunderstrike Cassandra! It was your wretched zealotry that killed my son!

speaker: Catherine
text: The only name I answer to is "Catherine". Prepare to taste the blade of one who serves the goddess. Now you face a Knight of Seiros!

speaker: Lonato
text: The fog has cleared. There's nothing left to hide you or the filthy Central Church from the judgement of the goddess!

speaker: Militia
text: Lord Lonato... Please, don't die...

speaker: Edelgard
text: I'm sorry, but I don't believe Lord Lonato has the strength to carry on.

speaker: Dimitri
text: I am sorry... But did you really think you would get away with this?

speaker: Claude
text: The nobles start the war, but it's the commoners who spill their blood first...

speaker: Lonato
text: You have been deceived by that witch... I will show you the truth!

speaker: Lonato
text: You! I will be the one to kill you, no other!

speaker: Catherine
text: You have lost all sense of justice.  You want to fight me? So be it. I'll send you to meet your goddess.

speaker: Lonato
text: Stand down, Ashe. I must destroy these evil-doers by any means necessary!

speaker: Ashe
text: Please surrender, Lonato! Whatever your reason for doing this, we can still talk it out!

speaker: Lonato
text: Rhea is an infidel who has deceived the people and desecrated the goddess! We have virtue and the goddess herself on our side!

speaker: Ashe
text: Even if all that's true, dragging the townsfolk into it like this isn't right!

speaker: Lonato
text: Enough. If that is how you feel, prepare yourself! I'm putting an end to this!

speaker: Lonato
text: I apologize, Your Highness. It is regrettable that we should cross swords like this.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Lonato, I sympathize with your position. I really do. I have no wish to kill you, but I am afraid you have left me no choice. Please...forgive me.

speaker: Lonato
text: Your Highness... I cannot stop here. For my child, and for the people of Fódlan. If you will not stand aside, then I have no choice but to cut you down.

speaker: Lonato
text: That vile woman... Christophe... Forgive me...

speaker: Ashe
text: Lonato, I...

speaker: Catherine
text: I never thought I'd see Lonato meet this fate.  Well done, everyone. Let's gather our troops and go.

speaker: Caspar
text: Damn it! It was all so pointless. I've never seen so many people utterly heartbroken...

speaker: Ferdinand
text: Forcing innocent citizens to risk their lives... That man was not a noble, but a monster.

speaker: Hubert
text: What could have pushed Lord Lonato to this point?

speaker: Edelgard
text: Everyone was a bit shaken by the militia fighting alongside our enemies.

speaker: Byleth
text: No use dwelling on it.

speaker: Byleth
text: That is the reality of battle.

speaker: Edelgard
text: If only everyone could face reality so unflinchingly. The commoners who allied themselves with Lord Lonato believed they were fighting for a just cause. It would be disrespectful to consider them simply victims when they died for what they believed in. Still, we have no choice but to eliminate those who cling to unreasonable ideas of justice. Even if our enemies are the gods themselves...we must never lose sight of our goal.

speaker: Byleth
text: That's taking it a bit far.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Is it? Such a day may come, whether you expect it or not. You should be ready.

speaker: Byleth
text: Agreed.

speaker: Edelgard
text: I'm surprised to hear you say that.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Really, I'm just like Lonato. I, too, will be the sort of ruler who's willing to risk the lives of my citizens in service of a higher cause. It's not possible to change the world without sacrifice. Dying for the greater good is not a death in vain.

speaker: Catherine
text: Professor... I'm afraid this incident is far more serious than anticipated.

speaker: Ashe
text: Why... Why did this happen? Lonato was always such a kind man... Everyone in the village was...was so nice to me. And I...I killed them. I killed them all! I had to, I know I had to... I know that! But still... What does that make me?

speaker: Dimitri
text: Please, don't beat yourself up, Ashe. We did what had to be done.

speaker: Ashe
text: I'm...I'm sorry. I shouldn't be bothering you. I'm...I'm going to check on the town. I hope my brother and sister are OK.

speaker: Dimitri
text: That...that was my first time killing civilians too... Those who I'm sworn to protect.

speaker: Byleth
text: It was a necessary sacrifice.

speaker: Byleth
text: That is the reality of war.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Are you insane?! Those weren't knights or soldiers, but fathers and sons! We...we shouldn't have killed them. We should have found another way... I...I'm sorry. It's not fair for me to blame you for the circumstance. I know that if we hadn't...done what we did, even more civilian lives would have been lost. At least, my mind understands that. But...my heart... Professor... Those in power, no matter the era, always claim they fight for a just cause. That they take life to protect it. But... Is it truly OK to take any life you please, all in service of some implacable "just cause"? Lord Lonato didn't take up arms out of a lust for power. He simply believed his cause to be just. Who's to say it wasn't? Maybe we didn't have to cut him down like that. Maybe we could have reached a mutual understanding...found a path of peace. I...I have to believe that. Perhaps the notion sounds laughable to you. Mere lip service to naive ideals. But I can't believe otherwise.

speaker: Catherine
text: Sorry to intrude, but this incident may be more serious than anticipated.

speaker: Claude
text: Nice work, Teach. Still...that fight left a foul taste in my mouth. That aside, did you see how Catherine fought?

speaker: Byleth
text: She's incredible.

speaker: Claude
text: Agreed. I thought the power of the Heroes' Relics must be exaggerated, but I was clearly wrong.

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm stronger.

speaker: Claude
text: Ha! I love the confidence, Teach. But you're no match for the Heroes' Relics. They're on a whole different level.

speaker: Claude
text: Makes you wonder about that legend...

speaker: Byleth
text: What legend?

speaker: Claude
text: Oh, it's nothing. Just the usual fanciful nonsense. An ancient Relic that once cut a mountain in half with a single swing. That's what they say, anyway. But as amazing as Thunderbrand is, I don't think it fits that description. Apparently, Relics can harness tremendous power for those with a compatible Crest. Though you can technically use one so long as you have any Crest at all. I dunno. Long story short, I'd like to try cutting a mountain in half someday.

speaker: Hilda
text: Ooh! Are you talking about Relics? You'll be able to wield one soon, Claude! I just know it! After all, you've already been selected as the next head of House Riegan!

speaker: Claude
text: Easy there, Hilda. I don't know how apt "soon" is. My grandfather is still unbearably healthy. Oh? Is this news to you, Teach? Yours truly was recently recognized as a legitimate child of House Riegan. They possess one of the Heroes' Relics too, though I've yet to see it.

speaker: Byleth
text: Just recently?

speaker: Claude
text: I officially joined House Riegan only last year. Before then, I lived with my father.

speaker: Byleth
text: You haven't seen it?

speaker: Claude
text: I was raised by my father. House Riegan is on my mother's side of the family.

speaker: Claude
text: When I learned that my mother was the daughter of an Alliance noble, I was so surprised I thought the whole world was pulling a fast one on me for a week.

speaker: Hilda
text: So that means your mother is Duke Riegan's daughter, right? Where is she now?

speaker: Claude
text: I can't say. My mother's currently living in a different world than the one she grew up in and has no desire to return home.

speaker: Hilda
text: Um, OK. You sure have a lot of secrets, don't you?

speaker: Claude
text: I'm just keeping a promise to my parents. Make of that whatever you will. In exchange for my so-called secrecy, I'm free to do as I please, which is why I decided to see what the other side of my family was like. That's how I found out about this strange Crest I bear...

speaker: Leonie
text: Professor, Claude. It sounds like the troops will be withdrawing soon. We should return as well.

speaker: Ignatz
text: We won. We should be celebrating. Instead, we're heading back with heavy hearts...

speaker: Claude
text: Whoa there! What's the matter? You look as sad as a kitten without any yarn. If we hadn't done what we did, the rebel army would have followed this road all the way to the monastery. And they would have crushed all the little villages along the way. We stopped that from happening. You should be proud.

speaker: Catherine
text: Sorry to intrude, but this incident may be more serious than anticipated.

speaker: Catherine
text: I found this on Lord Lonato. It's a note that mentions a plan to assassinate Lady Rhea. We can't tell who sent it, so the source is suspect, but the content is too disturbing to ignore. We must report this to Lady Rhea right away. I hope that it's nothing...

speaker: Rhea
text: I am glad to see that you have returned safely. The goddess is gracious with her divine protection. But it was not only her divine protection that shielded you, was it? You are just as skilled as I had hoped.

speaker: Byleth
text: My students deserve the praise.

speaker: Rhea
text: I am not so sure.

speaker: Byleth
text: I still have much to learn.

speaker: Rhea
text: There is no need for modesty.

speaker: Rhea
text: I heard some of the students were...hesitant about fighting militia. However, we must punish any sinner who may inflict harm upon believers, even if those sinners are civilians. I pray the students learned a valuable lesson about the fate that awaits all who are foolish enough to point their blades towards the heavens.

speaker: Seteth
text: Our real concern is what Catherine reported. The secret message that was in Lord Lonato's possession. It contained a deplorable plot to target the archbishop on the day of the Goddess's Rite of Rebirth. The plan seems unrealistic at best, but a threat is a threat. We must maintain constant vigilance. To that end, I would like for you and your students to help with security on the day of the ritual.

speaker: Byleth
text: You can count on us.

speaker: Rhea
text: That is most reassuring. You have my gratitude.

speaker: Byleth
text: We won't let her down.

speaker: Rhea
text: That is most reassuring. You have my gratitude.

speaker: Byleth
text: Won't that endanger the students?

speaker: Rhea
text: Even if they encounter an enemy whom they cannot best, they should be fine so long as they have you on their side.

speaker: Seteth
text: The Rite of Rebirth is of paramount importance. It is when the Church of Seiros and its believers unite to pray for the return of the goddess. The archbishop and I will be confined to the Goddess Tower once the ritual begins. Of course, the knights will be on high alert as well, but there aren't enough of them to keep watch on every corner of the monastery. It is far from ideal to be forced to mobilize students, but the gravity of this situation requires that we all bend to avoid breaking.

speaker: Rhea
text: While there is no need to fear for my safety, we cannot turn a blind eye to those who would blaspheme so heinously.

speaker: Seteth
text: With any luck, this will all be for naught. Still, be on your guard.

speaker: Edelgard
text: You're here again... Professor... You've been crying. So even you cry sometimes. Oh... I suppose that was thoughtless of me to say.

speaker: Byleth
text: Yes, it was.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Long ago, someone said the same to me.

speaker: Byleth
text: It's fine.

speaker: Edelgard
text: My teacher. You're so blinded by grief that you can't see what's going on right in front of you.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Are you waiting for time to heal your wounds? Or have you curled up in a corner and lost the will to carry on?

speaker: Byleth
text: Does it matter?

speaker: Edelgard
text: It does. You've lost yourself.

speaker: Byleth
text: How could you ask me something like that?

speaker: Edelgard
text: It's not like you to speak to me like that. You know I'd never ask you a question without purpose.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Only you can truly understand your own sadness. Others can sympathize or even empathize, but all anyone else can offer are the tears of an outsider looking in. So I have no intention of crying for you, or of standing still with you. All I can do is promise to reach out my hand when the time comes for me to move forward.

speaker: Byleth
text: What do you mean?

speaker: Edelgard
text: The mysterious organization that was carrying out experiments in Remire Village and the chapel... They're up to something near Garreg Mach. The archbishop has sent the knights to undertake a large-scale investigation. No information has surfaced yet, but our enemies will soon be discovered. When they are, will you lead us into battle? Or will you just sit here with no thought for the future that is fast approaching? My teacher... There is a choice to be made. I hope you make the right one.

speaker: Sothis
text: My, my. She really is quite arrogant. She spoke her mind without an ounce of reservation! But she is right. The time has come to stand again. You already know what your answer is.

speaker: Monica
text: Oh, thank you. You saved me!

speaker: Thales
text: If you were to die, then the mystery of our bodies would be revealed. Preventing that was my only aim. I'm afraid you must remain, Kronya. There is something I need you to do.

speaker: Monica
text: Oh, of course. I am always happy to cooperate with Solon. Leave it to me.

speaker: Flame Emperor
text: How annoying.

speaker: Thales
text: Flame Emperor... Is she offending you? Unfortunately, we cannot take our eyes off her, so there is nothing to be done. You are our greatest creation. We used the defiled beast's blood as the fuel to your flame, that you may burn even the gods. Now is the time to cleanse Fódlan of that power, and bring forth our salvation.

speaker: Flame Emperor
text: There will be no salvation for you and your kind. Those responsible for such gruesome deeds in Duscur and Enbarr.

speaker: Thales
text: All so that you may acquire the strength you need. All for a purpose...

speaker: Sothis
text: What are you going at this hour? Ooh, I know... You are eavesdropping! I must admit that I approve.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Professor? We must remain quiet...

speaker: Sothis
text: I see... The Flame Emperor and Monica...and the mage who rescued Monica.

speaker: Byleth
text: It's time for revenge.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Not yet, Professor.

speaker: Byleth
text: What is that guy's name?

speaker: Dimitri
text: I don't know, but if we keep listening, we might be able to find out.

speaker: Sothis
text: An unexpected change to hear their plans! Patience, patience!

speaker: Monica
text: Oh, thank you. You saved me!

speaker: Thales
text: If you were to die, then the mystery of our bodies would be revealed. Preventing that was my only aim. I'm afraid you must remain, Kronya. There is something I need you to do.

speaker: Monica
text: Oh, of course. I am always happy to cooperate with Solon. Leave it to me.

speaker: Flame Emperor
text: How annoying.

speaker: Thales
text: Flame Emperor... Is she offending you? Unfortunately, we cannot take our eyes off her, so there is nothing to be done. You are our greatest creation. We used the defiled beast's blood as the fuel to your flame, that you may burn even the gods. Now is the time to cleanse Fódlan of that power, and bring forth our salvation.

speaker: Flame Emperor
text: There will be no salvation for you and your kind. Those responsible for such gruesome deeds in Duscur and Enbarr.

speaker: Thales
text: All so that you may acquire the strength you need. All for a purpose...

speaker: Dimitri
text: I've got you... Finally...

speaker: Byleth
text: Wait.

speaker: Byleth
text: Don't go out there.

speaker: Byleth
text: Let's keep listening.

speaker: Dimitri
text: If we don't act now, we'll miss our chance!

speaker: Flame Emperor
text: Hmm...

speaker: Thales
text: Hmph. Even if someone has overhead us, there is nothing they can do. There have always been rats in the walls, and there always will be.

speaker: Dimitri
text: No... The dagger...

speaker: Byleth
text: What's wrong?

speaker: Byleth
text: What about the dagger?

speaker: Dimitri
text: It...no. Never mind. It couldn't possibly be so. Professor, those are the ones we must destroy. They're the bastards who killed my family and Jeralt. For now, let's return to the monastery and regroup. As for the Flame Emperor's dagger...I'll hold on to it for the time being.

speaker: Sothis
text: Day 5 of the Garland Moon. I picked some flowers for her and returned home. The look of joy on her face at the sight of these flowers will be even more beautiful than the flowers themselves… Yeesh! That is enough. His entries from before your birth are full of such romantic blatherings as that. Oh… It must be deeply moving you to hear such things, but now is not the time for whimsy. Someone is here. You do not wish for them to see you in this state. So pull yourself together!

speaker: Claude
text: I thought I might find you here, Teach. Not the type to wallow in solitude, eh? That's a relief, let me tell you. So… What were you reading? Is that Jeralt's…

speaker: Byleth
text: Diary.

speaker: Claude
text: So it is.

speaker: Byleth
text: Love letter.

speaker: Claude
text: The contents are certainly bittersweet… But I think it's Jeralt's diary.

speaker: Claude
text: Hey, maybe this has some entries from when Jeralt left the monastery.

speaker: Claude
text: Is that so… He was the captain of the knights, but something made him leave the monastery in a hurry. If it has something to do with your birth, knowing what happened may get us closer to knowing what secrets the church is hiding… Teach… Would you mind letting me read that diary? I know how important it is to you, but I'm not asking lightly. Please, allow me to borrow it.

speaker: Byleth
text: You may borrow it.

speaker: Claude
text: I'm forever in your debt, Teach. If you'd refused, I would've had to sneak in here in the dead of night. I wasn't looking forward to that prospect. Anyway, let me fill you in on what's been going on lately, and not just as thanks for pointing me to that diary.

speaker: Byleth
text: I can't allow it.

speaker: Claude
text: Wait, are you really saying I'm going to have to sneak in here in the dead of night to read it? I know how important it is to you, but I'm not asking lightly. Please, allow me to borrow it.

speaker: Claude
text: Rhea dispatched the knights to various locations in a frantic search for the enemy. There's a rumor that she's already secured some information. Something big is gonna happen soon. That has me wondering… If you find out where the enemy is, what will you do about it? If you ask, I… No, scratch that. All of us students would gladly lend a hand. Even if it means going against Rhea's wishes. Don't forget it. Now go. Everyone's worried about you. You'd better show them you're in good spirits.

speaker: Sothis
text: If you must weep, then weep. I shall be here for you.

speaker: Byleth
text: Thank you.

speaker: Sothis
text: Well, it would be ridiculous not to feel anything after something like that. Go on and let it out. I am here.

speaker: Byleth
text: That won't be necessary.

speaker: Sothis
text: Are you already past it? You are unflappable. I will give you that much. In that case, I will remain silently supportive. You are right that we must keep moving ever onward.

speaker: Edelgard
text: Professor, I'm so happy to see you. You're finally returning to your old self. To see the light in your eyes again is a gift. It inspires me to carry on as well. As you know, the knights are searching furiously for any trace of the enemies who escaped. I'll inform you immediately if I learn anything relevant.

speaker: Edelgard
text: What happened to Jeralt... It's terrible. If there's anything I can do, simply ask. Even if what you desire is revenge...I'll gladly lend you my power. We can't let them get away with this.

speaker: Dimitri
text: Professor! Welcome back... I was... We all were...  You've been on our minds. Know that your enemies are my enemies. I will do all I can to help you find justice. There is no one else I can... My strength is yours alone. I will fight as you command... I will kill anyone should you ask it of me.

speaker: Dimitri
text: I'm so sorry about what happened to Jeralt... No...of course my sorrow is nothing compared to yours. The knights are even now searching for our enemies' whereabouts. They are to report back the moment they find something. If you desire revenge, Professor...you can count me in.

speaker: Claude
text: Hi, Teach. I see the storm in your eyes has passed… You're looking much better. I've been reading Jeralt's diary. The baby he mentions… That's you, isn't it? I can't understand about half of what's written on here… But Jeralt really cherished you. That much is clear.

speaker: Claude
text: I haven't lost a parent yet, so I can't even begin to understand how you must be feeling... But even while you're standing still, the world keeps on moving. I always find that oddly comforting.

speaker: Hubert
text: I've never been much for condolences. How about a little logic, instead? The knights have spread out around Garreg Mach in search of Jeralt's murderers. Thus, the monastery's fighting strength is, for the moment at least, depleted. Perhaps that was the enemy's real objective. We should be prepared for further confrontation.

speaker: Hubert
text: I've never been much for condolences.

speaker: Petra
text: Professor, please lend us your ears. Ferdinand is saying impossible things.

speaker: Ferdinand
text: I do not see what is impossible about it. All I said was that if you want to go back to Brigid, you probably can. You are...the Empire's guest, so to speak. They cannot afford for something bad to happen to you. There would be a diplomatic incident. Someone close to us has turned up dead, so one could argue that you're not safe here anymore.

speaker: Petra
text: You were already told! I am learning here, from the academy. What are you thinking, Professor?

speaker: Byleth
text: You do not have to leave if you do not wish it.

speaker: Byleth
text: You may return home if you please.

speaker: Petra
text: I am not returning to home until I have grabbed my goal! I will not be listening to the words of Ferdinand.

speaker: Ferdinand
text: No, look, I did not mean to pressure you. Apologies for the misunderstanding.

speaker: Linhardt
text: I slipped quietly into the vault and rummaged about, looking for anything we might find useful. There is a group of people who want to kill us, after all. What? This is no time for asking permission. I learned long ago that one can ask permission or forgiveness. It is rarely useful to request the former. Still, it appears that the knights have already taken everything useful. There were Crest-related objects I thought might be worth studying, so– There you go again with that stern look. Of course I'll put them back when I'm done. Assuming they bear no additional use.

speaker: Caspar
text: I'm not even close to being strong enough. I mean, Jeralt was so much stronger than me, but even he... That's enough. I can't dwell on the past. There's no way to know what my future holds but I do know one thing. Whatever happens, I have to make my own way in this world. I have to keep pushing so I can grow even stronger!

speaker: Bernadetta
text: Professor? I, um, I brought some flowers for Jeralt.

speaker: Byleth
text: Thank you.

speaker: Bernadetta
text: It's the least I can do. Sometimes I feel like all I do is run away...

speaker: Byleth
text: You're out of your room...

speaker: Bernadetta
text: Hey! Sometimes I go out for, uh...walks...

speaker: Bernadetta
text: Anyway, I'll go lay them out.

speaker: Dorothea
text: I've sung lyrics lamenting death many times on stage... But when something like this happens in real life... I'm lost. I don't know what to say. But I do know this much... Sir Jeralt must have been very proud to have you as his child.

speaker: Dedue
text: It is a shame what happened to Jeralt. I am sorry. There are no words. Leave some flowers on his grave for me.

speaker: Sylvain
text: Dark expressions don't suit you, Professor. But I'm... Well, I'm glad to see you out in the world again. It seems this month will be a quiet one around here. There aren't many knights around to liven things up.

speaker: Felix
text: Most of the knights are gone, seeking out the enemy.

speaker: Sylvain
text: Isn't that a bit much? I agree it's important, but is it a good idea to neglect the safety of the monastery?

speaker: Felix
text: What do you think, Professor?

speaker: Byleth
text: It would be a shame if we were invaded.

speaker: Felix
text: I agree. We can send some knights after our enemies, but so many? It makes the church seem reckless.

speaker: Byleth
text: You're worrying too much.

speaker: Sylvain
text: Hopefully the knights finish their business and hurry back. I wouldn't mind having a few extra lances around.

speaker: Ashe
text: Not just Tomas, but Monica too. We can't be sure who to trust anymore, can we? Who are these people, really? What do they want?

speaker: Mercedes
text: I'm so glad you're OK, Professor. I was so worried!

speaker: Annette
text: Oh, Professor! You must be starving. Mercie and I made some sweets for you. We were thinking that if you were to eat something sweet, it might help you feel better.

speaker: Byleth
text: Thank you for the thought.

speaker: Mercedes
text: Baking sweets is my specialty. I'm sure they'll do the trick.

speaker: Byleth
text: I'm fine.

speaker: Annette
text: Well, of course you are! And if you have sweets you'll be even more fine.

speaker: Ingrid
text: I'm so sorry... I never quite know what to say at times like these... Just...don't push yourself too hard too soon. It's OK to allow yourself to be sad right now. Losing someone dear to you... Well, each loss is unique, but it's a feeling I know very well. That said... Professor, I...

speaker: Lorenz
text: There is no one here who has not heard tales of Jeralt's valor. We have suffered a most dear loss. I do not know what the enemy's aim was, but I do know this–after what they have done, we cannot suffer them to live. If there is anything I can do to ensure that justice is brought swiftly, you need only give the word.

speaker: Raphael
text: You've gotta keep yourself active during tough times, Professor. Even if it seems impossible. That's how I got through when I lost my parents. If you need help with anything, just come and see me. Eating and training are my specialties.

speaker: Ignatz
text: I'm scared. I feel that I don't understand the world. How could something like that happen to Jeralt? He was so strong.

speaker: Byleth
text: Even though you're scared, push through.

speaker: Ignatz
text: You're inspiring, Professor. Ill do my best.

speaker: Byleth
text: What happens, happens.

speaker: Ignatz
text: I suppose, but... Please, take care, Professor! We can't afford to lose you too.

speaker: Lysithea
text: I'm sure you will pull through this because you're so strong, Professor. Best to stay calm during such tumultuous and upsetting times. We don't know the nature of our enemies. If we underestimate them, anything could happen.

speaker: Byleth
text: But if we don't defeat them…

speaker: Lysithea
text: I agree they must be defeated, but I also feel we must approach this with prudence.

speaker: Byleth
text: We should be careful.

speaker: Lysithea
text: Yes, I agree. I…don't want to lose you too, Professor.

speaker: Hilda
text: Professor! People are saying horrible things about Marianne. They're saying she's friends with the bad guys. If I hear someone say that, I'll…

speaker: Marianne
text: Leave it alone, Hilda. It doesn't matter.

speaker: Byleth
text: Just ignore it.

speaker: Marianne
text: Of course. Thank you, Professor.

speaker: Byleth
text: We'll defeat the bad guys. We'll show them.

speaker: Hilda
text: That would be the quickest way to resolve this. Come on Marianne, let's give it our all.

speaker: Marianne
text: I'll say a prayer for Jeralt's soul. There's not much else I can do…

speaker: Hilda
text: Professor, it seems like you're holding up OK, but… I'm worried about Leonie. She really loved Jeralt. I hope she can bounce back…

speaker: Leonie
text: Captain Jeralt's gone. He's gone. And we'd only just reunited... I'm sorry. I'm sorry, I'm sure this is even harder on you. But I just can't– I can't believe...

speaker: Rhea
text: Professor... How are you holding up? I know how heavily grief weighs upon one's heart... I lost my mother some time ago. It was... Forgive me my moment of weakness. Even all these years later, I cannot recall that time without feeling the pain as if it were brand new. Just know that I am praying for your mind and your heart to find peace.

speaker: Seteth
text: First Tomas, and now Monica. I do have a theory, though I admit it is nothing more than speculation. Both Tomas and Monica have each gone missing at one time or another. It was reported that when Monica returned from her disappearance, she began to act like a completely different person. As if, perhaps, the real Monica had been killed and replaced by an impostor. Thinking of it like that, it is possible that this Solon had been impersonating Tomas for some time. How they managed such a convincing change of appearance, though, I still do not understand.

speaker: Flayn
